story:
About Me
I've been studying ballet since I was a toddler and teaching now for nearly 15 years.  I've been so fortunate to receive world-class training and to be able to bring that caliber of instruction into people's lives all over Philadelphia by teaching for studios, universities, and dance companies.  The global pandemic has now allowed me to also bring this instruction via Zoom all over the world as far as Iran, Tunisia, Germany, the UK, Ireland, France, South Africa, Brazil, Ecuador, Mexico, Canada, and Japan.  I'm so excited to now be able to bring quality ballet instruction to even more people under my own name. 

What We Need & What You Get

My studio space is bright and welcoming and in need of the ballet treatment which includes:

  • A floating subfloor with a marley layer so that students can jump and turn freely without risk of injury : $5,500
  • Ballet barres for stability. $3,000
  • Mirrors for self evaluation. $3,000
  • Speakers for class music. $500
  • All funds will be applied to the above mentioned needs, even if I don't reach my entire goal.

Your donations will help me to provide an excellent ballet class experience for you, for the community at-large, and for students all over the world virtually.

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you unable to contribute but still want to help?

  • Sharing this campaign with your friends and followers on social media helps to get the word out.  Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
--------------------------------------------

What We Need

In order to bring this production to LA, we need to raise a minimum of $10.000, which will cover venue costs, and allow for other funds to go towards rehearsal space and compensating our artists!

Any donation, no matter how small, will make a difference to the quality of our experience with this piece—and will bring us that much closer to showcasing these italian-american theatre-makers. Thank you for your support!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Some are born great;

 

Project Nongenue started with a dream of representation and deep commitment to classical text. In 2017, a group of like-minded individuals broke open the Los Angeles classical theater scene with a critically acclaimed all-women production of Julius Caesar in an Echo Park parking lot. Since then, Project Nongenue has only grown in skill, ambition and hunger to create and perform deeply underrepresented narratives within Los Angeles theater and the entertainment industry at large - focusing on the ancient texts and stories which have shaped western society. At this poignant historical moment, we are bringing the Nongenue lens to Shakespeare's beloved Twelfth Night - opting to use its alternative title in our alternative examination of it: What You Will.

Shakespeare's Twelfth Night begins with a shipwreck that disrupts everything - creating a leading lady who crossdresses for survival, social elites who accidentally fall in love with members of the "wrong" gender, a servant who courts a duchess, and other social anarchies. Historically, productions have often regarded the instances of queerness and gender non-conforming behavior in this play as the butt of a joke, but our production of What You Will instead centers an earnest exploration these unconventional desires, bodies and identities. This play will shed light on the often invisible machinations of gender and sexuality, and challenge us to consider what our own desires might look like in a world with less restrictive norms.

Classical theater, historically, has not been a safe or understanding place for queer people, people of color or, more generally, people who differ from the dominant population. Because of this, we have become accustomed to a type of storytelling which leaves many of our identities and experiences. Your support for this project allows us to offer the world a new story - one that brings you, and many more of us, to the table. This is big stuff.

 

Some achieve Greatness; 

 

Project Nongenue has no sustainable financial sponsorship. Because we are a grassroots company, we consistently rely on crowdfunding campaigns to produce our work, and in turn attempt to create work that reflects the issues and needs of our communities. Without your continued financial support, there would be no Project Nongenue.

That being said, we hope to crowdsource $2,500 to finance this production. Here's a breakdown of where any contributed money goes: 

  • Stipends for Actors and Creative Team: The amount you donate directly impacts how much we are able to pay our team. Project Nongenue is a little fish operation with big fish goals, and because of that, our ability to pay our team is entirely dependent on fundraising. Compensating our team members for their tireless work is one of our highest priorities with this campaign.
  • Theater Rental (Have you rented a theater space lately? Because dang! Our small but mighty savings account is struggling to carry that hit!)
  • Costumes and Set (We have some INCREDIBLE designers on this show, and they deserve to have the materials necessary to construct a beautiful world for you all)

 

And some have Greatness thrust upon 'em!

 

On the eve of our fifth production, Project Nongenue has a proven track record of high-quality,  innovative, and socially-conscious productions. Our previous shows have been lauded as "visionary," "challenging," "impeccably staged" and have played to consistently sold-out houses. We aim to create work which is artistically compelling, innovative and vital in our political moment. But something besides the high quality work we create is at stake in this fundraiser:

"Being a part of Project Nongenue - it feels like community, it feels like home. I don't know of any other communities where you can be honest with yourself in this way."

"Project Nongenue is open to everyone on the spectrum. It's not open to just one race. It's not just one sex that's getting roles."

"I'm not used to working with classical texts where I feel like I am seen- as an actor, as a whole: with my queerness, with my identity - and not leave it outside of the room for the sake of the performance."

"When you're a person who doesn't fit into standard ideals, coming to Project Nongenue is like a safe haven... it confirms that you are not the only person who feels what you feel."

These quotes from our company members illustrate what we are really raising money for - not only are we making art that features voices which are traditionally ignored, but we are forging a new way to make art. We seek tell stories in a way in which identity is not something you have to fracture or hide, but rather something to be centralized, explored and celebrated. We have created a haven for artists whom popular entertainment has ignored - and finances are the primary factor that threaten the existence of this essential community resource.

 

Thank You.

 

Even by reading this far, you have done so much. Please know that your donations not only ensure the success of What You Will, but the future existence of Project Nongenue at large. We wouldn't be here without you, and you can help us stay here. Even if you can't contribute, don't forget to share our cause on all your socials, and most importantly, don't forget we love you!

Yours in Love and Revolution,

Olivia Buntaine

Artistic Director of Project Nongenue

story:
QU4RTER is a brand new British musical about LGBTQ+, BAME twenty-somethings, navigating their way through the harsh realities of London life, as they pursue their dreams. A workshop is taking place at The Other Palace, which culminates in a rehearsed reading of the show on Tuesday 5th June.

Directed by Charlie Parham
Musical Direction by Matt Nalton
Book, music & lyrics by Arun Blair-Mangat

Casting Director  Jacob Sparrow
General Manager  Michelle Barnette

 

Arun Blair-Mangat is the writer and creator of QU4RTER. He is also an actor. His theatre credits include: In The Heights, Angels in America, Kinky Boots, Romeo in Romeo and Juliet, Titus Andronicus, Company and Hairspray. Television includes: Press (BBC) and The Royals (E!).

 

Charlie Parham is a director for theatre and film. For Antic Face, Co-Artistic Director Charlie has directed première productions of Collective Rage: A Play in 5 Betties (6 OFFIE nominations including BEST DIRECTOR), School Play (OFFIE nomination: Most Promising New Playwright), For Those Who Cry When They Hear The Foxes Scream (OFFIE nomination: Most Promising New Playwright) and Hippolytos (Ian Charleson Nomination: Emma Hall). As associate director: Much Ado About Nothing (Rose Theatre, Kingston). Film and TV credits: Nightstand (Peccadillo Pictures), Full English (Antic Face & Seek Films), Assistant to Creative Director Coky Giedroyc on The Sound Of Music Live (ITV)

He also performs and writes as one fifth of drag band DENIM, which has played acclaimed sets throughout the UK (Soho Theatre, Glastonbury Festival, Edinburgh Festival)

 

Matt Nalton is an accomplished pianist, a published composer for TV, & he runs his own photography business.​ He most recently was Musical Director for Myth at The Other Palace. Also an actor, he has starred in shows such as Jersey Boys and Beautiful in the West End, and recently shot on his first feature Judy the Judy Garland biopic.
 

Jacob Sparrow is part of the internal casting department at the National Theatre. Selected projects include Julie (Lyttelton, dir. Carrie Cracknell), Follies (Olivier, dir. Dominic Cooke), Amadeus (Olivier, dir. Michael Longhurst), Love (Dorfman, dir. Alexander Zeldin) and wonder.land (Olivier, dir. Rufus Norris). Upcoming projects include Pericles, Hadestown and the revival of Follies (all Olivier Theatre). 

Prior to this he worked with Pippa Ailion Casting and Telsey and Co in New York. He continues to work with James Orange Casting as a Creative Associate.
 

Michelle Barnette is a freelance creative producer and general manager. She is currently producing: the Alan Bates Award for The Actors Centre, Sparks (VAULT Festival, Edinburgh 2018). Previously:  Love Me Now (Tristan Bates Theatre), Che: The Musical (BEAM 2018), The Scar Test (Soho Theatre, general manager), Brutal Cessation (Assembly, Edinburgh), Dust (Underbelly, Edinburgh), and a new musical currently in development.

 

I need to fundraise £3500 so that I can pay nine professional actors and the creatives involved in the workshop for QU4RTER. Some of the funds will also go towards the printing of scripts and scores.

If I don’t get the full amount, the funding will still be used for these expenses.

There are some fun perks for those who donate to this campaign - as a way of saying a huge thank you for your contribution - including...

  • A sneak peek at some of the demos from the musical
  • Tickets to the one-off rehearsed reading at The Other Palace
  • Your very own, original song!
     

I felt that there was a lack of representation of young, queer British people in musical theatre so I wrote QU4RTER. The story is set over the course of a year, starting from early Summer 2016 and finishing in Spring 2017. It places the issues of identity and sexuality at its core and illuminates the struggles and difficulties that young people face in present day London.

Please support QU4RTER in any way that you can. Your involvement will be instrumental in developing this new British musical and helping us bring this story to the stage.

Every contribution counts, however big or small.

Feel free to spread the word and post this campaign on social media.

story:
The Basics

Hi there! We're Coffee & Whiskey Productions, the awesomest group of theatre nerds this side of the Antilles. Coffee & Whiskey was founded in 2014 by playwrights Nic Wehrwein and Matt Diel, with one purpose—reforming the old, less-than-helpful “moderated talkback” model of play readings, and creating something of real value for playwrights. The goal, ultimately, is to change the conversations that happen during new play development. Making them better... stronger... faster. We can rebuild them. We have the technology.

The Script Pub

The Script Pub is the heart of the C&W enterprise; it is the central load-bearing wall of our Sears catalog pre-fab theatrical house. We take a play, put it on its feet, and give it a semi-staged, script-in-hand performance. Afterwards, we ask one simple question of the audience: What did you think? From there, we have a good, unscripted conversation, designed to help the playwright move their work forward.

Over the last 3 seasons, we've been fortunate to present some pretty freakin' fantastic plays from some pretty freakin' fantastic playwrights (including O'Neill finalists, National Latino Playwrighting Award Winners, and fancypants Kilroy Listers), and we’ve learned a lot about our process along the way. We’ve gotten to spend time with giraffes, eat ice cream with alcoholic clowns, and be consumed by Pez; we’ve explored visions of the future, memories of the past, and seen intersex fish in the present day (hey, trout!). All told, it’s been one hell of a ride so far, and we’d like your help to keep it going.

Where You Come In

What we're in search of is a gigantic pile of money. Once obtained, we will take that pile of money and place it in an Olympic-sized swimming pool, and dive in a la Scrooge McDuck. Once we finish doing that, we will take the money out of the pool and exchange it for goods and services. Thus will the 2017 Coffee & Whiskey Script Pub be born!

Seriously though, each and every Script Pub requires money for stuff, like:

  • theatre space
  • rehearsal space
  • the time and talent of the actors and directors
  • a surprising amount of pizza

We have thus far been able to fund Coffee & Whiskey’s activities through audience donations, a few generous sponsors, and by scrounging loose change from the couch. But now it’s time to step up, and take it to the next level, and win one for the Gipper, or something. Every red cent that we earn from this wacky funding endeavor will go directly to funding Coffee & Whiskey. If we net ourselves five grand, or fifty bucks, or even a measly two bits, it will help us continue the work.

And lest you think this is merely an exercise in altruism, fret not, cause we've got amazing perks for you! Stickers and T-shirts and mugs and maybe even baked goods! You get some sweet swag, and we get to keep doing what we love to do. It's a win-win, really.

Why It’s Important

"Theatre is Conversation" is more than just a pithy motto—it’s our guiding principle. We believe in fostering the true, honest conversations that are so very vital to us as playwrights, as actors, as audience members, and as human beings. That only happens when everyone has an equal voice. At Coffee & Whiskey, we say come as you are, and screw all the people who say you can’t or shouldn’t. Raise your voice above theirs and join the conversation. Right now, there’s nothing more important.

(This is the place where they say we should toot our own horns, and talk about successes and the great things our playwrights have gone on to do. Well, we’re not gonna do that. We won’t talk about any fancy New York productions, or radio play projects, or Ashland New Play Festival selections, or anything like that, because it would be gauche, and we’ve got class, dammit.)

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that new play development withers on the vine. When that happens, theatre DIES. You don’t want to be the one that killed theatre, do you? That would be awful. We don’t want you to have that on your conscience forever. Don’t be a murderer.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute directly, you can still help us by getting the word out. Tell everyone you know about the Script Pub and how to support it. Share it on IndieGogo, share it on Facebook, tweet that mess! Everything helps.
  • Next time you come to see the Script Pub, bring two people along-- we'll thank you for it, and they might also!

story:
Who We Are

Aleixa Freire + Molly Kennedy are a collaborative, choreographic performance entity rooted in contemporary dance. Together we create and perform work that seeks to intertwine virtuosic, highly physical dance forms with narratives connected to questions of deeper socio-political implication. https://www.aleixamollydance.com

BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS is our new evening length work premiering February 1st & 2nd, 2020 at Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn, NY. BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS  researches the ideas of connectivity in societal structures. How would the world be a different place if we each really knew one another? The work seeks to express how the physical language of our moving bodies can facilitate the creation of empathy and visibility. We are also studying rage and how we negotiate the expression or suppression of complex emotions. The exploration of how societal structures impose the image of perfection and how its intangibility creates an apathetic regard towards self and therefore towards others. Can candid emotional expression and sensitivity bring us closer towards inner and communal peace?

Dancers: Caylee Shimizu, Indigo Sparks, Alex Schmidt, Haley Sung, Shelby Nelson, Lindsay Wenning.

 

Our Campaign

BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS is a full length work performed by six dancers. As we are a new collective, any financial contribution to this project would help secure the rightful payment of each artist and collaborator (videographer, photographer, technician, event manager, etc) involved in the production of this work. Even if our fundraising goal is not fully achieved, any contribution would be beneficial to the support of this project and each of the many talented individuals involved. Each donor will be listed and credited on all programming information for the work as we are extensively grateful for any support we receive. 

 

The Impact

We are grateful to be a part of such a vast artistic community and feel that successful curation of BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS would help provide the continuation and expansion of this project following its premier. We see this work as only the beginning for our collective and see all contributions towards BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS as a stepping stone to a more secure future for our work.

 

Other Support Options

We understand if you are unable to contribute any direct financial support to this campaign. However, if you cannot donate we would love for you to consider other ways in which you can support this project! 

  • Share this fundraiser! If you yourself cannot contribute, please feel free to circulate it on social platforms or through word of mouth.
  • Follow us on Instagram! Keep up with the work and our process, events, and performances via our instagram @aleixamollydance
  • COME TO OUR SHOW! February 1st & 2nd at Center for Performance Research; tickets will be on sale come 2020 and we would love to see you.
story_txt:
Who We Are
Aleixa Freire + Molly Kennedy are a collaborative, choreographic performance entity rooted in contemporary dance. Together we create and perform work that seeks to intertwine virtuosic, highly physical dance forms with narratives connected to questions of deeper socio-political implication. https://www.aleixamollydance.com
BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS is our new evening length work premiering February 1st & 2nd, 2020 at Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn, NY. BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS  researches the ideas of connectivity in societal structures. How would the world be a different place if we each really knew one another? The work seeks to express how the physical language of our moving bodies can facilitate the creation of empathy and visibility. We are also studying rage and how we negotiate the expression or suppression of complex emotions. The exploration of how societal structures impose the image of perfection and how its intangibility creates an apathetic regard towards self and therefore towards others. Can candid emotional expression and sensitivity bring us closer towards inner and communal peace?
Dancers: Caylee Shimizu, Indigo Sparks, Alex Schmidt, Haley Sung, Shelby Nelson, Lindsay Wenning.
 
Our Campaign
BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS is a full length work performed by six dancers. As we are a new collective, any financial contribution to this project would help secure the rightful payment of each artist and collaborator (videographer, photographer, technician, event manager, etc) involved in the production of this work. Even if our fundraising goal is not fully achieved, any contribution would be beneficial to the support of this project and each of the many talented individuals involved. Each donor will be listed and credited on all programming information for the work as we are extensively grateful for any support we receive. 
 
The Impact
We are grateful to be a part of such a vast artistic community and feel that successful curation of BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS would help provide the continuation and expansion of this project following its premier. We see this work as only the beginning for our collective and see all contributions towards BEAUTIFUL FEELINGS as a stepping stone to a more secure future for our work.
 
Other Support Options
We understand if you are unable to contribute any direct financial support to this campaign. However, if you cannot donate we would love for you to consider other ways in which you can support this project! 


Share this fundraiser! If you yourself cannot contribute, please feel free to circulate it on social platforms or through word of mouth.

Follow us on Instagram! Keep up with the work and our process, events, and performances via our instagram @aleixamollydance

COME TO OUR SHOW! February 1st & 2nd at Center for Performance Research; tickets will be on sale come 2020 and we would love to see you.

story:
Our Story

Devon Frieder Productions has been putting on professional quality shows in New Mexico for over a decade, and we are so excited to be producing "Head Over Heels" this Winter. Ticket sales alone do not cover show expenses; from costumes, to microphones, to our performance space, a lot of funds are needed to put on a show each year. So this holiday season, consider giving to Devon Frieder Productions, and take pride in supporting the flourishing Albuqueruqe arts scene. As always, we are eternally grateful for your support.

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise at least $2000 toward production expenses. To show our gratitude, we are excited to offer some great perks at rising donation levels!

Supporter: For a $50 donation, you will receive a "Thank You" in our program!

Patron: For a $100 donation, you will receive a "Thank You" in our program, and two tickets to a performance of "Head Over Heels"!

Producer: For a $250 donation, you will receive a "Thank You" in our program, two VIP tickets to a performance of "Head Over Heels", and a signed poster from the cast!

Executive Producer: For a $500 donation, you will receive a "Thank You" in our program, four VIP tickets to a performance of "Head Over Heels", a signed poster from the cast, and a special mention in our curtain speech for you or your business/organization!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially, so please, share this fundraiser with your friends and family. Maybe even ask for a donation in your name for a gift this holiday season! More than anything, we hope to see you at our production of "Head Over Heels".

story:
Who Are You Again?

Stephen Bracco, the playwright and producer. I've been producing my plays in NYC at places like The Brick, the Secret Theatre, the Players Theatre, Manhattan Repertory, Between Us Productions, and most recently, at Hudson Guild for my first full-length production, Abominable Fancy. Simius will be the eleventh production of my work I've produced.

Theater, though paying little, costs a lot, but in every one of those productions, despite having shoestring budgets, I've tried to compensate my creative team fairly for all their fantastic work, and I want to do the same with Simius.
 

A Big Ape in the City

 

 

 

 

 

Simius: A feisty monkey puppet upends a wealthy family when he declares his love for the family matriarch. Add a Catholic nun psychologist questioning her vows and you have what the Broadway Bound Festival calls "a brash, appalling, hilarious, absurd, macabre comedy."

 

 

 

But...No Empire State Building?

No skyscrapers in the budget for this ape to climb! This Freudian family drama has three performances on Theatre Row, at the Lion Theatre, which can’t accommodate storage of big set pieces.

Minimal set means hiring skilled designers working with light, sound, costume--and space itself--to evoke the world of this unique psychological drama.

 

What's the damage, buddy?

Goal: $3,000. If you'd like to support us, then pick a contribution category that you like--or more than one--and know that your help is going to that specific part of our production.

Our creative team will be reaching out to their own circle of friends, so among all of us, our goal of getting help with the budget through this campaign is truly possible!

 


 


Current Budget: $10,000
Rehearsal space (80+ hours): $2,000
Publicity, including printing/mailings: $1,000
Props: $300
Set: $500
AEA insurance: $250
Costumes: $550
Director: $750
Stage Manager: $450
Actors (5): $500 each = $2,500
Designers (light, sound, costume, set): $1,400
Fight director: $300

All supporters get fun updates throughout the summer, like profiles of the cast and crew you're helping out, with interviews, photos, juicy gossip, and lots of monkey puppet love. You can choose from our "perks" of gratitude here or hit the big BACK IT button to set your own big amount!
 

Our Performance Dates

Tuesday July 30, 8pm
Sunday August 4, 5pm
Saturday August 10, 5pm
 

How else can I help?

You've got a handful going on and you can't support us--that's okay! Spreading word of this campaign to your fellow theater-lovers is a big help!

 


More about Stephen HERE

story:
Premiering at the Dream Up Festival at Theater for the New City in August 2013, The Loneliest Whale in the World is an exploration of hideous weirdnesses--human and non--and a collaboration between playwright Zoë Geltman and director Julia May Jonas.

Lucy, a mutant, friendless whale, washes up on a garbage-strewn beach in Babylon, Long Island intent on killing herself. As she waits to die, perfuming her surroundings with the stink of desperation, strange, magnetic forces that have been ripped with her from the sea work their way into the lives of two people in the process of clawing away at themselves. The two wretches escalate their internal fights with themselves: they peak, they panic, and then...? Perhaps Lucy is not so alone after all. The Loneliest Whale in the World is a play about gnawing at oneself and whether it is better to be swallowed up by that shameful, morbid pleasure, or whether we must finally give in to all the talking heads that tell us to stop. 

Why The Whale Needs Your Help

We are thrilled that The Loneliest Whale in the World got accepted into the Dream Up Festival at Theater for the New City, Artistic Director Crystal Field, for August-September 2013! Especially because this will be Zoë Geltman's first play ever produced! 

But, now we need to produce it. Your support will go towards rehearsal space--which adds up to an arm and a leg!--props, costumes, set pieces, and most importantly, paying the excellent actors and designers who will be donating their time to make this play really happen. 

Details

THE LONELIEST WHALE IN THE WORLD

August 28, August 31, September 3, September 5, and September 7

Written by Zoë Geltman

Directed by Julia May Jonas

Sound Design: Chuck Stern

Lighting Design: Amanda Clegg Lyon

With Neil D'Astolfo*, David Gould, Lucy McMichael*, Maggie Robinson, Elizabeth Spano, and Samuel West.

*Appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

Buy tickets here! 

About the Whale

An excerpt from The Loneliest Whale in the World was performed by Zoë Geltman, Preston Martin, Chuck Stern, and Marisa Wallin at The Invisible Dog Art Space in February 2013 as part of Catch!, the monthly performance series curated by Andrew Dinwiddie, Caleb Hammons, and Jeff Larson. Two monologues from the play were performed at Pussyfest, a fundraiser curated by Mariah MacCarthy. 

The loneliest whale in the world is a real whale! It was found by the Navy in 1989 (some say 1992) and it sings at a different frequency than all other whales. Because of its curious song, it has not been able to find any other whales, and they have not been able to locate it. Scientists do not know whether it is a hybrid of two different kinds of whale, a genetically mutated whale, or the last of an extinct species. 

Julia May Jonas and Zoë Geltman met when Zoë auditioned to play a 70-year-old Grandma named Rose in a play Julia wrote at Columbia University's MFA Playwriting Program. She got the part.

story:
Who We Are

Hi, we're the Wise Fish Theater Collective! Thank you for visiting our campaign page. As an intro, here are the fundamental tenants of our collective, or, what makes us Wise Fish and not fishbrains: 

Collaborative Theater (equality!): At Wise Fish, EVERY member gets a voice. That means that each show contains a variety of perspectives within it, allowing our productions to grow and change as we do and ensuring that no one way of looking at the world ever dominates our work.
Diversity (reality!): We strive to maintain a diverse collective. However, there is always room for improvement, and we are always on the lookout for new members who can offer new perspectives.  Keep an eye out for our member profiles, coming soon, where each member shares a little about where they grew up, be it Brooklyn, Argentina, Slovenia, Nebraska...
Absurdism (getting weird!): We love absurdist theater! No, we don't only produce theater by absurdist playwrights. But yes, it always gets a little weird.  Absurdism is where (wo)man's search for meaning and the fundamental chaos of the universe meet.  We think it makes a lot of sense to use an absurdist framework when creating art about today's world.
We are: Anthony Abdo, Dinah Berkeley, Martina Bonolis, Meghan Ginley, Danny Gomez, Alen Kolenovic, Victoria Myrthil, Franco Pedicini, Conrad Shaw, Colleen Slattery, Bianca Soto, Natasa Warasch.
We are currently trying to raise money for our first production:
Six Characters in Search of an Author by Luigi Pirandello, newly adapted by the Wise Fish Theater Collective

Robert Moss Theater
440 Lafayette Street, 3rd Floor
(between Astor Place and E. 4th Street) 
Fri 5/6, Sat 5/7, Mon 5/9 at 8pm
Thurs 5/12, Fri 5/13, Sat 5/14 at 8pm 
Sun 5/8 and Sun 5/15 at 3pm 


Before we could explore all the issues we're interested in, we needed to explore the medium of theater itself. We needed a piece to serve as our foundation. In Six Characters in Search of an Author, six characters enter a theater...and they won't leave. They demand that their story be told, and, more than that, told correctly. When they ask a group of career-savvy actors to portray their drama, the heart and soul of theater confronts its logistics, bottom lines, and egos. We are asked to reconsider the timeless question: Does art imitate life, or does life imitate art? Or, more importantly, is this whole art thing a sham to begin with?

Six Characters in Search of an Author is an absurdist exploration of theater and, more broadly, of art. Of what it can and cannot do, of what it means, of where it fails. As we explore theater's limitations, we explore our own, and we make fun of ourselves a lot. Really, a lot.  

                              "This is the cause of all this trouble. It's the words!"

What We Need 

Holy mackerel, theater is expensive! (Or, as company member and adorable schoolteacher Meghan Ginley would say, "Geez oh man!")  We need your help to ensure that we can pay all the fees associated with this production, and hopefully to put a little away for productions to come.  Help us to promote a theater that is not only an activity for the already moneyed, but something in which we all can participate. Theater for all! As we are a nonprofit, all of your donations are tax deductible. 


Here's a breakdown:
Rehearsal spaces: $1224
Renting the theater: $6600
Paying the Production Team (lighting designer, set consultant, costume designer, sound designer, stage manager): $2800
Advertising: $565.39
Set: $200
Lights: $300
Insurance: $450
Actors/Director: fueled entirely by coffee and Swedish Fish

The Impact
With your help, we hope to make this production a success and plan for our future productions. Our goal is to eventually have the funds to pay our actors and directors fair wages and to hire more people with something to say. As our collective grows, we want to give voice to new playwrights, directors, actors, and designers. We are especially interested in promoting the works of people who are underrepresented in theater today. Help us to ensure that New York theater artists have a collaborative, supportive environment in which they can make their art and share it with  you! Help us to grow our community and keep creative people working. Thank you, thank you, thank you! We are incredibly grateful.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate financially, you're not off the fish hook! You can still help us out by sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or email and spreading the word. We love you no matter how you can help. You're all starfish to us!

"Six Characters in Search of an Author Wise Fish Co" is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of "Six Characters in Search of an Author Wise Fish Co" must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Play

Proof is a beautiful Pulitzer Prize winning play by David Auburn about the effects of mental illness on a family.
It will be performed at The Tabard Theatre (Chiswick, London) for 4 weeks starting 29 September 2015. 

SYNOPSIS

Catherine has sacrificed her education and social life to care for her father Robert, a once brilliant mathematician. 

Following his death Catherine is now plagued with fears for her own mental health whilst dealing with the trauma of his passing and the attentions of his former student, Hal.

Hal desperately searches through the professor's notebooks hoping to discover something useable among his incoherent scribblings.

With the arrival of her estranged sister Claire, past pains and prejudices surface and the appearance of a brilliant proof, which Catherine claims to have written, ignites the doubts and tests the loyalties and love of all three.

Collaboration

We are delighted to announce that we will be collaborating with the charity Sane.
 

SANE is a leading UK mental health charity improving quality of life for anyone affected by mental illness - including family friends and carers.

Through us you will be helping to raise awareness about Mental illness and supporting the wonderful charity SANE with whom we are partnered for this production. Proof deals with a very personal exploration of mental illness and its impact upon the family – it is our honour to be able to promote SANE in our efforts to connect theatre in a direct and practical way with raising awareness. 

Cast & Creatives

TIM HARDY - ROBERT


Trained at RADA.

Work for the Royal Shakespeare Company includes: Henry V directed by Peter Hall and Marat\Sade directed by Peter Brook which played on Broadway before being turned into a feature film.Other theatre credits include: Hotspur in Henry IV and Dauphin in Henry V, for Prospect Theatre Co., (The Roundhouse Theatre), Rupert in Melon by Simon Gray,  (Haymarket Theatre), The Spartan Leader in Lysistrata, directed by Sir Peter Hall (The Old Vic Theatre/Wyndhams Theatre), Alan in Mary Barnes, by David Edgar (Royal Court Theatre), Perchik in Fiddler on the Roof, (Her Majesty”s Theatre) Mr.Kruger in Mephisto, (The Roundhouse), Peer Gynt in Peer Gynt, (Battersea Arts Centre), Petruchio in Taming of the Shrew (The Open Space) and Vladimir in Waiting for Godot. (The Tricycle Theatre)

Nathan in Guys and Dolls, Dunoi in St. Joan, Bassanio in The Merchant of Venice, Rosencrantz in Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead, and Colonel Cathcart in Catch 22, adapted by Joseph Heller, (all at Leeds Playhouse) Lord Darlington in Lady Windermere’s Fan, (Theatre Royal, Windsor). Title role in Macbeth and Reverend Hale in The Crucible, (Oxford Playhouse).

Cleante in Tartuffe, and Jo Mankewitz in Judy for Bristol Old Vic, which transferred to The Strand Theatre, and Bertram in Largo Desolato by Tom Stoppard which transferred to the International Arts Festival, Hong Kong. For Icarus Theatre Company, performs the one-man show, The Trials of Galileo, and next January will open“The Mountains of Madness” by H.P. Lovecraft.

In Europe Tim has played the title roles in Life After George and A Picasso, Michael in Someone Who’ll Watch Over Me for the Vienna English Speaking Theatre In the US he played Leontes/Old Shepherd in The Winter’s Tale, Mercutio/Lord Capulet in Romeo and Juliet, and Shylock in The Merchant of Venice.

In Opera for Music Theatre London, Tim has sung Sarastro in The Magic Flute, Commendatore in Don Giovanni, Bartolo in The Marriage of Figaro, The Baron in La Traviata, and Don Magnifico in Cenerentola. He also performs a song-cycle based on The Rhyme of the Ancient Mariner.

Going back to RADA on 1994 as a free-lance faculty member, he has directed on the annual Summer Shakespeare Course, the twice-yearly Shakespeare course in association with NYU, and on the annual Tree Evening for the leaving graduates. Tim is also a Member of the Admissions Panel. He created a 3-month course for Syracuse University in London, and has directed for Drama Studio London and Guildford School of Acting.

Television credits include the title role in Galileo, and Arthur Taylor in Oscar Wilde for the BBC, Jesus in Son of Man, John Rampayne in The Trial of Sir John Rampayne , The Doctor in The Wife of Bath, David Manners in Eastenders, leading roles in Midsomer Murders, Casualty 1909, and Macbeth.

Films credits include Captain Corelli’s Mandolin, The Duelist, Nothing but the Best, and Marat\Sade.

Other directing credits include  The Dumb Waiter by Harold Pinter, for the Covent Garden Festival, Dangerous Liaisons, and Rebecca for Vienna’s English Theatre, and Gaslight by Patrick Hamilton for English Theatre Frankfurt. In America: As You Like It at Notre Dame University, The Merchant of Venice and Romeo and Juliet at Butler University, and in Michigan, The Royal Hunt of the Sun.

http://www.spotlight.com/0090-1279-6112

JULIA PAPP  - CATHERINE

Julia was trained at the Hungarian Academy of Dramatic Arts and studied Meisner technique at The Actors’ Temple and at The Salon:Collective.

Julia’s theatre credits include: Nina in The Seagull, Sonya in Uncle Vanya, Natasha in Three Sisters, Viola in Twelfth Night, Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, Rosalind in As You Like It, Abigail in The Crucible, Veronica in The Fall of Man, Diana in The Dog in the Manger.

Recent feature film credits include: Maggie in Tariro, Anna in Archie, Rita in Seven Devils, Claire in Forever Tomorrow.

http://www.spotlight.com/9332-0195-9740

KIM HARDY - HAL

Kim Hardy was trained at the Central School of Speech and Dramaand studied Meisner technique at The Actors’ Temple and at The Salon:Collective.

Recent theatre credits include: Konstantin in The Seagull (IAN CHARLESTON AWARD nomination), Feste/Sebastian in Twelfth Night (Hoxton Hall), Hotspur in Henry IV (Rose Theatre Southbank), Lee in On the Ropes (Theatre Delicatessen), Kai in Boom (Bush Theatre), Boyson in Four Corners One Heart (Theatre 503), Andrei in Three Sisters, Romeo in Romeo and Juliet, Lysander in Midsummer Nights Dream, Louis the Dauphin in King John (Cockpit Theatre).

Recent film credits include: Jacob in Forever Tomorrow, Lucas in Lamb’s Damnation, Henry in Enginex4, Luke in Hidden Angel, John in Prick.

http://www.spotlight.com/9130-6720-1430

MARY-ANN CAFFERKEY - CLAIRE

 Mary-Ann was trained at The Bridge Theatre Training Company and studied Meisner technique at The Actors’ Temple and at The Salon:Collective.

Mary-Ann's theatre credits include: Kate in The Taming of the Shrew, Isobel in Measure For Measure, Hermia in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, Viola in Twelfth Night, Adela in The House of Bernarda Alba, Vanessa in The Chair, Jess in Love and Money, Prudence in Beyond Therapy, Nina in The Seagull, Connie in A Chorus Line, Maria in West Side Story.

Recent film credits include: The Red Line, Normalisation and Bigga Than Ben and recent Web and TV pilots Expenses Only and The Jason Philips Show.

Mary-Ann's recent voice over work includes Dr Who:Antidote to Oblivion alongside Colin Baker.
Mary-Ann also sings lead and harmony vocals with a successful covers band called The Rumours.

http://www.spotlight.com/0214-9082-5171

SEBASTIEN BLANC - DIRECTOR

Sebastien started as an actor. He studied Meisner Technique at The Actors’ Pulse in Sydney, Australia.

His directing credits include The Glasshouse at the Tristan Bates Theatre, Mojo at the White Bear, The Winterling by Jez Butterworth at White Bear Theatre, The Shallow End by Doug Lucie at the Southwark Playhouse, Sexual Perversity in Chicago by David Mamet at the Giles Foreman Lab, Interior: Panic by Tennessee Williams at the Pentameters Theatre and Boys’ Life by Howard Korder at The Kings Head.

Proof is his second collaboration with Front Foot Theatre. Their first production The Seagull was wonderfully received. Sebastien's previous plays have received 5 Off West End Award nominations and one award for Best Supporting Actor.

For more information abut Sebastian and his work visit:

  • www.blancmeisner.com

MICHAEL LEOPOLD - SET DESIGNER

Michael graduated with a BA(hons) Degree in Theatre Design from Wimbledon College of Art in 2014. An avid performer and actor, Michael strives to collaborate to create sets that strike at the heart of the sentiments of the material while accomodating and feeding directiorial creativity.

As an active and experienced associate designer Michael is a very capable model maker and draftsman, ensuring a paritive vision between all disciplines involved in the delivery of the live performance while ensuring the aesthetic quality of the production is ensured from an early stage in the development of the piece.

Credits include: Journey's End (The Charles Cryer Theatre),Halka (POSK Hammersmith), Alfie the Musical (London College of Music), Just So (Waterman's Theatre), City of Angels (Saint Paul's Private School, Hammersmith), Parade (Epsom Playhouse), RENT (Charles Cryer Theatre, Carshalton) Love Me Tender (UK Tour), Privates on Parade (Noel Coward Theatre), Twelfth Night' and  Comedy of Errors  (International and UK Tour), Peter & Alice (Noel Coward Theatre), Fallen (The Corbett Theatre)
For his portfolio please visit: http://www.mikejleopold.com
BEN MORRISON - LIGHTING DESIGNER

Ben has been designing lighting for plays and musicals for over ten years. He has worked at many local and larger regional theatres.

Recent credits include: Phantom (Charles Cryer Studio Theatre), Hairspray (Ashcroft Theatre), Witches of Eastwick (Secombe Theatre), Journey's End (Charles Cryer Studio Theatre) and Little Women (Edinburgh Fringe).

Ben is very excited to be working with Front Foot Theatre Company for the first time.

CHRIS ROE - COMPOSER

With a diverse musical background, playing classical piano/violin from an early age, studying contemporary composition at the Royal College of Music, electronic music in Paris and playing keyboards in the 70’s cover band Superfly Soul Collective, Chris is an individual and versatile composer, able to write and record his own music in a wide array of styles. 
Recent projects include the critically acclaimed feature documentary 'Death of a Gentleman', a nomination for the Peer Raben Award for Best Soundtrack on the animated thriller 'The Palace', and a screening at the BFI. Chris was also recently signed to SMARaw Talent Agency.
Alongside composition, Chris is the founder and musical director of ANIMA, a project combining live contemporary music with animated films. 

Chris is also passionate about getting young people involved in composition, and regularly runs projects with schools, involving workshops on throughout the compositional process, and usually culminating in a performance of the new student works by professional musicians.

http://chrisroemusic.com/index.html
PRODUCTION MANAGER - JOANNA BUCHTA

Joanna spend teenage years playing in amateur theatre productions dreaming of founding a professional Theatre company in the future. However, since moving to London in 2002, she has abandoned her amateur career and decided to focussed on Arts in general. 

Since completing her Arts Management degree in London, Joanna has worked mainly with independent theatre companies, on site- specific productions, with Kazuko Hohki, Kazzum, Panta ReiTheatre with Chiara D' Anna.

Joanna has also a wide experience working in many projects in field of Arts, these includes: independent music label, film production, arts conservation and interior design. 

In addition, occasionally Joanna is working as a double and worked in films Les Misérables ( 2012 ) and Suffragette (2015) 

What We Need 
Proof is a wonderful play that we are all very passionate about and can't wait to share it with an audience. We would like to use the money we raise here for advertising the show. This is important for two reasons:
  • The more people know about this play the more people we can reach with its important messages and raise awareness about mental illness. We are hoping to transfer the play to a bigger venue next year but this can only happen if we can show the management of the potential new venue that many people are interested. The best way to ensure this is to have a sell-out run.
  • All the cast and crew have kindly agreed to work on a profit-share basis, meaning that nobody will get a fixed fee. We will split the profit from the box office at the end. The more people who know about this show, the more tickets we can sell to make sure that our talented team will be compensated for their hard work.

Why Support Us?

1/ Art is one of the last pure conduits through which we as a people can reflect upon the human condition; it is a vital tool through which expression is given genuine freedom. We aim to produce plays which reach for people; that move them and hopefully leave them looking more closely at themselves and the world around them. In short, we hope to breed empathy and without this, without the ability to see and emotionally understand other people; other situations – what do we risk becoming?

In this country we have a growing tendency to ignore and victimise the weak, as demonstrated through Austerity. Amongst others, the disabled have suffered horribly but if the majority of people actually understood what it is to live with a disability – this abuse wouldn’t happen.

2/ Through us you will be helping to raise awareness about Mental illness and supporting the wonderful charity SANE with whom we are partnered for this production. Proof deals with a very personal exploration of mental illness and its impact upon the family – it is our honour to be able to promote SANE in our efforts to connect theatre in a direct and practical way with raising awareness.

3/ It’s a beautiful play and worthy of being brought to life with as much realism and truth as possible. With some more funding we can create a world on stage into which the audience can disappear and be further taken by the story.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this project. Share on Facebook, Twitter...

story_txt:
The Play
Proof is a beautiful Pulitzer Prize winning play by David Auburn about the effects of mental illness on a family.
It will be performed at The Tabard Theatre (Chiswick, London) for 4 weeks starting 29 September 2015. 

SYNOPSIS
Catherine has sacrificed her education and social life to care for her father Robert, a once brilliant mathematician. 
Following his death Catherine is now plagued with fears for her own mental health whilst dealing with the trauma of his passing and the attentions of his former student, Hal.
Hal desperately searches through the professor's notebooks hoping to discover something useable among his incoherent scribblings.
With the arrival of her estranged sister Claire, past pains and prejudices surface and the appearance of a brilliant proof, which Catherine claims to have written, ignites the doubts and tests the loyalties and love of all three.
Collaboration

We are delighted to announce that we will be collaborating with the charity Sane.

 
SANE is a leading UK mental health charity improving quality of life for anyone affected by mental illness - including family friends and carers.

Through us you will be helping to raise
awareness about Mental illness and supporting the wonderful charity SANE with
whom we are partnered for this production. Proof deals with a very personal
exploration of mental illness and its impact upon the family – it is our honour
to be able to promote SANE in our efforts to connect theatre in a direct and
practical way with raising awareness.

story:
What's The Tarot Reading?

We created The Tarot Reading to be a home for artists and entertainers of all stripes where audiences could always leave with something unforgettable. We wanted our artists and our audiences to feel like they had something at stake in their creation - that we could have fun, but also make a difference. Since it's inception, over 20 unique artists have created over 60 singular acts and formed over 300 personal memories in three awesome performances. Funding The Tarot Reading continues that goal, and creates space where that magic can happen.

What's It Going Toward?

The full amount of this campaign goes to supporting our artists with fees, commissions and cost of materials. If we don't complete our goal, the artists will (always) get paid first.

What's The Impact?

The Tarot Reading is always offered to audiences for a sacrifice of anything. It can be monetary, but doesn't have to be. We pay our artists for their valuable time and expertise, and do so with over 60%(!) of our earned income from generous sacrifices. 

We ask you now to make us another, pre-sacrifice so our Revelations can always find exactly who they need to without cost being a barrier. Give to The Tarot Reading so we can continue to commission the area's best artists to create sensational, interpersonal shows-for-one-and-many.

Can't Give To The Tarot?

There is one simple thing you can do to help out. All you have to do is tell one person - just one! - about your experience with us. Tell them what happened, tell them what excited you, tell them what you were left feeling and thinking and holding afterward. Then, point them here.

story:
About the Show

Xmas Carol is a modern day satire that updates the well known story to today's political landscape in the hopes of making people laugh while they realise that caring for others is as needed now as it was in Victorian times.

It will be playing for two nights, December 13 and 14, 2015,  at London's Old Red Lion theatre. 

What We're Asking 

All cast and (non-producing) creative are guaranteed a fixed fee for the weeks of work they will be contributing. It's a token, but important to recognize there is value in the work they do. 

In the interest of decreasing poverty in the arts community, we would like to invite those who can to contribute more.

In the hopes of providing something closer to a living wage for the performers and creative working on The Xmas Carol, the producers of this show are asking for donations to supplement the wages of the cast and production team: 

  • a cast of 7 8
  • director
  • scenic/costume design coordinator
  • lighting designer
  • sound designer
  • stage manager

The £1200 goal enables us to add just £100 each to the small fee we've guaranteed for the considerable time and effort they will each be giving the project.


UPDATE: We've had to expand to a cast of 8 - which means we need to exceed our target to get each person just £100 for 2 weeks of work!
story_txt:
About the Show 
Xmas Carol is a modern day satire that updates the well known story to today's political landscape in the hopes of making people laugh while they realise that caring for others is as needed now as it was in Victorian times.
It will be playing for two nights, December 13 and 14, 2015,  at London's Old Red Lion theatre. 

What We're Asking 

All cast and (non-producing) creative are guaranteed a fixed fee for the weeks of work they will be contributing. It's a token, but important to recognize there is value in the work they do. 
In the interest of decreasing poverty in the arts community, we would like to invite those who can to contribute more.
In the hopes of providing something closer to a living wage for the performers and creative working on The Xmas Carol, the producers of this show are asking for donations to supplement the wages of the cast and production team: 

a cast of 7 8
director
scenic/costume design coordinator
lighting designer
sound designer
stage manager

The £1200 goal enables us to add just £100 each to the small fee we've guaranteed for the considerable time and effort they will each be giving the project. 

UPDATE: We've had to expand to a cast of 8 - which means we need to exceed our target to get each person just £100 for 2 weeks of work!

story:
Short Summary

"What's In Front of You," seven short plays, written and directed by Joseph Walsh, is a cast of characters and situations that range from the comic and absurd to the tender and human.  What's In Front of You debuted in December at the Broadwater Theater, with two enthusiastically received sell out performances.  With this campaign we are working to fund a longer run of 6 nights at the end of September for those who weren't able to catch it the first time and those hungry to see it again!

What's In Front of You is Joseph's first work for theater.  His other credits include writing and directing the feature film, "Girl Missing," with Patrick McCartney, Adam McKay, Kate Walsh and Amy Poehler and co-Writing and co-directing the award-winning short film, "Model Trapper."  He is currently developing a new feature film set in Ireland in conjunction with the Irish Film Board; as well as working on a new full-length play.  Mr. Walsh is also and actor and artist. 

Performance dates:  Sept. 20, 21 8:00 pm, Sept. 22 7:00 pm, Sept. 27, 28 8:00 pm, Sept. 29 7:00pm.  Tickets at https://joseph-walsh-play.square.site/

 

What We Need & What You Get

Like most independent productions, What's in Front of You is self-financed and produced.  To fund all planned performances, our goal is to raise $4,000.00 for remaining costs.

The funds raised will go toward theater rental costs, rehearsal space, fees for technical support and Stage Manager(s), expenses incurred by our Production Team and the care and feeding of our performers throughout the run.

For this we need YOU!  People who care about theater, new theater, funny theater, weird theater, experimental theater, independent theater; who care about laughter, tears, awe, language, character, surprise, refinement, offense!  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help monetarily, no problem; we only ask that you share this on your social media: share, tweet, like, forward, instagram, hashtag--whatever!  All those things help too!  Lots!

story:
Background

I enjoy creating dance works for both film and the stage, whether dramatically charged emotional stories, cheeky humorous pieces, or more meditative, abstract works. I love crafting complex ensemble patterns and setting intricate partnering that doesn’t need to conform to gender norms.

This will be an important aspect of my new work “Come Out Swinging”, a fun, high-energy piece inspired by a brief scene in the Wonder Woman movie where Diana claims the slow-dancing townspeople are merely swaying not dancing. So now I will combine two of my favorite loves (dance and comics) to answer the question: How do the Amazons of Themyscaria dance?

Having recently self-produced my company's first sold out show at The Tank in Times Square, I wanted my next work to have a light and fun aspect to it. I have already booked the first performance which will take place in the beautiful hedge mazes at the historic Liberty Hall for a free dance festival in New Jersey. As a stretch goal, I have plans to bring my dancers to Comic Con in NY in October for a surprise flash mob!

 

Where the money goes:

I am asking for $1,000 which will pay for transportation to and from New Jersey for all the dancers, a stipend for performance, as well as food since it is an all day event. I will also be using the money to make costumes and will be purchasing a lot of raw materials to craft some individual armor for each dancer. I have also incorporated the Indiegogo fees in this number.

And since I want this to be step 1 for this work, I have a few stretch goals:

  • $1,250 Drone Footage! With just a little extra I will be able to provide drone footage of the work which should offer a great view of the dancer's interaction with the hedge mazes.
  • $1,500 Photoshoot! Push forward a little more with the funding and I'll be able to host a fantastic photoshoot on Governor's Island. 
  • $2,000 Flash Mob outside Comic-Con! Since the initial version of the work will be site specific, I'll need to host some extra rehearsals, as well as pay dancers for another performance.
  • $2,250 Amazon headgear! I am not currently adding any armored headgear to the dancers wardrobes. But if I reach this goal, I'll be able to add some cut throat tiaras. Who doesn't love a tiara that doubles as a weapon?
  • $3,000 Video! If we reach this level, I will make a professional level video that takes elements of the dance, but will showcase it in a format that is best suited for video vs. a live performance. 

I have been self-funding my work for the last 2 years, so no matter what is raised, the dancers will be paid. This funding campaign helps me to stay one step ahead of the costs, focus more on the creative aspect (vs taking extra shifts at various jobs), and make the costumes a more detailed and more personal for each dancer.

Other Ways You Can Help

While this is a monetary campaign, I am all for getting the word out about dance! I would love a share be it a general post to facebook or a heartfelt email to a friend who you think would enjoy letting a bunch of warrior women loose upon the world!

story:
This summer I will join Erik Ehn in a trip where artists, cultural workers, faculty and students travel to Rwanda. In Rwanda, we partner with Rwanda’s Interdisciplinary Genocide Studies Center (IGSC) to visit memorial sites and speak with survivors, government officials, scholars and cultural workers about the 1994 Tutsi genocide and the work of recovery. It culminates in an international performance festival, Centre x Centre, in Rwanda’s capital.  

Airfare is $2072 and daily cost of living is $125 per day, amounting to $3572.  I'm calling on help from friends to raise money for what will be a life-changing artistic venture.

From $1 to $100, everything is a big help.  

Also... if anyone has a better insider deal on airfare or knows the best place for immunization shots, send me a message at johnmoletress@gmail.com

More information:  My Website

story:
The Regime is Female

A tight 90-minute play, The Regime is Female plays with the question: how much of your humanity are you willing to lose if it means saving the world? 

The year is 2028.

Two years since the American dictatorship was overthrown.

Two years since over half of American males died due to the “XY” virus.

Two years of peace under the New Country principles.

Living isolated in an undisclosed location, River Flynn is a revolutionary legend. She is a Specialist: the executioner for any person caught performing a white supremacist or patriarchal act. She fills her free time indoctrinating her ex-Congressman father, training her protégé, and zoning out to old anti-establishment music.

But when a cis man is introduced as her new assistant, River starts to question her role, her country, and her humanity.

Why we're doing it:

"If they can see it, they can be it"

At Badass Lady Productions, we strive to create stories that feature diverse voices, often in the feminist and LGBTQ+ community. 

Deadly weapons. Sexualized (L) vs Humanized (R)

We're changing the narrative and obliterating stereotypes.

Powerful female leads in sci-fi are often highly sexualized. Our protagonist River Flynn is not here to look pretty as she strangles the life out of someone. She's a messy human killing machine: a complicated person who struggles with reality and power. 

Our scrappy non-binary soldier character is the voice of the newest generation - the future. Rarely do we see non-binary characters in media, let alone complex ones. We're thrilled that The Regime is Female strives to be a part of that solution. They will be engaging in stunts, mixed media performance, and is a significant player in the story. 

Even the male characters are non-traditional in The Regime is Female. We joke about how we have a "woke bae" character, but it's rare to find a male character who isn't the antagonist.

The gender role dynamics in The Regime is Female are refreshing and exciting. 

Also, there's stunts!! Who doesn't wanna see that?!

 

Your Support with Financing: 

Thanks to our partnership with the Tank, the overhead for this production is lower than most indie theatrical productions. However, rehearsal space in New York isn't cheap and we plan to properly compensate our performers and team. We also want to have promotional packages that will fill the house over our three-week run! 

Your support covers: 

  • Rehearsal space
  • Costumes, props, and set design
  • Payment for talent and production team
  • Press materials and promotion
  • Stunt equipment
  • Video equipment
  • Insurance

Stretch goals include hiring a professional PR company to promote the show, supplementing our own resources. 

Perks!

What's the fun of donating without perks? We're putting the "badass" in Badass Lady Productions with these perks. We have free empowerment coaching, personal training sessions, free tickets to the show, and so much more! Go claim yours before they run out!!

 

Who We Are:

 

Playwright: Sarah Elizabeth Grace

Founder of Badass Lady Productions, Sarah Elizabeth Grace has written and produced female-centered works since 2013. Self-produced works include Mental Nudity (PIT Underground), More (The Secret Theater), Implied Consent (Access Theater). Her ten-minute play Crush was featured in Alternative Theater's "#MeToo Plays" series in November 2018.  Sarah holds a BFA in Drama from NYU Tisch. Sarah's unflinching and riveting work is motivated by her interest in human behavior and its gray areas. She creates worlds that contain sex-positive anti-heroines and steady, soft-spoken men. In all of her plays, she strives to make authentic and fearless depictions of women. For more information, click here.

Director: Andi Villa Stover

Andi is a writer, director and dramaturg. As writer/director for LiveFeedNYC she has various credits such as: Places, Noodles Astray (La Mama E.T.C.) Julie S. Caesar and The Housewives of Trevi (Ace Hotel); Black Eye Fixer (Glasslands Gallery and Club Midway.) As a dramaturg, she has worked with playwrights Sibyl Kempson, Yasmine Lever, Charles McNulty and choreographer Johanna Meyer. Andi is the Literary Manager and teacher for Montclair State University. A frequent contributor to the Brooklyn Rail, she is a graduate of Brooklyn College (MFA) and Yale University (BA).

 

Fight Coordinator: Frank Alfano

Frank Alfano Jr. started his education in Florida's theater scene and graduated from VCU school of the arts in 2008.  Since then he has worked as a professional stuntman for film and television.  Film credits include: Joker, The Dead Don’t Die, Skin, and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. TV credits include: Daredevil, Gotham, The Blacklist, Law and Order:SVU, Person of Interest, Maniac, and many more.  Frank also performed stunts for Red Dead Redemption 2.

 

Badass Lady Productions

Badass Lady Productions has been producing authentic, women-centered stories in the New York City area since 2013. Most recently, Badass Lady Productions produced Implied Consent at the Access Theater to full houses and rave reviews. The company's first production Mental Nudity - a solo show about the triumphs and trials of growing up - had runs at Standard Toykraft and the PIT Underground in 2013. In 2017, the company co-produced More - a full length play about addiction - with the Secret Theatre's UNFringed Festival, and was revived for the Emerging Artist Theatre's New Works Series in March 2018. Spearheaded by Sarah Elizabeth Grace, Badass Lady Productions is devoted to making theater that is diverse, unapologetic, and real. Find us on Facebook!

 

Broke but Want to Help??

You can help by sharing this page! Spread the word!  

Badass Lady Productions is always looking for volunteers throughout this process. Audition monitors, readers, flyer-posters, set builders, you name it, we can use it. Reach out!

story:
Short Summary

Railcard theatre is a new theatre company consisting of young people that specialise in creating entertaining, escapist theatre that tackles relatable and inspiring issues through performance. 

Our target is to challenge the stigma around theatre by making it an accessible experience for young people to relate to and enjoy. We are looking to use verbatim stories as a basis to write our own original content that will aim to help unite and inspire young people.

We believe that theatre has the power to provide a creative outlet for young people who need guidance, unity and above all entertainment. Relatable stories are at the heart of our practice and we hope to inspire and entertain you with our performance.

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise a minimum of £100 to help us get our first performance under-way. We have currently received a grant of £200 from Lincoln University, (UK) which, although generous, leaves us short of our bare-minimum budget. We hope to create theatre that is truly enjoyable and enthralling, so please help us reach our goal! 

We care deeply about our community and all those who support us and believe we can bring joy to many. We will be offering rewards such as personal thank you messages and Snapchat previews of our teams work in rehearsals, so we can bring a little joy to your day and show you what we're about!

The Impact

With so many young people struggling to find reasons to be happy and inspired about their futures right now, We believe we can help make a difference. Every member of our team and cast has expressed the gratitude they have for theatre's influence on their lives.  We know first hand the power that theatre has to inspire hope and change, but also to simply offer the pleasure of an entertaining story. 

Risks & Challenges

Like any new theatre company we are faced with the challenge of competing for the few opportunities in our area and financing our projects. We are lucky to have a team of brilliant  and inspired individuals, who are working hard to ensure every aspect of our upcoming project is considered with these risks in mind.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to help fund our project? We understand! Even just a like or share of our Facebook page 'Railcard Theatre' would be hugely appreciated!

story:
Hello!

We are Eleanor Westbrook (singing, clown-y type theatre-making musician woman) and Livvy Lynch (performance/sound/video artist). We are taking two new solo shows to Edinburgh Fringe and sharing a full run at the festival. We will perform on alternating nights in La Vida Room 3 from the 4th - 25th August.

Livvy's Big Bird is a fast-paced multi-media show about a sub-human, more-than-human, city-dwelling pigeon whose wings don’t work. In a style that mixes tragedy with absurdity, the links between mental distress and neoliberalism are explored through voice, video and live-looping.​

Ellie’s Big Berg is a surreal adventure into antarctic exploration. It’s also a pondering on the meaning of life. It’s also really silly. And there’s live music and a silver onesie. See this review to get one man's perspective.

 

We are two artists who respect and want to support each other’s work, and we’re basically just asking for some help to pay for it. We have a long run with a lot of outgoing expenses and your (wonderfully generous) donation will help us cover the costs of:

  • Promo: flyers & posters (a LOT of flyers and posters waft their way around the fringe, so we need to try and keep on top of the paper wave).

  • To be in the official digital programme.

  • Our travel costs.

  • Lighting hire (our venue is not a theatre space so we have to glam it up ourselves).

  • Props/costume.

  •  

If we don’t make our goal, we will still perform. We will use whatever is raised to pay to be in the programme (£295.20), and use personal funds to cover the rest. The difference your donation can make is to render other purchases less of an obstacle.

 

We’ve been working really hard on making these new shows, and getting the word out is so important. It would be a shame to perform to no-one as we feel there is value in what we are bringing to the festival (a fundamental need for big laugh in face of big sad). If you are able to contribute anything, whatever the amount, it would go towards our presence on the scene and our learning & sharing as artists/makers/performers/human beings as a whole. (Just so you know, your taxes are going towards the Queen’s morning tit massage, so why not fund some art...?)

If you cannot make a contribution right now (maybe you’ve just spent your entire salary on a single cashew nut?), we understand. You can still help by making some NOISE about our shows. Spread the word, share our indiegogo page and Facebook info, and come visit us if you’re up at Edinburgh Fringe in August (we’re there all month)!

 

Warmest love and huge thanks,

Liv & Ellie x
story_txt:
Hello!
We are Eleanor Westbrook (singing, clown-y type theatre-making musician woman) and Livvy Lynch (performance/sound/video artist). We are taking two new solo shows to Edinburgh Fringe and sharing a full run at the festival. We will perform on alternating nights in La Vida Room 3 from the 4th - 25th August.
Livvy's Big Bird is a fast-paced multi-media show about a sub-human, more-than-human, city-dwelling pigeon whose wings don’t work. In a style that mixes tragedy with absurdity, the links between mental distress and neoliberalism are explored through voice, video and live-looping.​
Ellie’s Big Berg is a surreal adventure into antarctic exploration. It’s also a pondering on the meaning of life. It’s also really silly. And there’s live music and a silver onesie. See this review to get one man's perspective.
 
We are two artists who respect and want to support each other’s work, and we’re basically just asking for some help to pay for it. We have a long run with a lot of outgoing expenses and your (wonderfully generous) donation will help us cover the costs of:

Promo: flyers & posters (a LOT of flyers and posters waft their way around the fringe, so we need to try and keep on top of the paper wave).
To be in the official digital programme.
Our travel costs.
Lighting hire (our venue is not a theatre space so we have to glam it up ourselves).
Props/costume.
 

If we don’t make our goal, we will still perform. We will use whatever is raised to pay to be in the programme (£295.20), and use personal funds to cover the rest. The difference your donation can make is to render other purchases less of an obstacle.
 
We’ve been working really hard on making these new shows, and getting the word out is so important. It would be a shame to perform to no-one as we feel there is value in what we are bringing to the festival (a fundamental need for big laugh in face of big sad). If you are able to contribute anything, whatever the amount, it would go towards our presence on the scene and our learning & sharing as artists/makers/performers/human beings as a whole. (Just so you know, your taxes are going towards the Queen’s morning tit massage, so why not fund some art...?)
If you cannot make a contribution right now (maybe you’ve just spent your entire salary on a single cashew nut?), we understand. You can still help by making some NOISE about our shows. Spread the word, share our indiegogo page and Facebook info, and come visit us if you’re up at Edinburgh Fringe in August (we’re there all month)!
 
Warmest love and huge thanks,
Liv & Ellie x

story:
We're Back!

Thanks to our loyal supporters and fans, our L.A. production of WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP was a hit!  The huge buzz helped propel WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP to its official World Premiere at the prestigious 500-seat TUTS Underground in Houston.  The show got rave reviews and standing ovations every night!! 

People keep asking us to bring WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP back to L.A.!! We are very proud and happy to announce our upcoming production at the Whitefire Theatre in Sherman Oaks, opening Friday, March 25th, 2016! We will run for a total of 6 consecutive Friday nights!  The show features two brand new songs that have never been heard before! 

We will definitely sell out, so reserve your tickets early!!!

What We Need & What You Get

We are crazy artists, much like our lead character, Rita.  We promise  to put on a brilliant show for you that will make you laugh, cry, be inspired and go home singing!!  This has been proven show after show!!! 

However, we need to fully finance this production through the kindness (and tickets) of our supporters and fans!  We need financing to pay for the theatre, designers, crew, and to hire an expert musical theatre publicist. Your donations will be repaid with our endless gratitude and fabulous perks!

And for you high rollers, donations of $7,500 and above will be rolled over into an investment in the future Off-Broadway run!!!

About the Show

Janet Cole Valdez, Deedee O’Malley and Bettie Ross are multi-award winning writers and composers. Together they have created WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP, inspired by true experiences in the entertainment industry.

WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP takes us on a wild ride with New York actress Rita Donatella, in her quest to land the role of a lifetime in a Johnny Depp film. She constantly re-invents herself to be more perfect for the role, as she navigates the rough waters of surviving in the big apple with her dream intact. It is both hilarious and heartwarming, to see how Rita comes to terms with the big questions: how to survive financially, how to recognize true love, how to balance the demands of career and family, and ultimately, what is really important in life?


Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating for tickets and other goodies, you can help by spreading the word!!

story:
Short Summary

This is an Independent Student Production at the University of Southern California. What that means is everything about this show is student organized, student run, and student produced. At USC, we are always challenged to take initiative and push ourselves to what we can create and do. This production is a perfect opportunity to showcase just that, but we cannot do that alone. That's why we are reaching out to all of you: friends, family, classmates, random people we've met in the elevator, all of you.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order for this show to reach it's full potential, we need help from all of you guys to afford the lighting, set design, and costuming for this show. Our goal is to reach $2,000 so the designers can afford the best proper materials to make this show as great as it can be.

You can think of your donation as your admission. As an independent student production, we have a "suggested" $5 ticket admission price, but any donations of a higher value can secure you at least one ticket on any night of your choosing. Other perks can include: mentions as donors and backers of this wonderful show in the program distributed at every performance, thank you videos from the cast and crew, and preferred seating at a performance of your choosing.

If in the unfortunate case we do not reach our total goal of $2,000 we will still do everything in our power to help the designers afford the materials they need. However, it would be terrific to see many different people donate to this cause and show their love and support for the arts. The cast and crew consists of 16 people total. If each person reached out to 10 friends, and all their friends donated $10, we would only be $400 short of our goal, and that's incredible to think about! Such a small personal donation can make the world of difference to those of us working on this production. 

 

The People You Are Helping

The cast and crew of this show who need your help are:

Sabrina Batchler - Sister Glenna/Caiaphas the Elder
Shrey Bhargava - Judas Iscariot
Reese Brucker - Loretta/Matthias of Galilee/Soldier 2
Kristin Clarke - Henrietta Iscariot/Mary Magdalene
Brandon Courture - Judge Littlefield/Saint Matthew
Stephanie Elmir - Saint Monica/Soldier 3

Miguel Angel Garcia - Simon the Zealot/Butch Honeywell
Danny Herman - Satan
Josh Lozier - Yusef Akbar Azziz Al-Nassar Gamel El-Fayoumy
Matt Mitchell - Bailiff/Sigmund Freud/Saint Thomas
Sara Molinar - Fabiana Aziza Cunningham
Austin Peay - Jesus of Nazareth
Grace Sallee - Saint Peter/Pontius Pilate
Angie Sarkisyan - Gloria/Mother Teresa/Soldier 1

Directed by Michael DiNardo
Stage Managed/Assistant Directed by Brenda Plitt

 

The Impact

At USC, students have the opportunity to work on shows fully funded by the school and directed, designed, and produced by professors and guest directors brought in from the LA area. What's special about Independent Student Productions like this one is they challenge and encourage students to produce everything by themselves. There are no academic advisors, or directorial help by professors during the process, but rather everything is created and collaborated by the students themselves. From rehearsals, to designing, to acquiring materials and resources, through to the final performance, it is 100% student run and organized, and provides everyone involved with a unique learning opportunity that cannot be achieved through other shows.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford any donations at this time, not to worry! Something that is just as helpful is awareness about this fund and campaign, so please share this on any social media platform you're on, as well as when you have the chance to talk about with friends, family, classmates, co-workers, etc. The more people hear about this campaign, the less each individual needs to donate to achieve our goal, and the easier it can be to come together as a community and help make this production a hit.
