story:
Jessica Cermak has been creating theatre off off broadway theatre for five years.  She is passionate about creating work that exposes her community to the classics by using inovative production concepts. 
 

 

The Three Sister Experiment

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6SxzdBxZ-o&...

Based on Three Sisters by Anton Chekhov
 
Directed by Josie McAdam
Featuring:
Jessica Cermak
Heather Cambanes  
Sam Kinsman
Fe(lix) Namasté
 Victoria Tucci  
Annie-Sage Whitehurst

March 21, 22, 23, 28, 29, and 30 8p at WOW cafe theatre.

59-61 E 4th St  New York, NY 10003 

To reserve tickets, click on the link below.

http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?showcode=THR45
 
 

What We Need

We are opperating on shoe string budget, but we will still accure some minor expenses.  Below is a basic break down of our budget for The Three Sisters Experiment.  Please consider assisting us in production costs.

Actors $700
Director $200
Rehearsal $300
Lighting                  $100
Sound $100
Costumes $200
Promotion $500
   
 TOTAL $2,000
   

Perks

$20 - A ticket to the Three Sisters reading on Febuary 22nd 7p

$50- A ticket to the Three Sisters reading, A ticket Three Sisters Experiment and a thank you in our program

$100- All of the above and two free drinks at Three Sisters Experiment

$200 - All of the above and a signed cast photo from Three Sisters Experiment

$500 - All of the above and your choice of a Russian dish served to you during the intermission of Three Sisters Experiment

$1,000- All of the above and a performance of a scene of your choice from Three Sisters at a location of your choice (within the NYC tristate area)

 

About WOW Cafe Theatre


WOW Café Theater is a women's theater collective in NYC's East Village, which promotes the empowerment of women through the performing arts.

Historically, WOW has been a majority lesbian woman's space. WOW welcomes the full participation of all women and transpeople in solidarity with women. WOW especially welcomes women and transpeople of color, and women and trans people who identify as lesbians, bisexual and queer. We provide a working theater space to our members & the technical support to create and produce works, regardless of economic status.

story:
UPDATE:  YOU DID IT! Thank you for supporting Hook & Eye and our upcoming production of The Summoners! We look forward to seeing you in January.

THE HOOK…

Every theater company has its angle.  Hook & Eye builds plays collectively with our "cloud" of artists. The Summoners is being created in four phases:

Phase One (completed! Partially funded by your previous donations, thank you!):

  • In July, we headed out to a lovely farm in Pennsylvania - a creative army of ten - to build a new piece. What resulted is a moving examination of modern America, corporate intrusion, and the current state of hope

Phase Two (completed):

  • We just finished the Script Workshop of The Summoners in October. Our playwright, Gavin Broady (who wrote so brilliantly for all three of last year’s PlayLabs) is working on revisions. The company will convene on November 13th for a final read-through before we head into pre-production and rehearsal
Phase Three (RIGHT NOW!):

  • FUNDRAISING. The costs involved to make a piece of original theater and bring it to the stage are surprisingly high. We'd like to share with you exactly where your generous contributions will go.

Phase Four (January 2014):

  • The Summoners will run January 21-February 1, 2014 at the C.O.W Theater on Manhattan's Lower East Side!

THE EYE...

At the center of the storm is a calm reality. We have raised one third of our budget, but we need your help. Grants help, applications are in, but right now, YOU are our seed funding.   Here is a breakdown of our remaining four highest expenses.

  • Theater Venue, Rehearsal Space & Insurance $6,200

  • Press & Marketing $1,200

  • Design Elements: Costumes, Sound, Sets & Props $2,400

  • Artists & Staff Compensation $4,200

& YOU...

Every dollar you give toward this campaign will help bring The Summoners to life. This is not for our general operating budget, that’s a different story for another time. If you are short on funds, but still want to help, we welcome Volunteers!

  • We have opportunities for ushers at each performance or maybe you want to help out at the Box Office - or perhaps you're handy with power tools or have access to low-cost printing . . . please contact us if you want to get involved!

  • Spread the word - You can do this right from home!

  • Use the share tools and post the Vimeo video to your Facebook and Twitter sites. Or direct them to our website or Facebook page. The more this crowdfunding drive goes viral, the more chance we have of sharing the world premiere of The Summoners with the widest audience possible.

Thank you from all of us at Hook & Eye Theater!

Carrie Heitman, Chad Lindsey, Gavin Broady, Virginia Venk, Emily Kunkel, Cynthia Babak, Christopher McMahon, Yasmeen Jawhar, Elizabeth London

story:
Short Summary

This is the World Premiere play about the famous meeting between veteran eccentric English poet, Dr. Edith Sitwell and rising American film star, Marilyn Monroe in Hollywood at the bequest of Life magazine in 1953. Two more opposite women it would be impossible to find and yet they shared a difficult upbringing and hid behind the public façade of their larger than life personalities. This play examines both the real vulnerable women underneath and their iconic personas they are best remembered for. Hollywood director, George Cukor, who knew both women, is desperately trying to hold proceedings together as he struggles to capture on film the historic meeting between the two women on a studio sound stage.

What We Need & What You Get

If we raise $6000:

  • Playwright, David Bottomley will be able to fly out to San Diego from London to be part of his World Premiere at the San Diego Fringe Festival.
  • The funding will allow us to tell the story with scenery, props, costume and makeup.
  • As well as hire our personnel: Actors, stage managers, Scenic Designer, Lighting Designer, Costume Designer, Wigs and Make-up Designer and Sound Designer.
  • Tax Deduction when donating for this production: Actors Alliance of San Diego Tax ID 33-0488471

The Impact

The San Diego Fringe Festival brings artists from all over the world and the United States of America together to create art. This is a valuable asset bringing culture and people to create a positive impact for this great city in California.

This project will connect two artists, a British playwright from London and an American director from San Diego to work together in bringing this world premiere play come to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps, even if it's $10 or $25, that is such a great support for us to create; however, we understand that in certain circumstances some people cannot afford to give money, we do ask that if you could please share this to as many people you can.

The many ways you can share is on facebook, e-mail, linkedon, twitter and google+... Please help us create our goal or above to make this come true.

Thank you,

Bryant Hernandez
director of THE PEACOCK AND THE NIGHTINGALE: When Edith met Marilyn

story:
Help The Chaski's Theatre Co embark on their debut performance project at the Cockpit Theatre!

Chaski's provide a transatlantic platform for outstanding work from the Americas largely unknown to the UK. We work with text from North, South and Central America, but giving a UK platform to Latino playwrights is also a central part our work.  This debut performance project is a one-night showcase of six extracts taken from a shortlist of plays that have never before been seen on a London stage!

Where's your money going?

This activity is our first step into a public performance, following years of research and development and countless meetings and workshops. Your support will help us to take this first step with confidence and security, helping us to cover the cost of rehearsal space, set demands, marketing and to pay the artists involved and our cast of eight. We intend to divide funds as follows:

Rehearsal space: £900

Fees for production staff: £750

Director & cast travel expenses: £1100

Set, costume and props: £500

Marketing: £150

Contingency and other fees: £300

Come and see the results!

New World Playwrights - A Night of Unwriting 

Cockpit Theatre, 14th Dec. Book tickets here.

Featuring work by: Migdalia Cruz, Octavio Solis, Matthew Paul Olmos, Mariana Carreño King, Pedro Miguel Rozo and Nate Rufus Edelman, as well as text from Pulitzer Prize winner Nilo Cruz.

The showcase will give us the opportunity to physically engage in the staging of these plays and to present them in front of an audience - including peers, press and producers. We want to evidence the fact that there is a place for these texts here and to use our skills as artists to serve them in the best possible way to a British audience. Our achievements here will set Chaski's well on its path to a full production in 2015 and to further enriching the UK with a constant stream of outstanding American text. 

The event is truly a seed that we now need to plant, the first step into solidly establishing our company, to tell stories that need to be told.

The Cast

Adam Patrick Boakes 

Zelina Rebeiro

Rowan Polonski

Eva Fontaine

Huw Parmenter

Fiz Marcus

Josie Dunn

Gerry Howell

Heather Winstanley

Raymi Renee

Director - David Zoob

Project Manager - Teya Lanzon

Lighting - William Adams

Sound - Tord Brudevoll

Costume - Maddy McIndoe

Photographer - Lee Bader

More about us...

The Chaski's Theatre Company was formed by Rose Bruford graduates reacting against the limitations of their profession, in a money-driven industry where commercial gain and fame tend to trump story. Above all we wanted to continue to tell stories with integrity on our favourite platform. 

After our Bolivian story "Give Us This Day Our Daily Bread" was crowned the winner of The Lost Theatre's 5 Minute Festival in 2011, we continued to look to stories from distant lands. This interest led us to the Americas - North, South and Central - and to the outstanding works of such playwrights as Nilo Cruz; Octavio Solis; Migdalia Cruz and Miguel Pinero, among others. Our desire to tell their stories led us to establish close links with the playwrights in question and so today, we benefit from strong relationships with a large number of American artists. With the Old Vic New Voices LAB scheme supporting us with rehearsal space, Chaski's have already begun to read-through, workshop and translate some of this text. Over the past three years, we have nurtured relationships and built the artistic bridges that run from America to the UK - these are strong, now they must go further!

The Chaski's future...

Not only the event, but the entire process of managing the project, of rallying together as a company, of mounting this one night show; will prepare Chaski's for the road ahead. 

Our first performance endeavour, and the many challenges that we are sure to encounter will be invaluable to our company's growth and development. It is only through such experiences that we can truly begin to function as a business and to gain the necessary skills that will go on to secure our future and our ability to keep producing work with integrity.

The importance of this showcase is further emphasised by the fact that our contacts in the USA are constantly growing, and we now wish to deliver palpable, visual and physical evidence of what our company is about and what we have to offer! 

And lastly...

We understand that many of us are not able to help with £££, particularly at this time of year, but your help in spreading the word and sharing our project around is so super valuable! Please help us to reach out to as many people as possible in this limited amount of time!
story_txt:
Help The Chaski's Theatre Co embark on their debut performance project at the Cockpit Theatre! 



Chaski's provide a transatlantic platform for
outstanding work from the Americas largely unknown to the UK. We work with text
from North, South and Central America, but giving a UK platform to Latino
playwrights is also a central part our work. 
This debut performance project is a one-night showcase of six extracts
taken from a shortlist of plays that have never before been seen on a London
stage!
Where's your money going?

This activity is our first step into a public performance, following years of research and development and countless meetings and workshops. Your support will help us to take this first step with confidence and security, helping us to cover the cost of rehearsal space, set demands, marketing and to pay the artists involved and our cast of eight. We intend to divide funds as follows:
Rehearsal space: £900
Fees for production staff: £750
Director & cast travel expenses: £1100
Set, costume and props: £500
Marketing: £150
Contingency and other fees: £300

Come and see the results!

New World Playwrights - A Night of Unwriting 
Cockpit Theatre, 14th Dec. Book tickets here.

Featuring work by: Migdalia Cruz, Octavio Solis, Matthew Paul Olmos, Mariana Carreño
King, Pedro Miguel Rozo and Nate Rufus Edelman, as well as text from Pulitzer
Prize winner Nilo Cruz.
The showcase will give us the opportunity to physically engage in the staging of these plays and to present them in front of an audience - including peers, press and producers. We want to evidence the fact that there is a place for these texts here and to use our skills as artists to serve them in the best possible way to a British audience. Our achievements here will set Chaski's well on its path to a full production in 2015 and to further enriching the UK with a constant stream of outstanding American text. 
The event is truly a seed that we now need to plant, the first step into solidly establishing our company, to tell stories that need to be told.


The Cast

Adam Patrick Boakes 

Zelina RebeiroRowan Polonski

Eva Fontaine

Huw Parmenter 
Fiz Marcus

Josie DunnGerry HowellHeather Winstanley








Raymi Renee




Director - David Zoob

Project Manager - Teya LanzonLighting - William AdamsSound - Tord Brudevoll

Costume - Maddy McIndoe

Photographer - Lee Bader

reach out to as many people as possible in this limited amount of time!

story:
HISTORY OF THE CARVER THEATER

The Carter Theater opened on Sept. 29, 1950 and was named after the scientist George Washington Carver. For three decades, the theater featured a wide variety of entertainment. That meant everything from movies to musicals to performances from artists like soul singer Sam Cooke, who would stop by for a late-night gig after playing at the Blue Room at the Roosevelt Hotel.

The Carver Theater is recognized on the National Register of Historic Places as having "exceptional significance." This designation is because it was one of the first major theaters that catered specifically to black people during a time when New Orleans’ entertainment venues — and most other institutions — were segregated. When it was built in 1950 as a movie theater and a talent show venue, it was a turning point for blacks in New Orleans.

The Carver was built during Jim Crow, and during Jim Crow blacks weren't allowed on the ground floor of the theater. They had to go up to the balcony, and this theater was built as the only theater without a balcony in the city. 

In 1980, the theater became a medical clinic. Then the historic site suffered major damage from six feet of water during Hurricane Katrina.

After undergoing an extensive renovation and restoration, The Carver Theater has re-opened its doors. It now accommodates up to 500 seated guests and over 800 standing. It is available for private functions, film productions and live entertainment. The Carver is also equipped with a high-tech Meyer sound system and has a second-floor VIP lounge.
What We Need & What You Get

As you now know, The Carver Theater is a gem inside and out! The Carver, as it exists has a parking at the rear of the building. We have acquired an additional lot adjacent to the theater that we wish to develop into The Carver's primary parking lot.

  • The cost for the development of this parking lot is $60,000. 
  • We have put together several unique perks that allow you the "Backer" to come experience The Historic Carver theater first hand and/ or align yourself or your business with The Carver Theater. 
  • All funds raised will go directly into the development of our new parking area and any other related costs that may arise during that time.

The Impact

New Orleans has a ton of re-building to do, but we have come a really long way! We’re going to be part of that eclectic mix that is the Treme community! The Carver Theater is a catalyst for redevelopment in the neighborhood.

  • Come and Experience the culture the Treme/ Mid-City area
  • Enjoy an array of live performances and events at The Carver Theater
  • Help to revitalize a neighborhood that is coming back stronger than ever before! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We truly understand that you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • You can email this campaign to your friends and family!
  • Share it on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.
  • Old Fashion Word of Mouth!
  • Look for the Indiegogo share tools above!

We'll see you at The Carver!!

story:
Foxy5 Werqshop is a communal experience cultivated through dance, video, and selfexpression.

Through our network and Werqshops, we’re building a community of

creative individuals, a place where futures in self-expression can grow.

Here’s How Our Werqshops Work:

> It’s a 5-week series of dance classes, 1 choreographer, and 1 particular style,

per session

> After 5-weeks of practicing perfection, the Werqshop will end with the dancers

working-it-out! Makeup artist included – the end of every session is a complete

video shoot, crafting the choreography into an amazing video experience

> The goal of every Werqshop is to leave both performer and choreographer

with an awesome new piece for their reel – and makeup artists, videographers,

directors, and editors a new piece for their portfolio

> In addition to the Werqshop experience, all individuals within Foxy5 are part

of our Community of Creatives, which means all-types-of-talent at your disposal

and networking galore

Why We Need Your Support:

Starting an organization that exists solely to support the community that supports it means that money can be tight. Things like, insurance, incorporation costs, and financial organization, seriously add up, and can truly burden the beginning stages of a business.

It’s not easy – but before we can give back to our community – we’ve got to get our model off the ground. 

With a donation to our campaign, you’re making the Foxy5 community even  stronger.

Thank you and keep it Foxy!

Jessie & Sarah

Co-founders, Foxy5 Werqshop

story:
Short Summary

2020 is just around the corner, but the World Dance Instructor Survey is still using 1990 technology.  And it takes a long time to get our results.  We will hire a developer to bring this process to your phone or tablet, let you enter your teaches as you go, and get results almost instantly (by the end of the project.)   Currently many instructors send in their teaches to regional collectors who will continue to offer that service for those not connected to technology. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for seed money to fund the first phase of the development.  $2500 will pay for the design, initial coding and testing phase of developing the app.  Most features of the app will be free for everyone.  We might find some features that will be more expensive to offer and additional funding will be sought for that phase. 

The Impact

We already collect teaches from over 200 instructors around the world, but this app has the potential to increase that 10 times.  It also will be able to break down reports regionally and give instructors more details that they can truly use to make their classes the best in town!

It will encourage instructors to try new exciting dancers and encourage the best choreographers to keep working hard. 

Risks & Challenges

We know apps can have glitches when they first launch.  We hope to set expectations that we will need everyone to help us test and work out the kinks.  This is a project for and by the dance community.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Any small contribution is greatly appreciated.  Ask your students or other instructors you know to pitch in.  Especially those who don't currently contribute data to the survey, because they have waiting for it to join the 21st Century!  Tell them we're here!

story:
On September 2, 2011, almost two years to the day since I first arrived in Chicago to pursue the whole playwriting thing, my play Alone Apart will premier at the Chicago Fringe Festival. Obviously, I am terribly excited.

However, as my master's degrees in English and Theatre make clear, I am also terribly poor and have terribly poor judgment. Because of this poor judgment, I have taken it upon myself to produce the show myself.

The good news is that I have assembled a great production team, but the time has come to give them money to buy and make things. Even with a thrifty, lil' fringe production such as ours, stage blood costs money (actually we're using corn syrup and food coloring, but you get the point).

At any rate, a little under $100 to costume five actors, a little more than $100 to build the set and the props, then there are the printing costs for scripts and publicity materials, $250+ for the rehearsal space, not to mention the original $400 pay-to-play fee for the festival, itself. It does tend to add up. And, as much as I loath to come to you with hat in hand, I could really use your help.

Because THE SHOW MUST GO ON and it's contributions from viewers like you that keep fine nature programs like this on the air. Anything at all you could give would be deeply appreciated by me and the rest of Team Lonely--a bunch of wonderfully talented, dedicated people who are volunteering their time and considerable talents to make this a memorable, quality production.

Needless to say, if you are a friend of mine who doesn't live in Chicago and can't make the performances, but would happily pony up the ten bucks for a ticket if you were in town, well, this is your chance to do so without actually having to sit through the play, itself. Now how much would you pay?!

Seriously, this show means a great deal to me. It's the second part of the trilogy I've been spending almost a decade working on. It's my first full Chicago production. It's in a decent venue in a program that has some visibility. And, in the grand scheme of things, it's my dream. I know times are tough and I have no right to ask (and feel pretty lousy about it, to be honest), but any spare dimes you might part with will be put to good, artistically viable use, I assure you.


Thank you!

story:
In 2015, we presented a site-specific world premiere of FLOYDADA, Barry Rowell’s play about two eccentric, middle-aged sisters in 1927 Texas. Dalia, a terminally ill artist, and Ada, the dutiful caretaker, are forced together again after years apart. Unwilling to sit around and wait to die, Dalia shakes up her sister’s mundane existence by convincing her to open a Dada-inspired cabaret in the family’s empty storefront. Floydada was a finalist in the 2011 Texas Playwrights Festival.

The response from the press and audiences was so enthusiastic that we are reconfiguring the production for traditional theater spaces and working with companies and festivals outside of NYC—including Great Escape Stage Company in Marshall, MI—to bring FLOYDADA to their audiences. We had an enormous raw storefront space for the premiere—so large, we were able to include an art gallery as part of the event. For the “portable” version, the team is retooling the video, staging, sets, and music to work in a more compact, intimate environment—while still keeping a sense of the huge expanse of the West Texas plains. To help with that, we’ve expanded the sound effects in the play to make the aural experience grander and more pervasive. We’ve also enhanced the set and projection screens to recreate some of the scope that made the NYC production unique.

We’re entering the home stretch now with a March 2016 workshop in The Lounge at Dixon Place in NYC. Since we won’t be able to take everyone out on the road, the workshop gives the team members two full days to really work on the show together and get it ready to travel. We’ve raised over half of what we need; all we need to finish is at least $3,000 to help us cover some of the expenses and stipends for all of the artists.

We’re SO-O-O-O close to a production that can be enjoyed by people around the country and, eventually, around the world. Please HELP US reach our goals by donating something—anything at all—right now.

Thank you so very, very much.

Barry, Catherine & Ralph

Show website: http://peculiarworks.org/floydada

Company website: www.peculiarworks.org

story:
Auld Stag Theatre is an exciting new theatre company based in Edinburgh. We aim to bring high quality, contemporary Scottish theatre to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe every year. This year we can't wait to present our debut production "Yellow Moon: The Ballad of Leila and Lee" by David Greig.

We have a hugely talented team on board to make "Yellow Moon" a fantastic show for audiences of all types. To compliment this team, we are keen to be able to use high quality set, costume, props and lighting. This is where you come in.

Without these things we simply cannot produce the show that the you deserve to see, and like many new theatre companies, we need your vital support in order to raise the funds that will push us over the finish line!

With your help, we can put on a truly top class show that will excite and impress audiences throughout our Fringe run, while also bringing to light fantastic Scottish theatre that many people may not be aware of.

The team behind Auld Stag Theatre are: Julia Carstairs, a recent journalism graduate from Edinburgh Napier University; Joe Christie, an English Lit. and French student at the University of Edinburgh and Macleod Stephen who studies Law, also at the University of Edinburgh.

We were brought together by our shared passion for great theatre combined with our determination to bring something new and exciting to the Scottish theatre scene.

This campaign is of vital importance to help us acheive that goal not just for this year, but for future productions; first impressions are vital, and you can help us make a great one!

Where does all the money go? Well, we need to cover a wide variety of costs in order to produce our play, and so funds raised from this campaign will be distributed to help cover all areas of the production: set, props, costume, advertising, venue hire and the the rights to perform the play! We are aiming to raise £850, which will enable us to fully cover all of our costs.

By donating to our cause you also become eligible to claim some awesome perks! For £5 you will be mentioned in the programme, for a tenner you can have a poster signed by the cast. Bigger donations will secure you free tickets to see the show, and there are even chances to meet and have dinner with the cast and the director!

We appreciate that not everyone is able to contribute directly, but you can still help us! We would be massively grateful to anyone and everyone who could spread the word about our company and our show; the more people who know about us, the more likely we are to reach our target!

story:
Krétakör Foundation - Support us, so we can play!

Since its establishment in 1995, Krétakör (Chalk Circle) has been the most vanguard underground arts organization in Hungary that has gained reputation for its politically reflective performances.The organization, that over the recent years has become the artistic epicentre of the democratic movement in Hungary, primarily produces stage performances and media art productions. It is led by Árpád Schilling (artistic director) and Márton Gulyás (managing director).

As of 2010, Hungary slowly but surely has begun getting closer authoritarianism, and has started resembling rather ang autocracy than a pluralist, liberal democracy.The currently governing center-right party led by PM Viktor Orbán has demolished the democratic institutions, and now has turned against the non-partisan civil society organizations. It has blacklisted all those organizations that are committed to defend human rights, democratic values and individual freedom. Krétakör is at the top of its blacklist. 


Since 2009 Krétakör has gradually lost all its state funds. However, we consider it as a success: our critical approach to depict politics compels us to remain independent from the cultural regime in every way. We cannot accept the way the Hungarian government functions nowadays, so obviously we cannot be its beneficiary either. This is one of the reasons why Krétakör is very dependent of private donors.

Árpád Schilling: Lúzer

Schilling`s new play "Lúzer" (i.e.: loser) is a reconsidered concept of his earlier play `The Party` that Krétakör staged in March 2014, just a couple of days before the Parliamentary elections in Hungary. With his provocative play, Schilling devoted himself to keep the nature of politics under scrutiny. How does the Party take control? How can democracy become an instrument of the ultimate power in the hand of the rulers? How could the Party become a piece of breaking news day after day? Simply, how does the Party operate and what it is good for? In 'The Party', Árpád Schilling invited the audience to redefine their way of thinking about public life: both the supporters of the current government and the skeptical members of the opposition were addressed. 

The Party was played in Hungary, Belgium and Sweden. The performance made a great impression on the audience, along with a far-reaching echo in the media. "If Bertolt Brecht had done theatre in 2014, he would be called Árpád Schilling". – Scène, Cédric Juliens.

In a new theater performance "Lúzer" (premier 5 October, Trafó, Budapest, Hungary) Schilling and his friends will punch in the face of those who are just sitting in the tepid water, waiting for someone else to make the changes. The company will not let their audience fall asleep.

"Something happens in Hungary that so far was known for me only from my readings. Viktor Orbán is establishing an absolute power in a democratic system of which each and every element is codified by him. Today’s Hungary is one of the most brutal democracies, where the governor party has direct influence on the public and commercial media, the bank system and the entire economy. Viktor Orbán is Hungary’s omnipotent master who does not have to fear of any pretender since there are no real rivals to threat his position. The left wing and liberal parties failed in Hungary." – Árpád Schilling's personal artistic comment.


Schilling's intention is to continue working on the topic of politics, but this time he will make the performance even rougher, more direct and up to date. He invited some actors of his former troop; Annamaria Lang, Lilla Sarosdi and Sandor Terhes will be joined by Emőke Kiss-Végh and Tamás Ördög, two young talents. The performance has already been invited to the Steierische Herbst in Graz and to the Theatre National of Bordeaux.

Your contribution will help us fund the creation of the performance.

Make a donation and we go on with our mission!

We very much appreciate even the smallest donation you can make to help us realize our project, each piece makes a difference. If you got us nothing but a caffé latte a month, we can continue to play the game.

Please let your friend know about this campaign.

* Email the link to this campaign to friends, family, colleagues, etc.
* Post the campaign link to your Facebook page, Twitter feed or other social media.
* Come see the play! See you on 5-6 October 2014, Trafó, Budapest, Hungary. 

THANK YOU!

story:
Short Summary

Art for Progress is proud to announce their upcoming production of Much Ado About Nothing. One of Shakespeare's most beloved comedies, Much Ado also takes a complex look at love, relationships and searching for "self," This production will use the classic language of Shakespeare in a modern setting - demonstrating the relevance of the writer's work in present day. This incredible show will also feature some of NYC's finest actors, comedians and public servants all on stage for a good cause. After production costs - all profits will go to Art for Progress's Education Program - helping young people tap into their artistic abilities. We hope you can contribute towards this important work and look forward to seeing you at the show!

Who We Are

Art for Progress is a New York City-based 501(c)3 nonprofit arts
organization committed to supporting international artists and providing
arts education in under-served communities.

Art for Progress’ Arts Education Community provides under-served youth
with dynamic artistic programming that promotes reflection and
self-expression. By connecting youth with working artists, their
communities and each other, we hope to transform the way they see
themselves and the world around them.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to present 'Much Ado About Nothing'!

     Your donation will go to: 

  • Theater rental
  • Our musicians
  • Rehearsal space and rehearsal pianist
  • Program and poster printing 
  • Publicity


    • To thank you for your support we have the following perks: 

    • VIP tickets to the show
    • Signed programs and posters from our cast and crew
    • An invitation to our wrap party
    • A private concert in your home
    • And much more!

Any funds we receive will go towards paying our production costs. Any additional funds past our goal plus all tickets sales will go directly to Art for Progress in support of their educational programming. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about our fundraising campaign, Art for Progress: Much Ado About Nothing, and our upcoming performances! 

  • Share our campaign with your friends via social media
  • Let fellow Shakespeare lovers know about our performances in May 
  • Like our Facebook page and share our updates

story:
"Urinetown" is the first musical student lab produced through Pitt's theatre department and the first collaborative process with Musical Theatre Club. However, musicals are extremely expensive. 

While we have earned some funds from the department and from the funds of our student groups, we are still a little short. With this additional money we would be able to fund the equipment and personal for microphones, afford to build our set, and purchase costume pieces/makeup so we don't have to use all of our own materials. As you can see above, rehearsals are underway and the cast and crew are working extremely hard (check out our gallery to see photos from the rehearsal room). Please let us help make a production that supports their talent and passion.

Urinetown is presented through special arrangement with Musical Theatre International (MTI). All authorized performance materials are also supplied by MTI. 421 West 54th Street New York, NY 10019, Phone: 212-541-4684, Fax: 212-397-4684, www.MTIShows.com

(Image artwork by Tim Kaniecki)

story:
Who we are

We are Megan Rhyme and Elizabeth Hicks, two people from very different fields who share a similar goal: to collaborate across disciplines and investigate the connections between art and science. Megan is an independent choreographer in Chicago who has danced with Salty Lark Dance, Renegade Dance Architects, Synapse Arts Collective, and has produced work at the Chicago Fringe Festival, and Links Hall. You can find more about her work at www.rhymedance.com. Elizabeth is an astrophysicist who studies fluid dynamics.  She is also the founder of Epsilon Delta Labs (www.epsilondeltalabs.org), a research lab focused on interdisciplinary projects.  We met at a joint event between Northwestern Science and Society and the Art of Science Learning, which took place at the Museum of Science and Industry. We decided to collaborate on this project because we want audiences to see that art can happen anywhere and to show that dialogue between art and science can enhance both artistic and scientific inquiry. You can visit our project website at http://epsilondeltalabs.org/far-from-equilibrium/ .


Our project is an artistic exploration of turbulence. Turbulence is in most places in the universe: in cream stirred into coffee, in the raging, swirling flames of forest fires on Earth, and even in massive explosions of energy from the surface of our Sun. This chaotic, complex twisting and stretching of fluid is mysterious, even to scientists. “Far From Equilibrium” invites audiences to immerse themselves in the beauty of turbulence and consider uncertainty, complexity, and how motion underlies form. This dance will be presented as part of Science Works, an annual STEM career celebration held at the Museum of Science and Industry. Tickets are included with general museum entry and can be purchased at www.msichicago.org. It is also a part of Chicago Artists Month, the 20th annual celebration of Chicago’s vibrant arts community presented by the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events www.chicagoartistsmonth.org.  


By contributing to this campaign, you will be helping fund Chicago artists and building collaborations between arts and science. Our campaign funds are going directly to paying the dancers and artists involved in the project and production costs such as rehearsal space and costumes. By showing your support, you’re showing the world that art and science have a vibrant future together!


What We Need

Our goal amount is $1500, which covers our necessary production costs, such as:

  • Costumes - $150

  • AV setup at the Museum - $150

  • Audience engagement tools such as programs, signs, and turbulence experiments that audience members can play with after the performance - $200

  • Videography to record the performance - $300

  • Dancer stipends - $100 stipend per dancer x 7 dancers = $700

Paying stipends to our dancers is very important to us, as they are the artists who are literally putting their brains and bodies to work to make this project possible.  We are going to pay a modest stipend of $100 to each dancer, which barely begins to cover the 50-60 hours worth of rehearsal time that they each put in!

We are very committed to the project and have already used our own personal funds to rent rehearsal space. If we don’t reach our goal, any funds we raise on Indiegogo will be going to cover dancer stipends and necessary production costs first and any remaining costs we will cover out of pocket. If we meet and can exceed our goal, there are some other costs that we would love to fund! Those include upgrading the quantity and quality of our audience engagement tools and reimbursing ourselves for the cost of renting rehearsal space.


Our perks

We have some fantastic perks for this project! All donations, regardless of the amount, will get recognition in our program. If you donate at one of the following levels, you will receive the perk for that level!

  • $20: Hand-made bookmark featuring the visual art of Elizabeth’s turbulence research

  • $35: DVD with a video of the dance

  • $50: DVD PLUS a personalized thank you video from the cast of the project

  • $75:  1 hour, one-person "Physics and Art” tour of the Art Institute of Chicago with Elizabeth

  • $125: 1 hour Behind the Scenes session for up to 4 people, either “Introduction to Modern Dance” with Megan or “Special Topics in Astronomy and Physics” with Elizabeth

  • $250: *Limited Edition* Laban Movement Analysis session with Certified Laban Movement Analyst Madeleine Reber OR a 11X14 Canvas print of Elizabeth’s turbulence research artwork



What we’re going to do

We want to open people’s minds to dance and science. Both are fields which tend to make people scratch their heads and say, “I don’t get it!”. Elizabeth and I are interested in cross-disciplinary work; we want to give people opportunities to discover more about the world by connecting across genres and labels. National ideas like STEAM education and TED talks are starting to foster communication between artists and scientists, and we want to bring that energy to Chicago. The Museum’s Science Works event is a career fair designed to showcase the many different fields in science; we want to expose attendees to the expanding world of cross-disciplinary work and get people talking about art and science collaborations.

Both Megan and Elizabeth have had experience with art and science collaboration before. Megan collaborated with a neuroscientist in 2010 to produce a show at the Chicago Fringe Festival, called Inner Cartography, about the brain and body mapping.  Elizabeth has created visual art works based on her research into fluid dynamics; her art has been presented and won honorable mentions at the Northwestern Science in Society’s Scientific Images Contest.

The project will include opportunities after the performance for individual audience members to learn more about turbulence and discuss collaboration with Megan and Elizabeth. Our goal is for the audience to make connections between the science and the art: to use the dance to help them better grasp the physics of turbulence, and use the physics as an entry point for appreciating the dance.



Our Challenges

The unique and exciting opportunity to perform at the Museum of Science and Industry also means that we won't be earning ticket sales, a typical source of revenue for many performing artists and arts organizations. So your support would mean to world to us; it will allow us to pay our hard working dancers for their time and cover production costs such as costumes and AV rental.

Megan’s company Rhyme/Dance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization.That means that all your donations to this project are tax-deductible!  Contributions for the charitable purposes of Far From Equilibrium must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate, there are still other ways you can help us out! Please consider spreading the word about our project and our campaign to others you know who might be interested. Indiegogo has lots of fabulous tools for sharing on many different social media platforms! Part of our goal is to raise awareness about art and science collaborations, and sharing our project with your friends will help us do just that. Thank you for your support!

story:
Ten years ago, Leap of Faith (a dance studio) started with 10 students. All the classes (ballet, tap, jazz, liturgical) were offered on Saturday. We practiced in a church basement. Our first production was in a facility with a small stage, minimal lighting and limited staging capabilities.

Today we serve close to 200 students from Central Ohio. We hold classes at our own facility (which has two studios) in the evenings Monday through Thursday, and from 8 to 5 on Saturdays. In recent years we have moved our annual showcase to the auditorium of a renovated, historic high school with a huge performance space and the potential for professional quality lighting and staging.

Unfortunately the space does not come with the lighting equipment needed to bring out the unique beauty and talent of our diverse student body.

Every year the dancers of Leap of Faith bring their best to the stage.

This year we want to light up their world.

Our 10-Year Anniversary Showcase Performance in June 2014 is an opportunity for the Leap of Faith community of staff and volunteers to show its appreciation for the dancers' dedication and hard work by providing professional quality lighting to illuminate and enhance the production.

The Leap of Faith staff spends its creative and emotional energies providing a safe, fun, and educational environment for our diverse student body. Our students (ages 3 1/2 to 73...and counting) learn more than choreography and dance terms.

They experience the embrace of a community.

We want to add another layer of education and experience.

We want Leap of Faith dancers to experience what it's like to maneuver around a boom or choose fresnel lights and gels, or discern how the use of a scrim will affect the interpretation of a performance.

As Leap of Faith celebrates its anniversary, we need professional lighting equipment so we can provide new educational performance opportunities for our dancers and present exciting dance productions to our audience.

We want to take a Leap into the Light.

After our project is successfully funded, Leap of Faith must meet the challenge of reaching out to the community to ensure that the professional lighting equipment not only serves its purpose to illuminate and enhance the performance but is also used to create opportunities for members of the community. 

Question: Who will light the stage to bring forth the choreographers' creative vision?

Answer: The supportive network of Leap of Faith families and the community at-large. 

This challenge sets the stage for Leap of Faith to become more tightly connected to the Central Ohio community. Parents and student volunteers will have an opportunity to use their theater production skills. Parents can help with equipment management, while local high school students may be invited to work directly with the Leap of Faith owner and artistic director to learn how to develop a lighting design and how to program intelligent lights from a lighting board. 

The only setback that could arise would be if the equipment was not delivered in time for the show. And if that turned out to be the case...

...the show would go on because dancing through every situation is what we do at Leap of Faith.

Our students (ages 3 1/2 to 73...and counting) learn more than choreography and dance terms.They experience the embrace of a community.We want to add another layer of education and experience.We want Leap of Faith dancers to experience what it's like to maneuver around a boom or choose fresnel lights and gels, or discern how the use of a scrim will affect the interpretation of a performance.As Leap of Faith celebrates its anniversary, we need professional lighting equipment so we can provide new educational performance opportunities for our dancers and present exciting dance productions to our audience.We want to take a Leap into the Light.After our project is successfully funded, Leap of Faith must meet the challenge of reaching out to the community to ensure that the professional lighting equipment not only serves its purpose to illuminate and enhance the performance but is also used to create opportunities for members of the community. Question: Who will light the stage to bring forth the choreographers' creative vision?Answer: The supportive network of Leap of Faith families and the community at-large. This challenge sets the stage for Leap of Faith to become more tightly connected to the Central Ohio community. Parents and student volunteers will have an opportunity to use their theater production skills. Parents can help with equipment management, while local high school students may be invited to work directly with the Leap of Faith owner and artistic director to learn how to develop a lighting design and how to program intelligent lights from a lighting board. The only setback that could arise would be if the equipment was not delivered in time for the show. And if that turned out to be the case......the show would go on because dancing through every situation is what we do at Leap of Faith.

story:
ANY CONTRIBUTIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE. PLEASE INCLUDE ADDRESS SO THAT WE CAN SEND YOU A DONATION LETTER.

 

 

Steep Theatre Company in association with Michael Padden
and The 37th Annual Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival present:


An exciting new play by a new voice in the American Theatre!

KATHLEEN TURNER'S EAR

Written by: Jonathan Edwards
Directed by: Alexandru Mihail
Production Designer: Kristen Robinson
Featuring: K. Todd Freeman and Danielle Skraastad
 

About Steep Theatre Company-Producer

Steep Theatre has become known as a home for hard-hitting, finely tuned ensemble work. With each production, the company has shepherded a growing community of audiences and stakeholders into bold new territories of story and performance. Over the years, Steep productions have been named to TimeOut Chicago's Top Ten Shows of the Year list five times, the Tribune's Top Ten List once, the Tribune's Best of the Fringe list twice, the Sun Times's best of the year list twice, and WBEZ's Top Ten Shows of the Decade. In six years of Jeff Eligibility, Steep has received 11 Jeff Nominations and has won the 2009 Jeff Award for Best Ensemble (In Arabia We'd All Be Kings), the 2010 Jeff Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role (Harper Regan), and the 2011 Jeff Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role (A Brief History of Helen of Troy). Steep was named the 2010 Broadway in Chicago Emerging Theatre Award Winner.

 

 

Help Steep Theatre Company bring this show to NYC.

If you contribute this is what you will receive:

 

  • $10-$25 donations receive a shout out on our facebook and twitter pages
  • $26-$50 donations receive the shout out and a Kathleen Turner's Ear button to wear.
  • $51-$100 donations receive the above and a signed Kathleen Turner's Ear postcard. Signed by some of the artists.
  • $101-$500 donations receive all of the above plus an invitation to a reception with the artists.
  • $500 and above receive 2 tickets to the performance of Kathleen Turner's Ear on Friday, October 26th @ 8pm plus all of the above. 

About the Samuel French OOB Festival


The Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival started in 1975 and is Manhattan’s oldest, continuous short play festival.  In the first 36 years of the Festival, over 500 theatre companies and schools participated. Applicants included companies from coast to coast as well as abroad from Canada, Singapore, and the United Kingdom.  The Festival has given emerging playwrights the opportunity to have their work produced with the support of such theatres as The Public Theater, The Royal Court, Ensemble Studio Theatre,  The Flea Theatre, The Living Theatre and Naked Angels, and with the backing of prestigious university playwriting programs such as The New School for Drama, Columbia University, University of Iowa, and Tisch School of the Arts’ Dramatic Writing Program.

The Festival has served as a doorway to future success for many aspiring playwrights, and has helped launched the work of notables as  Theresa Rebeck, Shirley Lauro, Sheila Callaghan, Bekah Brunstetter, Steve Yockey, Saviana Stanescu, and David Johnston.  In many cases, Festival participation has sparked agent contracts for Festival finalists and all of the final forty plays selected to be perform in New York are guaranteed to be seen by an Artistic Director of a major theater, a professional playwright, and a theatrical agent.  Many past Festival playwrights have gone on to win major Playwriting awards and honors, as well as to have major theatrical productions of their works staged.

How the Festival Works

The Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival is distinct in two ways: it requires applicants to collaborate with a producing organization and it offers a prize of publication in the notable OFF OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL PLAYS series.  Though many of the works that play in the Festival have been developed under the wing of theatres, universities, and writer’s groups, many of the plays that are produced as part of the Festival are world premieres.

The application period for the Festival begins in late December/early January and lasts until early March.  Playwrights may submit up to three unpublished plays that may be performed in 30 minutes or less.  On their application, playwrights must cite the organization that will produce their play (at this early stage it is often the playwright themselves) and a liaison for Samuel French to contact with Festival information. Submissions are whittled down by the Festival editorial staff, and the Final Forty are chosen to present their play during Festival week.

Festival week consists of 6 performance sessions  in which 6 to 7 scripts are presented in front of a judging panel comprised of an Artistic Director, an agent, and a professional playwright.  At the end of each session, the judges deliberate and 1 to 2 plays are selected to move on to the Festival Finals.  Finals take places of the last of day of the Festival.  During the Finals, the Festival staff will watch the final twelve to fourteen plays and select six authors to be a published in a the OFF OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL PLAYS series, which is published and licensed by Samuel French, Inc.

 


For more information about the Festival visit: http://oob.samuelfrench.com/index.php/about-2/


For more information about Steep Theatre Company visit: www.steeptheatre.com

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

You can purchase tickets to come see the show. Jonathan's session will be on Friday, October 26th @ 8pm. Tickets can be purchased by visiting:

http://www.telecharge.com/BehindTheCurtain.aspx?prodid=9254&mode=moreShowInfo


You can visit our facebook event page for more details:

https://www.facebook.com/events/517692684924143/

story:
Who We Are

Next In Line Productions LLC was created with the purpose of having an avenue for rising talents to showcase their abilities and, more importantly to take control of their own future in the world of Theatre here in New York City.  Frank McGuinness's Someone Who'll Watch Over Me is the start to that future.

What We're Doing

Someone Who'll Watch over Me is a play written by Irish dramatist Frank McGuinness. The play focuses on the trials and tribulations of an Irishman, an Englishman and an American (Edward, Michael and Adam) who are kidnapped and held hostage in Lebanon. As the three men strive for survival they also strive to overcome their personal and nationalistic differences. Related to this is each individual's own attempt to maintain sanity under the watchful eye of both captors and supposed comrades.

When and Where

August 29th, 2014 - September 6th, 2014

Gene Frankel Theatre 
24 Bond Street
New York, NY 10012 

Friday, August 29th @ 8pm
Saturday, August 30th @ 2pm and 8pm
Sunday, August 31th @ 1pm
Wednesday, September 3rd @ 8pm
Thursday, September 4th @ 8pm
Friday, September 5th @ 8pm
Saturday, September 6th @ 2 pm and 8pm

Tickets to go on sale AUGUST 1ST!


What We Need

Our Goal is to raise $10,000 by September 6th. While we are using our best abilities to keep the cost of the show at a minimal, additional funding allows the show to be designed and executed to the highest level possible, and would also allow us to provide conservative stipends to the artists who are dedicating their time to this show. Our breakdown is as follows:

Theatre Rental: $6000
Props and Costumes: $400
Sound, Lighting and Set: $1600
Artist Stipends: $1400
Publicity, Marketing, Online Promos: $600

Our Team

Director – Jesse Jou
Producer – Shiva Kalaiselvan and Tabia Lau
Dramaturgy – Lila Becker
Scenic / Lighting Design – Scott Mancha
Costume Design – Kristin Isola
Sound Design – Matt Otto
Production / Stage Manager – Jill Woodward
Poster Design – Eva Mlinar
Photos – Osber Photos and Kelly Stuart
Video – Black Box Productions
Dialect Coach – Bridget Ori


Featuring performances by:


John Garrett Greer*
Austin Jones*
Hardy Pinnell*


*Appearing Courtesy of Actors Equity Association.

Equity Showcase Approved.

story:
Summary

Judy Garland was described by Fred Astaire as "the greatest entertainer who ever lived." Having journeyed through a lifetime of professional triumphs and personal struggles, Judy left behind a legacy of lessons that are relatable to performers, like myself, and the public alike. My goal is not to fund an hour long concert featuring your average "impersonation" of Judy. As far as I'm concerned, equally Judy's "once in a lifetime" talent is an impossible feat. It is my dream to use my own individual voice to tell Judy's story, and the lessons I have posthumously learned from her legacy, through the most recognizable gift she left behind: her songs. This evening of entertainment will be designed to pay tribute to Judy's versatility and will include song, dance, and maybe a personal story or two.

Featuring: Brian Jones, Lauren Devine, and a special guest.

Songs to Include: Once in A Lifetime, Get Happy, The Man That Got Away, Down with Love, Zing! Went the Strings of My Heart, By Myself, Good Morning, Ballin' the Jack, The Trolley Song, Over the Rainbow, and MANY more...

Date: December 19 @ The Duplex (70 Seat Off Broadway Cabaret Space- West Village NYC)

Contributors will provide resources to make the following possible:

  • Renting Performance Space
  • Renting Rehearsal Space
  • Compensating Pianist for Accompaniment and Music Arrangement Services
  • Compensating Guest Artists
  • Compensating a Videographer
  • Publicity
  • Costuming

What We Need & What You Get

 

Funding Goal: $2800

Your contribution to this campaign will create an invaluable opportunity for my guest performers and I to pay tribute to a music, film, and theatre legend, as well as express our own unique voice and stories to the New York City public and professional theatre community. As a dreamer and entertainer myself, I know that it is a rare  and valuable opportunity to have the chance to perform material that I love, while being a (as a famous Judy Garland quote puts it) "first rate version of myself." This is both a labor of love, and an opportunity for career advancement as I present an uncensored, uncut version of myself to an audience that includes friends, family, and perhaps members of the professional theatre production and casting community.

***PLEASE SEE THE PERKS ASSOCIATED WITH DIFFERENT DONATION LEVELS


  • If the funding goal is not reached, funds will go towards producing whatever version of "Once in a Lifetime: The Songs of Judy Garland" is financially feasible. Funds will first be applied to securing space and equipment, and then be applied to other aspects of the production (as listed above) at the producer's discretion.
  • If more funds are raised than requested, the additional resources will be used to increase production quality and actor salaries.

Risks & Challenges

 Producing theatre is a difficult challenge in New York City for the following reasons:

  • The expense of securing reputable spaces well suited to material
  • Fairly Compensating Actors, Singers, and Dancers
  • Fairly compensating skilled musicians/arrangers
  • Fairly compensating production staff, so as to ensure a high quality production
  • The necessity and high cost of publicity, and managing the risk of creating  sustainable audience attendance

Together, we can create an environment in which beautiful, grass-roots work grounded in passion is POSSIBLE in New York City!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If can't contribute,  that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Share our Indegogo campaign!
    • Share our event with your family and friends!
    • Buy tickets to see our production!

    Make ADVANCED Ticket Reservations HERE: http://www.theduplex.com/~thedup/webcalendar/view_entry.php?id=8796&date=20141219

story:
Hi, I am Jack Wernick, a playwright who is about to have his first play produced. Thank you for stopping by.

 

I am very excited to have had my play “Destination Wedding” accepted at the Midtown International Theatre Festival in New York in July. It is an honor to have been chosen for the festival. I have been working on getting this play produced for several months, and soon that dream will become a reality. But first, I need your help in realizing my dream!

 

The script is completed, director Cedric Hill is at the helm, and a talented cast featuring David Rossetti has been assembled. Rehearsals are ready to begin!

 

As we only recently received news of the festival acceptance, we are understandably eager to help cover the expense of mounting a production in a matter of weeks. That’s where we’re hoping you can step in and help us produce this wonderful play!

 

Your contribution, whatever the amount, will make a big difference!

 

Destination Wedding by Jack Wernick will appear at the Midtown International Theatre Festival from July 24-28, 2012.

 

www.midtownfestival.org

 

What We Need

 

Our budget is designed to cover the following expenses to ensure a professional production:

 

  • Props
  • Set construction
  • Labor
  • Actors           
  • Projection
  • Sound design
  • Lighting design
  • Stage manager
  • Publicity
  • Director

 

 

The Impact

 

This festival production is not only an opportunity to present the play, but an opportunity for the actors and writer to gain exposure through press coverage and reviews. Our goal is to connect with theater producers who will share our enthusiasm for this play and decide to produce it Off-Broadway, as well as at theaters in other major cities. This exposure will offer the creative team the opportunity to work on future theater projects together, as well as allow the writer to pursue his dream of establishing his own theater company.

 

This production could also lead to agent representation for the writer, as well as further opportunities, credibility, and visibility for the actors, director, and writer.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Even if you can’t contribute, you can help us!

 

Help spread the word by using the IndieGoGo Share Tools.

 

Follow us on Facebook at:

 

www.facebook.com/pages/Destination-Wedding/281146915307721

 

Follow us on Twitter at: https://twitter.com/DestinationWedn

 

Thank you!

 

From Jack Wernick, Cedric Hill, and David Rossetti; we thank you so very much!

story:
#BringBackTheState

The London State Theater, built 79 years ago in 1936 in historic downtown London, Ohio, received a major facelift in 2010 by George Peyton. 
But only two years after Mr. Peyton re-opened the theater, technology changed. Movies aren’t distributed on film anymore. 

To keep running, The State needed a new digital projector. 

With everything George had already put into fixing up the State, the new projector was just one expense too many, and the theater closed in January of 2013.

Since the theater closed, the theater's roof has a sprung a few leaks. Portions of the ceiling plaster have collapsed from where water pooled. 

There's no structural danger, but every expert we've had on the roof agrees that the roof needs to be replaced.

We are raising $70,000 to re-open The State Theater in London. It’s just a portion of the budget we need to get the place up and running again but It’ll go a long way into helping us install a digital projector with crystal-clear picture, and a roof that won't leak.

Your contribution, no matter the size, tells us that we’re not alone in believing that downtown London needs to bring fun back!
With your help, the State can be THE place to see first-run blockbuster movies, go on dates, visit with friends, and take the family.

What We Need

• Priority one: a projector
Movies come as computer files now, and are played on digital projectors. The files are a proprietary format that protects the movie industry from piracy. Only three projector manufacturers (Christie, Sony, and NEC) make projectors capable of showing movies in the format sent for first-run movies.

We're looking to buy an NEC digital projector; a new, brighter, shinier screen - and having these professionally installed. The price to do so should cost about $40,000 to $43,000.

• Priority two: a new roof

We'd like people to be able to watch movies without needing an umbrella.

The roof has been patched so many times, that estimates for a temporary roof fix are nearly as much as the estimates for replacing the entire roof. 

We project the roof replacement to cost between $27,000 and $30,000.


We've set our fundraising goal at $40,000. We'll open with a tarp on our roof if we have to. But we're hoping to raise $70,000 right off the bat. 


Who We Are

We're the Treynor family. We already live and work in the heart of London. Rob worked for years with The Madison Press and still contributes regularly. Shannon has a law office on North Main, just a few doors from the courthouse.

We have two kids at London Middle School and one at London High School. Between them, they represent London in track, golf, baseball and band. Our two sons are Boy Scouts in London's troop 102. Our daughter is a regular altar server at London's Saint Patrick Church. 


Because London is our home, we want to help revitalize downtown London and make it a destination for kids, teens, adults and seniors. 


The Plan

We would love to run this movie theater. We think this would be a great family business and a real asset to downtown London and the greater London community as a whole. 

We want to attract new business and bring life back to our main street – so people want to be here.

There’s a serious lack of venues where folks can go on dates or  to meet with friends in this town. Bringing a destination back to downtown London will go a long way to revitalizing the city.

Our plan is to upgrade the concession offerings to include gourmet meal  and snack options, beer, wine, and also the traditional premium movie fare of popcorn and candy.

We're also looking to start a semiannual local filmmaker's festival: Where Madison County residents' YouTube videos are showcased on the big screen, and the best are rewarded prizes and bragging rights.


What You Get

Not only will your financial contribution be the first step in helping downtown London become a vibrant and attractive destination again, you also can get some cool perks and swag as a thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help

What makes London so special of a community is the willingness for people to invest in their city. 

That's why we're confident that you'll understand that having a working movie theater in downtown London is an investment in our town's future. Having a destination downtown is a magnet that will attract other businesses and retail establishments.  

But we understand not everyone can invest with their pocketbook. But maybe you know someone who can. It costs you nothing to spread the news that the State Theater wants to re-open. Share this indiegogo campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter page (use hashtag #BringBackTheState) Harass your wealthy uncle into contributing.  Ride your bike down the street at 6 a.m. while shouting our URL.

Together, we can make this happen!
story_txt:
#BringBackTheState
The London State Theater, built 79 years ago in 1936 in historic downtown London, Ohio, received a major facelift in 2010 by George Peyton. 
But only two years after Mr. Peyton re-opened the theater, technology
changed. Movies aren’t distributed on film anymore. 


To keep running, The State needed a new digital projector. 

With everything George had already put into
fixing up the State, the new projector was just one expense too many, and the
theater closed in January of 2013.
Since the theater closed, the theater's roof has a sprung a few leaks. Portions of the ceiling plaster have collapsed from where water pooled. 
There's no structural danger, but every expert we've had on the roof agrees that the roof needs to be replaced.

We are raising $70,000 to re-open The State Theater in London.
It’s just a portion of the budget we need to get the place up and running
again but It’ll go a long way into helping us install a digital projector with
crystal-clear picture, and a roof that won't leak.
 
Your contribution, no matter the size, tells us
that we’re not alone in believing that downtown London needs to bring fun back!
With your help, the State can be THE place to see first-run blockbuster movies, go on dates, visit with friends, and take the family.  What We Need • Priority one: a projectorMovies come as computer files now, and are played on digital projectors. The files are a proprietary format that protects the movie industry from piracy. Only three projector manufacturers (Christie, Sony, and NEC) make projectors capable of showing movies in the format sent for first-run movies.
We're looking to buy an NEC digital projector; a new, brighter, shinier screen - and having these professionally installed. The price to do so should cost about $40,000 to $43,000.
• Priority two: a new roof
We'd like people to be able to watch movies without needing an umbrella.
The roof has been patched so many times, that estimates for a temporary roof fix are nearly as much as the estimates for replacing the entire roof. 
We project the roof replacement to cost between $27,000 and $30,000.

We've set our fundraising goal at $40,000. We'll open with a tarp on our roof if we have to. But we're hoping to raise $70,000 right off the bat.   


Who We Are
We're the Treynor family. We already live and work in the heart of London. Rob worked for years with The Madison Press and still contributes regularly. Shannon has a law office on North Main, just a few doors from the courthouse.
We have two kids at London Middle School and one at London High School. Between them, they represent London in track, golf, baseball and band. Our two sons are Boy Scouts in London's troop 102. Our daughter is a regular altar server at London's Saint Patrick Church. 



Because London is our home, we want to help revitalize downtown London and make it a destination for kids, teens, adults and seniors.

We would love to run this movie theater. We think
this would be a great family business and a real asset to downtown London and
the greater London community as a whole.

bring life back to our main street – so
people want to be here.

There’s a serious
lack of venues where folks can go on dates or  to
meet with friends in this town. Bringing a destination back to downtown London will go a long way to revitalizing the city.
Our plan is to upgrade the concession offerings to include gourmet meal  and snack options, beer, wine, and also the traditional premium movie fare of popcorn and candy.
We're also looking to start a semiannual local filmmaker's festival: Where Madison County residents' YouTube videos are showcased on the big screen, and the best are rewarded prizes and bragging rights.


What You Get
Not only will your financial contribution be the first step in helping downtown London become a vibrant and attractive destination again, you also can get some cool perks and swag as a thank you.



    Other Ways You Can Help
What makes London so special of a community is the willingness for people to invest in their city. 
That's why we're confident that you'll understand that having a working movie theater in downtown London is an investment in our town's future. Having a destination downtown is a magnet that will attract other businesses and retail establishments.  
But we understand not everyone can invest with their pocketbook. But maybe you know someone who can. It costs you nothing to spread the news that the State Theater wants to re-open. Share this indiegogo campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter page (use hashtag #BringBackTheState) Harass your wealthy uncle into contributing.  Ride your bike down the street at 6 a.m. while shouting our URL.
Together, we can make this happen!

story:
Airdance, the Philippines’ premiere contemporary dance company, is proud to announce that two of their choreographers: JED AMIHAN and NICOLE PRIMERO will be representing the country as they pursue artistic endeavors abroad, in prestigious dance programs.

ARTIST PROFILES

Airdance Associate Artistic Director JED AMIHAN was chosen for the International Young Choreographer Project in Kaohsiung, Taiwan - a project of World Dance Alliance - Asia Pacific and Americas, this July 5-25, 2015. Jed has been member of Airdance since 2005. He has also performed in and choreographed numerous pieces for Airdance, such as in the Wi_Fi Contemporary Dance Festival and Fringe Arts Festival Manila. He has performances in musicals, TV shows and Independent Dance Film production. Jed was most recently in the C-MAP program for choreographers held in Bacolod, and is also the school director for Airdance. Jed continues to hone his craft as a choreographer as he creates pieces not just for the company, but for other dance schools and universities as well.

NICOLE PRIMERO, meanwhile was chosen for the DanceWeb Europe Scholarship Program, part of the Impulstanz Festival in Vienna, Austria, which is from July 15-August 19, 2015. In 2008, she was recognized as the Most Promising young choreographer in the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival’s New Choreographers Competition. Since then she has continued to explore her work, delving into her rich literature background, using research and reading as driving forces for her choreographic experiments. She is also a contributing writer for the Cultural Center of the Philippines Encyclopedia for the Arts.

Both Jed and Nicole still need assistance for airfare and living expenses, since these will not be provided by their respective programs. 

SEND-OFF SHOW:  "FOREWORD | FOREWARD"

Come and lend your support to Jed Amihan and Nicole Primero, as they stage their pieces in a send-off and fundraising show, entitiled "FOREWORD | FORWARD", this June 20, 2015 at the Airdance Studio. Tickets are at 200 pesos, but guests are more than welcome to contribute more, to assist Jed and Nicole with living expenses and airfare.

We hope that this endeavour will create awareness and give support to Filipino dance artists.

For more information, you can check out the Airdance website www.airdance.com.ph, or email info@airdance.com.ph. Contact us at 0916-3566693 or 414-5279.  

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Help us make some and noise and spread the word! Share this through Indiegogo, through your social media accounts, or by word of mouth! Every little bit of help counts!

story:
Our Story: ASHANI DANCES is a Seattle-based dance company founded in the summer of 2011 by artistic director, Iyun Harrison. The focus of the company is to create collaborative art with 'emerging' designers, visual artists, composers, musicians and actors. ASHANI DANCES is concert dance as a total theatrical experience.
 
Our Reason for Being: We are committed to providing a place where exceptionally talented young dancers  can receive the guidance and support necessary to transition from the pre-professional stage to becoming a rounded professional. We also are committed to helping gifted young choreographers deepen their creative practice by providing professional opportunities to produce and present their work.

Why We Need Your Help: Ashani Dances needs to raise $5,000.00 to help us get our first production up and running. Your contributions will go directly to paying for our theater rental at the Erickson Theater on Capitol Hill in Seattle, paying our 12 fantastic dancers, collaborators, costume and lighting designers, to make costumes and pay for rehearsal space rental. No contribution is too small.
