The fan man
or how to dress an elephant
Help us to make the performance.
Help us to make an untold story to be told.

The topic of the performanceThe topic of this performance “ the fan man or how to dress an elephant” is human difference: Either how each individual perceives himself as different or how society influences and is influenced by or reacts to something considered different. On stageOn stage we will witness a series of everyday events seen from a poetic perspective. This perspective will  both shed light on an event that can be seen from a different angle and will bridge the audience with what so far can not be said or can not be expressed. 
These brief acts  are characterised by the need to express the real, the specific, the subjective, the situations that the heroes experience. The process of the performance
The process of the performance does not depend on a pre-existent dramaturgy. 
On the contrary the final text will come from the creative participation of the members of the group through written and oral work as well as improvisations. Each member participates actively to the performance with his/her own personal contribution. Moreover exploring the abilities and the expressive means of every member, we aim to show that performable-something that can be staged- is not only the common, but also the different and the uncommon. 

The integration of mentally challenged people:
Group membership and cooperative work lead to these peoples' development both on a social and individual level as they have to take initiatives. Because the rehearsals  
have equal demands from every participant, they become more active as they feel they won't be judged as individuals but as a team. Their enthusiasm about sharing the responsibility for what is to be performed, is gradually becoming discipline and consistency, as to reach the final goal is not easy and requires hard work. Also the fact that they' re asked to express their opinion on the work they have to do, helps them share thoughts, fears and dreams and therefore it makes them more communicative.

En Dynamei "Diverse Potential"En Dynamei (‘Diverse Potential') is an organization based in Thessaloniki, Greece, which
includes young people with intellectual disabilities, volunteers, parents and friends.
Founded in 2008, the group was born from the overwhelming need to share and express
personal stories through the prism of artistic expression. En Dynamei exists to facilitate
exploration into the undiscovered sources of creativity as well as integration of its
members into the wider social environment. The group organizes, develops and
promotes a variety of educational, social, artistic and cultural activities, collaborating with
major organizations in Thessaloniki. The members coexist within a community focusing
on establishing a symbiosis of interpersonal relationships and identifying and developing
the individual skills and interests of each person.
The ultimate goal of En
Dynamei is to challenge the
conventional interpretation of
what is ‘different’ or
‘unfamiliar’ in the arts and to
embrace diversity in the
modern era. Drawing together
people from mixed
backgrounds, En Dynamei
utilizes the artistic process
(theatre, film, music, visual
arts) to create a common
ground for experimental
creation and communication
through its fluid and daring language. The artistic medium becomes the meeting point
that breaks down the prejudices and barriers between audience and that which is
‘different.En Dynamei is working towards ‘a place’ where:
• living an everyday life amongst passionate and devoted people is a daily source
of inspiration and an encouragement towards excellence
• holistic expression and creative integration using art is an answer to the question
‘Who am I really?’
• art becomes the common ground to meet with original ideas, thoughts and
feelings, through color, touch, words, shapes, sound, rhythm, movement
and….life.Contact:
Eleni Dimopoulou, Theatre Actress/Director
Co-Founder of En Dynameielenidimopoulou0@gmail.com

story:
We here at CAGE Theatre Company is proud to bring back one of our favorite shows, a story of heroes, villains, dragons, monsters, and princesses!, and we absolutely need your help!

Were you a fan of old school Nintendo?

Maybe you played D & D growing up?  (Or maybe you still do!)

Maybe you like stage combat, girls in corsets, loads of comedy and love triumphant?!

Quest of the Hero is ALMOST BACK and we will make it better than ever!

Our budget has the following breakdown:

$500 - Rehearsal Space (because when you see the amazing swordplay, you'll see how much room we needed!)

$400 - Costumes (heroes gotta have their tunics, villains gotta have their claws!)

$400 - Set (wait 'til you see how we change location like a video game)

$250 - Festival fees and marketing (ad space, playbills, postcards, and everything else to spread the word!)

$250 - Props (there's books, bottles, bows, bo staffs, and beyond to buy!)

$200 - Misc. Expenses and Repairs (because sometimes things happen)

Our perks below are top notch, and we believe that every little bit helps!  Don't be afraid to take part in the creation of the next new and exciting theatre show, The Quest of the Hero!

In addition, Quest of the Hero! will help with supporting Safe Horizons.  Safe Horizon is the nation’s leading victim assistance organization and touches the lives of more than 250,000 affected by crime and abuse each year. Whether we are responding to child abuse, domestic violence, or other violent crimes, we help victims and their families heal and rebuild their lives.

Safe Horizon takes action by providing practical services like a new lock, 24-hour hotlines, safe shelter, and food as well as supportive services like mental health counseling. Our dedicated staff offers compassionate, expert support, helping victims find hope by offering a chance to tell their story in their own words, a guide through the criminal justice system, and a safe place to sleep.

Any money above our goal we'll be donating to help keep their services available.  And keep a lookout, as we're looking for new ideas to spread their message!

Below is information on the show.  Take a look, and maybe you'll want to come and see us!  Thanks for reading!

Tickets $18. For tickets visit http://www.planetconnections.org

C.A.G.E Theatre Company is pleased to present THE QUEST OF THE HERO!, written and directed by Michael Hagins, as part of the 6th Annual Planet Connections Theatre Festivity. The Festivity will take place May 12th through June 8th at the Paradise Factory, 64 E. 4th St., New York, NY!

THE QUEST OF THE HERO!

Save the princess.  Be a Hero.  Get Laid.

#choosequest

Chester doesn't want to be the hero, but he's the son of a legendary one. On his father's insistance, he embarks on a quest to save a princess... which is a lot harder than it sounds. He must discern between friend and foe, truth and lies, good conversation and bad jokes, and find those who really do need to be saved. Will he be the HERO? And willl he ever get LAID?

The production stars Christian Sochor as Chester, Vanessa Wendt as Princess Zelga, and Scott Janneke as Mushroom.  Narrated by Adam Baritot

Featuring Ian Heitzmann, Matthew Velez, Xavier Rodney, Sam Lopresti, Michael Rehse, Chelsea Rowe, Sonia Hebé, Molly Way, Laura Snell*, Chris Morrell, Rebecca R. Overholt, and Rachel Collins.

*These actors are appearing courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association. 

The Quest of the Hero! plays the following schedule as part of the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity:

Dates:

Sun, May 18th@3:00pm(Show 1) 

Wed, May 21st@2:00pm(Show 2) 

Mon, May 26th@8:30pm(Show 3) 

Tue, May 27th@3:00pm(Show 4) 

Wed, June 4th@8:30pm(Show 5) 

Sat, June 7th  @1:30pm(Show 6)

story:
The annual Off-Broadway performance event for emerging and established choreographers.

Choreographer's Canvas is a platform for emerging and established choreographers to showcase their work Off-Broadway to industry professionals and the general public. The concept of the Canvas stemmed from Twyla Tharp's book "The Creative Habit", where she writes:

"I walk into a large white room. It's a dance studio in midtown Manhattan. To some people, this empty room symbolizes something profound, mysterious, and terrifying: the task of starting with nothing and working your way toward creating something whole and beautiful and satisfying. It's no different for a writer rolling a fresh sheet of paper into this typewriter (or more likely firing up the blank screen on his computer), or a painter confronting a virginal canvas, a sculptor staring at a raw chunk of stone, a composer at the piano with his fingers hovering just above the keys. Some people find this moment - the moment before creativity begins - so painful that they simply cannot deal with it. They get up a walk away from the canvas." 

Our company wanted to create an event and environment where choreographers would feel encouraged, supported and excited about presenting new work.  We also wanted to reach our to all the different kinds of choreographers from film to Broadway to opera to music videos who might benefit from this experience.

Through annual submissions, a panel of dance professionals chooses 15 to 20 cutting-edge choreographers from around the world in all styles including tap, ballet, theatre dance, jazz, hip-hop, modern, lyrical, contemporary, aerial, ballroom, Middle Eastern, swing and more. For the past 6 years the Canvas has presented over 65 choreographers, giving performance opportunity to over 450 dancers to sold out shows! The choreographers participate in the Canvas free of charge and are provided with the performance venue, technical designers, as well as all of the marketing and promotional materials.

With this comes it’s challenges, but you can help! One of the most daunting tasks for this event is fundraising. Since 2008 the Canvas has been funded by The Group Theatre Too with marketing support from Broadway Dance Center, Capezio, Society of Stage Directors & Choreographers, and Manhattan Movement and Arts Center. Every year, we are tasked with obtaining the start-up capital to cover the theater rental, promotional materials, and technical requirements. Your support through Indiegogo is necessary to keep this incredible program growing and giving choreographers "a large white room" to create their next great piece of art.

One of the unique challenges of the Canvas is that it all takes place in one day! Fortunately we have a great team of organized leaders who run a tight ship. We are lucky that this project has been running for the past six years, so needless to say we have learned from our past experience. Also, with the correct funding, we can add more hands-on-deck to work backstage and behind the scenes making the experience optimal for the choreographers, dancers and audience members.

We are also expanding the Canvas to other cities and this past year successfully produced the first Nashville Choreographer's Canvas in conjunction with Lipscomb University.  Watch below for coverage from the event:

begins - so painful that they simply cannot deal with it.  They get up a walk 
away from the canvas."  
Our company wanted to create an event and environment where choreographers would feel encouraged, supported and excited about presenting new work.  We also wanted to reach our to all the different kinds of choreographers from film to Broadway to opera to music videos who might benefit from this experience. Through annual submissions, a panel of dance professionals chooses 15 
to 20 cutting-edge choreographers from around the world in all styles including 
tap, ballet, theatre dance, jazz, hip-hop, modern, lyrical, contemporary, 
aerial, ballroom, Middle Eastern, swing and more.   For the past 6 years the 
Canvas has presented over 65 choreographers, giving performance opportunity to 
over 450 dancers to sold out shows! The choreographers participate in the Canvas
 
free of charge and are provided with the performance venue, technical 
designers, as well as all of the marketing and promotional materials.

With this comes it’s 
challenges, but you can help!  One of the most daunting tasks for this event is 
fundraising.  Since 2008 the Canvas has been funded by The Group Theatre Too with marketing support from Broadway Dance Center, 
Capezio, Society of Stage Directors & Choreographers, and Manhattan Movement 
and Arts Center. Every year, we are tasked with obtaining the start-up capital to cover 
the theater rental, promotional materials, and technical requirements.  Your support through Indiegogo is 
necessary to keep this incredible program growing and 
giving choreographers "a large white room" to create their next great piece of 
art. 






One of the unique challenges of the Canvas is that it all takes place in
 one day!  Fortunately we have a great team of organized leaders who run
 a tight ship.  We are lucky that this project has been running for the 
past six years, so needless to say we have learned from our past 
experience.  Also, with the correct funding, we can add more 
hands-on-deck to work backstage and behind the scenes making the 
experience optimal for the choreographers, dancers and audience members.We are also expanding the Canvas to other cities and this past year successfully produced the first Nashville Choreographer's Canvas in conjunction with Lipscomb University.  Watch below for coverage from the event:

story:
Who are we?

We are a group of young artists looking to make a difference in our world. After doing the show once with some success we wanted to do the show a second time to allow more people to come to see it.

What We Need & What You Get

We need 500 dollars in order to obtain the rights for the show and get the technical elements for it. If you support the campaign you could receive a signed playbill, a custom made poster from the show and even a sit down with the director and executive producer to discuss the show. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word to your friends and come out and see the show when we open!

Want more info?

Check out our Facebook page for more information, the dates of the show and some pictures from the original performance. https://www.facebook.com/PPASProductionOfDogSee...

story:
Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theatre's 2013 season began last July with Artistic Director Vit Horejs teaching directors from all over the world to play with puppets at La MaMa Umbria in the gorgeous Italian countryside. This summer the company also performed in Montauk, Southampton and in libraries and parks in New York City's five boroughs. 

And, only weeks after the U.S. government ground to halt, we look forward to sharing with you the twenty-four-hundred-year old constitution critique that is the basis for our new play, THE REPUBLIC, or, MY DINNER WITH SOCRATES.  Is democracy not the ideal form of government?  Was Socrates executed by a vigilant Athenian "department of homeland security?"  The play may not answer these questions, but we hope to open a dialogue in a true Socratic method. 

THE REPUBLIC will premiere on November 29 presented in La MaMa's Fall 2013 Season, and run for three weeks. We want you to be part of the action as an audience member and supporter, and in post performance discussions. 

We have a cast of 6 actors, 50 marionettes and dozens of shadow puppets.  The live music is by Clifton Hyde, set design by Tom Lee, marionettes by Jakub “Kuba” Krejci and Milos Kasal, and shadow puppets and costumes by Theresa Linnihan.

Cast members are Deborah Beshaw-Farrell, Christopher Broholm, Vit Horejs,  Theresa Linnihan, Jonathan Mastrojohn, and Alan Netherton.

Rehearsals began in September and we need your help to bring the play to the stage. Help us raise $2,644 toward the total budget of $34,500.

Save the date:

THE REPUBLIC, OR, MY DINNER WITH SOCRATES

LA MAMA, 74 East 4th Street, New York City

Nov 29-Dec 15 2013 / Thursdays--Saturdays. at 7:30 PM, Sundays at 3:00 PM 


All donations to The Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theater (CAMT) are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by the law. (CAMT is a program of GOH Productions, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization.)

Please view the video of some of our recent work and rehearsal photos to get an idea of what we are known for in the world of innovative puppetry!

story:
Our Story

Bobby Hot Stuff is an improv comedy group from Los Angeles comprised of players with training backgrounds from iO West (formerly named Improv Olympic West) and Upright Citizens Brigade Los Angeles. We specialize in performing a variety of forms in repertory.

For the last four years, Bobby Hot Stuff has produced, booked, and hosted a night of improv comedy in Hollywood every Friday night in The Loft at iO West. BHS founded and hosts the Annual Slacker Festival in the fall at iO West, and they have been featured selections for the last three years at the L.A. Improv Comedy Festival.

This year, for the first time, we have been invited to perform at the San Francisco Improv Festival on Thursday, August 25th. BHS will perform a modified Slacker (an form of long form improv) they created called a Memento Slacker (loosely inspired by the film MEMENTO).

Cast: Aaron Bendele, Jonathan Flanagan, Bernard Hyland, Echo Kellum, Lydia Nelsen, Patrick Stubbins and Jonathan Townsager. Coached by Bridget Kloss-Dario.

The Impact

Many of you reading this are improvisers, so you know that we don't get paid for doing our shows. For the rest of you "civilians", in addition to not getting paid (we do it for the thrill of performing in front of a live audience), there are expenses that come with being an improv group. Each of us pay our coach and room rental fees (approx. $50/month per person), as well as the cost of promoting our weekly show (printing show posters monthly, approx. $30/month total). In other words, without your generous donations we will have to pay for the entire trip out of pocket, possibly cutting the length of our stay in San Francisco short.

What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign goal is $550. Here's how our budget needs break down:

$250 for gas for two cars and parking. We calculated our gas costs on Mapquest, rounding up for construction/detours/parking fees).

$267.80 for our hotel room for two nights in the Hotel Carlton. We selected it for it's proximity to the performance venue, it's in a safe neighborhood and they offered a great deal to SFIF Performers.


That brings the trip cost to $517.80. We rounded up to $550 to cover the fees for the campaign (Indiegogo and credit card processors). We would love to raise more than that, it would allow us to possibly expand into two rooms and have a small per diem for food.

If we don't reach our goal, your donations will still go to our campaign. Unlike a campaign on Kickstarter, all of your donations go to us regardless of whether or not we hit our goal. However, if we do not reach our fund-raising goal, Indiegogo takes 9% of the funds raised instead of 4%. In addition to our campaign on Indiegogo, we're also raising funds the old fashioned way: passing a hat every Friday night during our show until the Festival.


Now for the fun part! We are offering perks for your donations.

Here are some highlights with links:

$100 (2 total) - A headshot/photo session/publicity photo shoot from Paper-Machete by Aaron Bendele, photographer and cast member of Bobby Hot Stuff. Click the link above for more examples of his work.

$60 (2 total) - 2 Flights Each at iFly Hollywood (a $120 value). Our own Jonathan Townsager is an indoor skydiving instructor and he can teach you the thrill of skydiving in a safe, controlled environment at Universal Studios Citywalk.

$40 (2 total) - Poster Graphic Design. BHS cast member Aaron Bendele does most of the graphic design for Bobby Hot Stuff's monthly show posters. Click here for a link to past BHS posters designed by Aaron.


Note: Some of you may wish to donate but don't want a "perk" in return. You can donate as little or as much as you want, and Indiegogo accepts donations through PayPal or by credit card. Indiegogo also accepts anonymous donations.


Other Ways You Can Help

Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Indiegogo makes it easy to quickly share this campaign on all of your favorite social networking sites. Just click on the Share Tools directly under the video on this page. This helps us track how well we are promoting the campaign.

Thank you in advance for spreading the word about our little campaign! Remember, if you are as broke as we are and can't afford to donate, it costs nothing to spread the word!

story:
Who We Are ...

Scapegoat Garden is a Hartford-based collaborative dance theater, driven to create daring, interdisciplinary performance that goes in through the nose, eyes, skin, ears and mouth to stir those who witness or participate. Scapegoat Garden seeks to exemplify Hartford's innovative, high quality professional dance theater and to contribute to the ongoing evolution of contemporary dance as a viable American art form. The company strives to forge relationships with artists and communities, helping people see, create and contribute to a greater vision of ourselves, each other and our city.

Founded by Hartford-native Deborah Goffe in 2002, and established as a non-profit 501(c)(3) arts organization in 2004, Scapegoat Garden conjures lush worlds where dynamic movement, sound, images, garments, environment, food and drink are sourced for their ability to illuminate the human experience. The company's repertory has been selected for performance in festivals and venues throughout the region including: Hartford’s Charter Oak Cultural Center, the Wadsworth Atheneum, the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven, Provincetown Dance Festival, Boston Center for the Arts, Bates Dance Festival in Maine, New York City’s Raw Material Performance Series at Dance New Amsterdam, DUMBO Dance Festival, Artists of Tomorrow Festival, and Fridays at Noon at the 92nd Street Y. 

Scapegoat Garden's current team of core collaborators includes: Jennifer Cormier, Leslie Frye Maietta and Katie Jackson Cook.

Where We Call Home ...

garden: a place where humans define, initiate and interact with form to create a specialized environment.

Since March 2011, The Garden Center for Contemporary Dance has served as Scapegoat Garden's home - a laboratory for creative process, performance and community engagement. In addition to its function as our rehearsal and office space, this beautiful, light-filled room in Hartford's Parkville neighborhood is also an ideal space to create and display the company's rich visual landscape.

In the last year, we've hosted a number of community gatherings, classes & workshops, discussions related to the dance field and the role of the audience as collaborator, and works-in-progress showings for local dance-makers. Last fall we began a series of salon performances in the space, inviting small groups of invited guests to experience the intimacy of live interactive performance. And this spring we've introduced an Artist-in-Residence program where two local dance-makers are able to able to access rehearsal space, feedback on works in progress, performance opportunities, and a supportive network of peers.

Through the growing sense of place and community fostered by these activities, we are excited to further explore the company's hospitality aesthetic, discovering the place where artistic expression and old fashioned hospitality meet.

Why Now Is The Time

2012 marks the 10th anniversary of Scapegoat Garden and we've set some big goals for ourselves this year.  Rather than giving our attention to a series of lavish public celebrations (although we do reserve the right to party at some point - and you'll be invited), we believe our energies would be best directed to firming the company's foundation.

We invite you to celebrate with us by offering a financial contribution. Scapegoat Garden's mission of collaboration is fulfilled, in part, by the sustenance we receive from people and organizations outside the studio. We have never been more in need of your help as we work to grow more rooted in these challenging economic times. We welcome your support and participation at any level, and thank you in advance for all the ways you will help sustain the work of the Scapegoat Garden. Every dollar counts.  We are grateful to count you among our collaborators.

What We Need and What You Get

Our goal is to raise $8000 to cover rent and insurance for our beloved space, and to the allay some of the cost of Garden Center events.

Scapegoat Garden is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization, making USD contributions tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.  And in return for your generous contribution, you will receive a place of honor on our website's donor wall.  Depending on how much you give, you can also receive a seat of honor at a future salon event at The Garden Center.  The more you give, the bigger the role you can play in the configuration of an upcoming salon event.  Bring a friend, bring a piece of the work home with you, host your own salon evening, or sponsor a month of programing in your name at The Garden Center.

salon: a lively coming together of people from varied segments of the community, gathered under one roof by an inspired host, to share art, ideas, and conversation.

How You Can Help

With your dollars and your word, you can place a vote for the expressive power of the moving body and the collective power of the collaborative process.  Your word-of-mouth power is an essential component in the success of this campaign ... and that of the cultural eco-system wherever you live.  So, please PASS THE WORD ... tell it, email it, share it, post it, tweet it ... dance it!

story:
Our Story

Malashock Dance has moved beyond the 'single choreographer model and now incorporates the artistic voices of Associate Artistic Director Michael Mizerany and invited guest artists from throughout our region. This year, we look beyond the US to develop an artistic partnership with dance company Lux Boreal, based in Tijuana, for Malashock/RAW 2! RAW, a favorite with critics and audiences alike, returns for its second year featuring all new choreography by John Malashock, Michael Mizerany and guest choreographers Henry Torres and
Angel Arambula, artistic directors of Lux Boreal. Malashock/RAW 2 will be more provocative and cutting edge than ever before! Producer Michael Mizerany again promises that boundaries will be pushed and lines will be crossed in this exciting, not to be missed evening of dance.


The Impact

Malashock Dance is committed to providing paid professional opportunities for both dancers and choreographers. This year Malashock/RAW 2 features 2 guest choreographers from Tijuana and 11 dancers (3 Malashock Dance Company members & 8 guest artists). Your generosity will directly support these artists!


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise a minimum of $5,000 to help cover the costs of paying our dancers and guest choreographers. As with all artistic productions, ticket sales only cover a small portion of costs, which is why we need you! Your contribution will help us get this production from the page to the stage (The Forum Theater at the La Jolla Playhouse), and provide paid opportunities for the artists in our community.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word! Please share our campaign with your friends. Every little bit helps, and together, we can make our goal a reality! 


AND... Ok, Ok, Ok. Get this - we're gonna GIVE you cool stuff for less than a sentence worth of your words! RAW 2 is coming and we want YOU to help with a tagline! 4 runners-up will each receive a FREE dance class ($15) and the grand prize winner will receive two FREE tickets to RAW 2's reception/opening night ($80!) on Oct. 20, as well as their name in the OFFICIAL PROGRAM! Become our fan on facebook to learn more. http://www.facebook.com/malashockdance DEADLINE: September 6

story:
Short Summary

This is a play I have been working on for two years, and finally we are able to produce it in June.

We are a collective of artists interested in looking at important and relevant social issues through the arts. Theatre from its inception has been political, pointing out injustices to those in power. This play is important to all of us because of what is says about gender; highlighting and questioning the disparities between men and women. Especially those that we participate in, and those that we simply allow to happen to us.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need help with all sorts of costs. Funds will go toward:

Costumes - (There are a few period costumes in this piece, and so the cost of those may be significant)

Festival costs- (fees associated with publicity)

Rehearsal space - (renting rehearsal space in NYC can get pricey!!)

And most importantly, travel costs for the actors and crew - (cast and crew will be coming in for rehearsals and performances from the  boroughs, Long Island, and New Jersey. Being able to offset those costs for them would be amazing!) 

 

The Impact

lace is unrelenting in how it challenges the audience to consider their position. It asks: Are you someone who participates? Or are you merely a witness to what happens around you?

Even if you are unable to help us through this campaign, please, please please talk about it to your friends and family. We need all the audience support we can get!

Performances:

Friday, June 7 9:00pm

Sunday, June 9 1:00 pm

Saturday, June 15 9:00pm

Wednesday, June 19 7:00pm

Especially those that we participate in, and those that we simply allow to happen to us.
 


What We Need & What You Get
We need help with all sorts of costs. Funds will go toward:
Costumes - (There are a few period costumes in this piece, and so the cost of those may be significant)
Festival costs- (fees associated with publicity)
Rehearsal space - (renting rehearsal space in NYC can get pricey!!)
And most importantly, travel costs for the actors and crew - (cast and crew will be coming in for rehearsals and performances from the  boroughs, Long Island, and New Jersey. Being able to offset those costs for them would be amazing!) 
 


The Impact
lace is unrelenting in how it challenges the audience to consider their position. It asks: Are you someone who participates? Or are you merely a witness to what happens around you?
Even if you are unable to help us through this campaign, please, please please talk about it to your friends and family. We need all the audience support we can get!
Performances:
Friday, June 7 9:00pm
Sunday, June 9 1:00 pm
Saturday, June 15 9:00pm
Wednesday, June 19 7:00pm

story:
Artwork donated by  John R. Dilworth. of Stretch Films

The Project:

Local residents and theatre buffs alike are organizing in an effort to reestablish The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre  to its former glory.  That's where we come in. Our grass roots theatre company Arch Villain is set to catapult interest by producing the first play on the American Shakespeare Festival stage in 29 years: a steampunk version of Richard III. 

Together with your help, we will be able to breathe new life into this historical landmark, and bring theatre, culture and tourism back to Stratford, CT.   

What is The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre?

The historical American Shakespeare Festival Theatre of Stratford CT was first founded in the 1950's by Lawrence Langner, Lincoln Kristein and Joseph Verner Reed.  Mr. Langner was also a founding member of the New York City Theatre Guild and Westport Country Playhouse.

Between 1955 and the 1980's The American Shakespeare Festival theatre has nurtured such talents as Katherine Hepburn, Chrisopher Walken, Ed Asner, James Earl Jones and Christopher Plummer. 

However, due financial and political complications, the theatre has been closed to the public for almost 30 years. 

Learn more about the theatre here: 

http://www.stratfordstar.com/4409/live-from-stratford-its-christopher-walken/

http://www.stratfordstar.com/4336/thanks-ed-asner-mayor-and-town-of-stratford/

http://www.stratfordstar.com/5116/walken-returns-to-old-stage-foresees-new-life/

Who we are:

This whole project began with three theatre artists:  Geoffrey Gilbert, Vic Terenzio and Melissa Schleier. We are all professionally trained actors who met while performing together in a local community theatre production.   Since then, we teamed up with Stratford town councilman and actor Matt Catalano, who has been advocating for the theatre for several years. 

Together we founded Arch Villain Theatre Company:

"We are on a quest to heighten emotions, envelope the senses and awaken the psyche.  By producing plays both new and old, we endeavor to propel an ancient art form into the modern age."

We boast a highly skilled and diverse group of regional talent that includes an alumni member of the National Shakespeare Company, producers, professionally trained actors, and designers. 

What We Need & What You Get:

Your funds go towards all the bare necesities of theatre production. This will include: advertising, playbills, flyers and postcards, costumes, production crew, props, lighting equipment and miscellaneous needs (i.e.: fans, electrical cords, water, and duct tape, etc...for some reason projects AlWAYS need duct tape).

                         Richard III Production Budget:

Print/Internet Advertising:                                                              $1,500

Playbills:                                                                                      $2,500

Flyers/Postcards:                                                                             $252

Production Crew (Stage Manager, Electrician, Stage Hands):               $1,500

Costumes ($100 per costume x 25 actors)                                       $2,500

Props:                                                                                            $200

Stage Lighting:                                                                             $6,000

Miscellaneous:                                                                                 $500

Subtotal:                                                                                                                    $14,952

Total (Including Indigogo fees):                                                                                                     $16,077              

If we do not reach our goal, we will still use whatever we raise toward the show.  We will attempt to build the show out of tin foil and a piece of bubble gum if we must.  However, we feel the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and it's legacy deserve the best production we can possibly give. 

If we surpass our goal, 30% of the extra funds will go toward improving our production (better costumes, better lighting, happier production crew), 40% will go toward efforts to renovate the theatre and %30 will go towards paying the actors.

Please check out the "Perks" column on the right hand side of this page to learn about the great bonuses of becoming an Arch Villain benefactor!

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you are as inspired as we are but are a little hard up on cash, you can still have a huge impact. Simply share this campaign on your social media site, talk it up with your friends, like our Facebook page, and follow us on Twitter.

 

“Sometimes things become possible if we want them bad enough."

T.S. Eliot

story:
Welcome to Ebony Cabaret.. a warm trip back to the juke joint nights, sassy singers, Burlesque dancing and bands that swing! We have been appearing monthly at M Bar since launching in Sept 2012. Each month we get bigger audience, new songs,dances and memorable experiences. Our goal has always been to create an environment that nurtures the artist and leaves the audience feeling like they really are apart of a family.

I feel in the short time we have been on the scene we have done that. With that same intent and spirit we are participating in this year's Hollywood Fringe Festival. The Hollywood Fringe Festival is an annual celebration of the emerging arts. Environments for the Fringe include both traditional and unorthodox venues; fully equipped theatres, street corners, clubs, bars, and places unexpected. Performances are self-produced by local, national, and international arts companies and independent performers.

We plan to showcase ourselves at Three Clubs in Hollywood a premier spot for Burlesque and Cabaret. Since we are known for presenting our show as dinner theatre we are going to partner with a well known food truck to prepare some succulent tempting treats for all our guests.

In preparation for this venture we are doing a small overall of our show. Nothing is broke we just want to add a little more razzle dazzle, more dance, more variety acts, better costumes to take our show to the next level. Not to mention the festival fees, marketing,promotion and performance salaries that all need to be budgeted for. 

As you see we need a little help from our friends. Friends like you who understand the need for wonderful live theatre. Who understand that building can be a community effort and that the results when met create magic! That is why we are here. To ask our community of friends, friends of friends, colleagues and new supporters to "Come share the night with us" as we like to say at Ebony Cabaret. Come share in the journey of a great concept that is evolving right before your eyes!

Your support will ensure that we are able to provide the best show possible. It will pay performers, it will pay our Fringe Fest fees, and moreover it will launch our marketing campaign. We want to see Ebony Cabaret in every city, entertaining the masses from small rooms like Three Clubs to the Vegas Strip baby. And our road starts this summer at the Fringe. Won't you Come Share the Night?

Thank you for your support and we look forward to entertaining you at a venue near YOU!

Creator/Producer

Desiree Parkman

story:
Please donate to help me pay my expenses and get to Thailand for Spark Circus 2013!

WHO AM I?

My name is Heather Denham. I am excited to be a member of Spark! Circus this year. I am a fire performer and hoop dancer. For the past decade, I lived in San Francisco where I graduated from the master’s program in fashion design at the Academy of Art University.  After graduating, I worked seven years as a technical designer in the fashion industry.  Last year, I left my job to pursue hooping, fire performing, costume making, and circus arts full time.  I grew up in Carson City, Nevada.  At the age of three, I started acrobatics and dance lessons. I quickly fell in love with dancing, performing, acrobatics, and costumes. In the last few years, hooping has become my passion and has brought me back into performing. I appeared throughout the Bay Area as a solo act and with the hoop-dance group Mandala. I was a finalist on both seasons of Hooping Idol on Hooping.org. I am also a certified Hoop Dance Instructor from Body Hoops for both children and adults.

WHAT IS SPARK CIRCUS?

Spark! Circus is an entirely volunteer circus that spends a month benefiting disadvantaged children on the Thai Burmese border. A group of over 20 international performers travel to refugee camps, migrant schools, hospitals and orphanages. We perform silly routines for the kids by day and circus-style fire shows at night. We also run playshops, bring donations of toys and art supplies, teach the kids how to make their own toys and generally make them laugh. The refugees live a life of insecurity and restricted freedom. There are very few opportunities to play, laugh, be creative or have any sort of childhood. Spark! reaches over 4,000 children each year.  Spark! Circus aim is to brighten days with magic, wonder, and laughter. We are all unpaid performers and Spark! relies entirely on your generous donations and community support .

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

You are donating to help get me to Thailand to volunteer perform and teach with Spark circus. I will be using these funds for my airfare, food and accommodation expenses while on the project

WHAT DO YOU GET AS A REWARD?

I have a master’s degree in fashion design and I worked for over 7 years in the fashion industry in technical design. You can get a tutu or furry leg warmers. They will both have fabric from my circus costumes incorporated in. Also, I will make a CUSTOM furry vest, furry coat, or any other costume you can imagine.

WHAT IF I DON’T REACH MY GOAL?

If I don’t reach my goal, all the proceeds will go to SPARK! Circus. I will still send you your reward.

HOW MUCH DO I NEED?

I need to raise $1200-$1500 for a plane ticket, $700 for living expenses, $300 for costumes, and $300 LED and fire tools.

WHY SHOULD YOU CONTRIBUTE?

Spark! Circus is designed to develop creativity, physical fitness, communication skills, teamwork, confidence and cultural awareness. Play is a fundamental part of children’s development and a basic human right. We bring a big spark of happiness, love, amusement and entertainment into these children’s lives and the lives of those who work with them in the camps and orphanages. Through play we learn so much about ourselves. We not only learn physical coordination and skills, but also learn about the space around us. We let out our creative imagination, lightness, laughter, joy, and delight. This lasts long after the circus is in town The long term objective is to build the childrens’ confidence, cooperation, mental and manual skill levels, and creativity through play.

If you wish to donate directly the Spark Circus project; for the toys, art supplies and necessities we bring into the communities we work with on the Thai Burmese border, please go to our website www.sparkcircus.org and follow instructions on how to donate there!

If you are unable to contribute, please share this on your facebook or twitter account, or with family and friends.

story:
TUG - by Dog Kennel Hill Project

Short Summary

Hello -

Tug is a unique experience of sound, movement, design and natural occurrences chugs along the canal at 4 miles per hour on an adapted heritage work boat. Please help bringing it to Watford as part of Imagine Watford: A Festival of Extraordinary Open Air Moments. Tug will show on 26th, 29th 30th June presented by Watford Palace Theatre.

For bookings call 01923225671

http://www.watfordpalacetheatre.co.uk/page/tug

Who are we?

Dog Kennel Hill Project is a dance performance collective combining the artistic voices of Ben Ash, Henrietta Hale and Rachel Lopez de la Nieta, each having a distinctive performing career in British contemporary dance.

See our website http://dogkennelhillproject.org/

find out more about Watford Palace Theatre - http://www.watfordpalacetheatre.co.uk

We are committed to exploring new contexts for dance, through a process of investigation, risk, experimentation and cross over with other art forms. Intriguing, slippery, mind-blowing and laugh-out-loud funny have been some of the ways past work is described. Asking questions about this crazy world forms the basis our work together, and we like to find a kind of beauty within the absurdity of being human.

About This Project

Highly ambitious – TUG is all about taking ourselves out of the contemporary arts bubble and placing our work in a deeply alien environment, creating opportunities for meetings, exposures and clashes with and around different ways of life.

TUG will engage participation from canal communities and bring performance to an area rarely, if ever, the setting for contemporary performance.

Urban canals tend to conjure up ideas of disenchanted places, historically the place of the socially excluded navvies and more recently showing the decay and neglect of our abandoned industrial trade. It is in these wasteland territories, only now being reclaimed, repopulated and re-imagined with romantic notions of craft and folklore, that we will find material to weave into engaging scenarios. TUG is a meditation on waterways in which concepts and notions of fluidity, stagnation, social class, progress and degeneration all come into play.

the resulting production is a 30-40 minute performance journey with a cast of 4 multi-talented performers. It also includes a larger cast of participants who we recruit locally and work with to perform small incidental moments along the towpath, again,rooting the experience in its particular site.

Audiences can either board the boat in exclusive groups to get an intimate immersive experience -stepping onboard means becoming an integral part of the whole spectacle as though they were our cargo that we transport....

other larger groups follow the boat on a towpath walk with an audio guide containing an evocative sound score of voices, characters and music. Each experience plays with the merging of real, imaginary, functional and mythical situations and spectators are invited to form part the experience of their fellow audience members.

How can your contribution help?

We have been working in these environments starting on the heritage boat, Renfew based in Braunston, Northamptonshire. Here we began with the construction of a spectacular stage set designed to form an intriguing contemporary showboat. TUG had a successful first research presentation in Nottingham last year – now YOU can help support the re - development costs of taking the boat to Watford and embedding the themes of the work into the local histories and people this skippering, before we then take the work to some of UK's larger citeis such as London and Manchester, and more remote canal communities.

The plan is that during each stage of relocating the work to a new environment we will engage in local encounters where we discuss and document lives of people working the canal environment, talking about work and how they feel about things work, politics and economics related. An intriguing aspect of this is to research how our work, and more generally arts, performance and dance are perceived by the locals through these formal and informal conversations. At times we are heckled, other times people just stop and stare, but people always have something to say – these encounter never cease to surprise and inspire us.

See our blog to watch footage from Nottingham and our progress over the next few weeks- http://www.dkhptug.wordpress.com/

Your support

Placing high quality performance outside of traditional theatre is expensive.We have raised £50K out of a total budget of £65 through Grants for the arts, and partner organisation funding. Tug is co -produced by Dog Kennel Hill project, Dance4 and Watford Palace Theatre, supported using public funding by the National Lottery through Arts Council England, and commissioned by Dance Umbrella and The Place, with development support from Halton Borough Council, Arts development Team Halton, The Canal & Rivers Trust, South East Dance and Watford Museum

Your support will help to pay us reach our crowdfunding target of £2000 which will go towards funding TUG's second develpmental phase including an extensive research phase to unlock the hidden secrets of the Watford Waterways area, meeting locals, working with local performers and of course transporting the boat from its home in Northampton – a 4 day journey, The performances are 26th,29th and 30th June

Other locations planned for 2013 pending further funding include Dance Umbrella festival in London, The Lowry in Manchester and the Brindley in Runcorn.

We value any contribution you can make and feel a true connection and gratitude to anyone who commits to our work. Our perks, true to the style of DKHP are playful, special and a touch bizarre, including ways in which you can inform aspects of the work or become part of a deeper network of ideas that gradually become enmeshed in our practice like some strange form of currency or exchange of cargo

Even if you cannot support financially, there are ways to get involved:

See our campaign to recruit volunteer performers for incidental towpath activity, http://www.watfordpalacetheatre.co.uk/page/volunteer-performers-needed-2

or if you are not performance inclined but live or work around Watford's waterways then do come forward with a story to tell, that might end up part of the show.....

 

Collaborative team

Directors – Henrietta Hale and Rachel Lopez de la Nieta

Composer and musician -Sianed Jones http://sianed.co.uk/

performers – Colin Poole, Rohanna Eade and Ben Ash

design team –DKHP and Tony Wadham, Jon Ratigan

What we have done before

  • Dog kennel Hill Project's work has shown in a range of contexts including the visual arts, opera, circus and television commercials

  • DKHP have received a broad set of commissions including a TPSE Relay commission to make work for Kings Wood with Stour Valley Arts, a recent commission for new work on Scottish Dance Theatre and 6 Place Prize Commissions

  • Associate artists with Dance4, Nottingham

  • Their recent credits have including performances at The Barbican, Whitechapel Gallery, Nottdance 2011, ArtsCross -China, Aerowaves Spring Forward Festival -Slovenia and The British Council Showcase at Edinburgh Festival 2011

recent reviewers say

“Dog Kennel Hill Project (DKHP) has a manner of performing that is fresh and nuanced.” Flora Wellesly Wesley – Bellyflopmag.com on Figure stuck Stuck at Whitechapel Gallery

 

“This was anarchic mayhem writ large but funny and always absorbing, delivered with style and great humour from excellent performers.” Graham Watts – Dancetabs.com  on Pavlova's Dogs created for Scottish Dance Theatre by DKHP

 

“original and provocative as well as highly entertaining.” Tamia Deaville – The Argus, on The Devil and The Details at The Brighton Festival

 

DKHP have proved themselves to be creators of work of consistent quality and invention, demonstrated by the range and profile of our partners across the arts and beyond.

An intriguing aspect of this is to research how our work, and more generally arts, performance and dance are perceived by the locals through these formal and informal conversations. At times we are heckled, other times people just stop and stare, but people always have something to say – these encounter never cease to surprise and inspire us. 
See our blog to watch footage from Nottingham and our progress over the next few weeks- http://www.dkhptug.wordpress.com/
Your support
Placing high quality performance outside of traditional theatre is expensive.We have raised £50K out of a total budget of £65 through Grants for the arts, and partner organisation funding. Tug is co -produced by Dog Kennel Hill project, Dance4 and Watford Palace Theatre, supported using public funding by the National Lottery through Arts Council England, and commissioned by Dance Umbrella and The Place, with development support from Halton Borough Council, Arts development Team Halton, The Canal & Rivers Trust, South East Dance and Watford Museum
Your support will help to pay us reach our crowdfunding target of £2000 which will go towards funding TUG's second develpmental phase including an extensive research phase to unlock the hidden secrets of the Watford Waterways area, meeting locals, working with local performers and of course transporting the boat from its home in Northampton – a 4 day journey, The performances are 26th,29th and 30th June
Other locations planned for 2013 pending further funding include Dance Umbrella festival in London, The Lowry in Manchester and the Brindley in Runcorn.
We value any contribution you can make and feel a true connection and gratitude to anyone who commits to our work. Our perks, true to the style of DKHP are playful, special and a touch bizarre, including ways in which you can inform aspects of the work or become part of a deeper network of ideas that gradually become enmeshed in our practice like some strange form of currency or exchange of cargo
Even if you cannot support financially, there are ways to get involved:
See our campaign to recruit volunteer performers for incidental towpath activity, http://www.watfordpalacetheatre.co.uk/page/volunteer-performers-needed-2
or if you are not performance inclined but live or work around Watford's waterways then do come forward with a story to tell, that might end up part of the show.....
 
Collaborative team
Directors – Henrietta Hale and Rachel Lopez de la Nieta
Composer and musician -Sianed Jones http://sianed.co.uk/
performers – Colin Poole, Rohanna Eade and Ben Ash
design team –DKHP and Tony Wadham, Jon Ratigan
What we have done before


Dog kennel Hill Project's work has shown in a range of contexts including the visual arts, opera, circus and television commercials 


DKHP have received a broad set of commissions including a TPSE Relay commission to make work for Kings Wood with Stour Valley Arts, a recent commission for new work on Scottish Dance Theatre and 6 Place Prize Commissions


Associate artists with Dance4, Nottingham


Their recent credits have including performances at The Barbican, Whitechapel Gallery, Nottdance 2011, ArtsCross -China, Aerowaves Spring Forward Festival -Slovenia and The British Council Showcase at Edinburgh Festival 2011


recent reviewers say
“Dog Kennel Hill Project (DKHP) has a manner of performing that is fresh and nuanced.” Flora Wellesly Wesley – Bellyflopmag.com on Figure stuck Stuck at Whitechapel Gallery
 
“This was anarchic mayhem writ large but funny and always absorbing, delivered with style and great humour from excellent performers.” Graham Watts – Dancetabs.com  on Pavlova's Dogs created for Scottish Dance Theatre by DKHP
 
“original and provocative as well as highly entertaining.” Tamia Deaville – The Argus, on The Devil and The Details at The Brighton Festival
 
DKHP have proved themselves to be creators of work of consistent quality and invention, demonstrated by the range and profile of our partners across the arts and beyond.

story:
What is Obedient Steel?

Obedient Steel is a play about the brightest minds in the world. They are young, smart, and talented. They dance. They wear very stylish glasses. Their work is too complicated to explain to parents or childhood friends - it is also too secret. But if you did know, you would be very impressed. Then, something happens. A small thing, really, that could have happened to anyone, or just as easily not happened at all. And now nothing will ever be the same.

This is a play about Brilliance. This is a play about Progress. This is a play about the guinea pig you really didn’t mean to hurt that is now lying dead on the table. This is a play about You.

(graphic design by E. Noelle Bullion)

Obedient Steel has been developed since Spring 2012 with Tugboat Collective, playwright Chloe Brown, and director Rebecca Wear. It will premiere November 14-24 at HERE Arts Center, featuring Nathaniel Basch-Gould (Tugboat member), E. James Ford, Craig Mungavin, Anastasia Olowin, Max Reinhardsen, and Kate Thulin (Tugboat member).

What is Tugboat Collective?

Tugboat Collective is a Brooklyn-based group of collaborative artists dedicated to developing accessible, low-cost, experimental theater. Headed up by Artistic Directors Eben Hoffer and Joseph Wolfslau, Tugboat Collective is Nathaniel Basch-Gould, Chloe Brown, Mike Faba, Isaac Hoffer, Kate Thulin, and Nick Trotta. We are actors, writers, and designers; we make work that is surprising, funny, and makes use of the fact that you are in the room with us.

(Jack the Bird and Moon & Marble)

We've been hard at work this past year. In December, we premiered Moon & Marble, a white-face clown show that featured live music and a complex hemp-and-bag fly system at the Brooklyn Lyceum.  Next came Jack The Bird, which appeared both in January's Snowballs Festival (Space on White) and August's Dream Up Festival at Theater for the New City. We also continued workshopping our surreal rock musical, The Violet Road, and produced a full album of music from the show.

All the while, we worked on Obedient Steel. Since April of 2012, Tugboat has held regular workshops to develop the piece. When we began, we didn't have a script or even a story, just a lot of questions about things we'd read, heard, or seen through bullet-proof glass. After a year and a half of writing and workshops, we are so excited to share our fourth Tugboat production with you.

Why We Need Your Support

We're over the moon to have been selected for HERE Arts Center's SUBlet Series. However, even with this subsidized rental, the cost of the venue in addition to the other costs of putting together a full production mean that to present Obedient Steel, Tugboat must raise $5,000.

Where do these dollar bills go towards?

  • Performance venue rental
  • Rehearsal space
  • Material for set, costume, and props
  • Sound and lighting equipment
  • Transportation of equipment and materials
  • Marketing and printed materials

We are so thankful for whatever you can give - we couldn't do it without you!

story:
Help Relay Go On Tour!

My name is Margit Galanter, and I am going on tour this spring with a piece called Relay: Discovering New Species. I am a dance poet and movement investigator, and my fascinations regarding the composition and value of movement have drawn me to collaborative embodied research for decades. I teach, curate, organize, write, and practice movement. Specifically in the movement arts, I practice the Feldenkrais Method, Chinese energetics, embodied language practices, and dance. I often hesitate with that final word 'dance,'  because my work is constantly finding new ways to expand perspectives on dance - and by doing so, building connections between things -- people, disciplines, languages, and aesthetics. I work with subtle practices to create conceptual work that springs from the body's ability to know and articulate, which is a long and potent road. 

Relay: Discovering New Species is an evening-length dance poetry performance piece when it interacts with artists in the environment where presented, in collaboration. Relay will tour both informally in February after a residency in Southern California in Joshua Tree - with presentations in LA and Riverside - then with shows in March in Seattle and NYC, and then in June with a culminating event in the Bay Area. This piece is inspired by a three-year research of dance poetry inspired by the poem Concordance by Mei-Mei Bersenbrugge and Kiki Smith, and 25 traveling interviews I instigated in the summer of 2013. Relay continues to defy the term solo; in each location I am collaborating with local artists to create unique events that spring from the location. 

You are very much invited to the shows, and I need your help to get there! 

What I Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $2800 for this project. Your support will directly enable this touring project to be financially sustainable. For the support to come from my relations is an honest treasure, not only of the financial kind, but also of a more invisible value - strengthening and deepening mutual support and dialogue. By offering a donation, you become a participant in the circulation of this piece.

Here is the breakdown:

Expenses:

  • Costume + Set: $550
  • Partial Travel + Gas: $450
  • Partial Per Diem: $335
  • Admin: $150
  • Space Rental: $825
  • Food for events: $400
  • Participating Artist Fees: $800
  • Archiving: $250
  • Total Expenses: $3,760

Projected Income:

  • Ticket Sales: $750
  • Workshops: $450
  • Total Projected Income: $1,200

Expenses - Projected Income: $2,560

Indiegogo Campaign Fees: $240

Total: $2,800

In the event that the full amount is not reached, this will come out of set and per diem, and other sources will be sought. Ideally the full amount is reached here in this forum, and with more, full travel and per diem will be reimbursed, and more offered to participating artists. 

For each of the tiers of the project, there are perks which are listed here on the site. The more you offer, the more you receive. Based on what you give, you will receive: acknowledgements in a final program, a home-made audio playlist, a Relay visual collage made by artist extraordinaire Neil Marcus, free tickets to the show, a qigong DVD, personally-made digital collage, or tailor-made phone or in-person sessions in Physical Intelligence. 

Why Fund this Project, and Why Now? 

I am seeking funds for this for a few reasons: Firstly, I am very excited about the research - the nascent fields of dance poetry and movement culture came directly out of my decade's plus research in embodied language, in response to the colleagues, mentors, and field from which my work springs. Over time I have found that the only way to move ideas forward is through enacting and being in conversation; this tour is this very engagement. 

A second reason to fund this campaign is that this is a tour, and to make a tour is a big expense (both the traveling and the not-working-during part). Cost of living in art-making is for real, so your support will literally make the tour possible.

Thirdly, there is an aspect of this piece which is about felting relations, that the Relay project is indeed an art piece, and it is also a life-practice-cultural investigation in meshing connections, so in earnest, to ask for support is to be indebted to you, and entangles us more deeply, beautifully. I seek to enrich my relations with you all, and hope that this project and campaign can not only bring in income to support itself, but also further open up a dialogue amongst us. 

As you may know, I have spent many years supporting other artists as an organizer, curator, and co-director in the arts. Perhaps I have even offered you an opportunity over time. With this project, I am not only making a single work, but integrating my deep curiosity around relational aesthetics, cultural work, and the efficacy of community-building through the arts. I believe in the work enough to ask for support, both artistically and in the ways that the aesthetic material is coherently aligned with the material of the piece.

Your donation will support this tour, where the project will intersect with multiple performers and audiences in several cities, and by signing on now, you will help this project reach its goal of financial sustainability. 

More Information:

Relay:

Relay is a longterm dance poetry project. It is a three-part dance poetry performance working with material that ranges from embodying poetry, transducing conversations into practice-actions in space, and studying energetics with swords. Inspired by the visual poem Concordance by Mei-Mei Bersenbrugge and Kiki Smith, for three years I have been investigating particular questions around embodied language, in resonance withplace and space. In the summer of 2013, I conducted twenty-five traveling conversations with artist/practitioners in a region of the East Bay (Relay Encounters). These conversations offered intriguing perspectives movement, language, and landscape, and set up an ephemeral a web of relations. This current touring iteration of Relay: Discovering New Species is a composition experimentally-based on materials of the summers' encounters; while the piece does not immediately address all of the interactions nor encompass them, the conversations provided multiple layers of communication which became both direct and indirect material for the piece. What"Discovering New Species" refers to is the awe of what it means to make something, for it to be named in a sense  - be it sound or object or action - that is entirely novel for that moment, yet drawn from what already is. This delicate place of encountering language and tone is the material of this work.

The Tour

February
Residency, feral studio.home, Joshua Tree
Presentation, Pieter Performance, LA
Presentation, CHAR Salon, Riverside

March
Performance, Taoist Institute, Seattle, with Jessika Kenney
Performance, The Loft, Brooklyn, with guests

June
Performance and Events, Bay Area, CA

Over the three years I have been: embodying and performing segments of the poem through traditional and experimental tactics, writing a poetry chapbook (Relay transduxions), exchanging with artists in various disciplines, laying fallow and integrating, and coming up with terms to meet new regions of practice, such as "transductions" to describe the process of taking material from one medium into others, and "anchoring" to deal directly with counteracting with confusion and adrenaline in performing. I tend to take long periods of time to investigate material when I work, so the art is deeply embedded in with my intellectual, physical, cultural, imaginal, and aesthetic fascinations over time, and they cross and exchange with others.

The experiential process of art always interacts in some way with larger, cultural questions. At every step of this project, I have been extending what it means to be in solo through multiple forms of conversation. Actually, this piece is an early step in defining the term and field "Movement Culture," which is coming to be defined like this: embodied action has deep meaning and is mutually effected by the people and situation of which it is part. This work as well as the term continues to be redefined through the people from which is springs and conversations that grow over time.

By supporting this project, you will be more woven into the threads of this work.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Of course, if you are unable to offer any direct donations to the campaign, there are other ways that you could support the project that would be very valuable. Firstly, It would be so great if you could spread this campaign, put it up on your wall or site or pass it along via email. This would be so great! Additionally, if you live in any of the cities where there will be a public event, you could help with coordinating or getting the word out. Please get in touch directly, and we can figure this out. Thanks so much!

With appreciation and felt, 

 Margit

Relay Encounters, Conversations, and Collaborations with:

Violet Juno: Art-Life Exchange
Maureen Whiting: Choreographic Mentor
Avery Hudson: Archival and Technical Support

story:
My name is Bayley and I have been granted an amazing opportunity to audition
for Juilliard (which I got a call back at), NYU, USC, UCLA, FSU, and many other incredible performing arts schools. I could not have gone to New York without your help! You are all so awesome! I hope to become an actress and by attending these schools, I could
make my dream come true. I have already done many independent films and have
starred in many theatre shows but I wish to continue to grow as an actress and
be on Broadway or go to Hollywood. Check out my IMDB: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3183762/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1

I
have many places to fly to so your support would be phenomenal. I unfortunately
cannot afford to buy plane tickets for my trips. Every penny counts! Thank you
for thinking of me. Your kindness means the world to me and I love you all so
much.
story_txt: My name is Bayley and I have been granted an amazing opportunity to audition for Juilliard (which I got a call back at), NYU, USC, UCLA, FSU, and many other incredible performing arts schools. I could not have gone to New York without your help! You are all so awesome! I hope to become an actress and by attending these schools, I could make my dream come true. I have already done many independent films and have starred in many theatre shows but I wish to continue to grow as an actress and be on Broadway or go to Hollywood. Check out my IMDB: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3183762/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1I have many places to fly to so your support would be phenomenal. I unfortunately cannot afford to buy plane tickets for my trips. Every penny counts! Thank you for thinking of me. Your kindness means the world to me and I love you all so much.

story:
We need your help.

$2,500 is our goal for this campaign.  The money we raise will help offset the costs of this production.  Expenses include participation fee in the festival, payment to creative team of actors, director, producer, stage manager, and set designer, props, costumes, PR, and rehearsal space. 

Even ten dollars will make a difference.

 

The Play:

THE LIGHT IN THE REFRIGERATOR

A new comedy by Laura Zlatos

Directed by Francesca Mantani Arkus

Staged Managed by Caroline Watters

Produced by Aaron Simms

 

Starring:

Mark Ellmore*

Joslyn Jensen

Ron Kagan

Michael Perrie Jr.

 

Diagnosed with an unknown, incurable disease, a man searches for the meaning of life and the answer to one of the world's greatest mysteries: Does the light go off in the refrigerator when you shut the door?

Presented and selected as part of the Strawberry Theatre Festival

February 27th @ 9PM

March 3rd @ 8PM

March 9th @ 4PM


Hudson Guild Theater

441 West 26th St.

New York, NY 10001

 

Tickets are $18 (subject to service charge) at

http://www.therianttheatre.com/item.php?id=161

*The Light in the Refrigerator is an Actor's Equity Approved Showcase

 

Please help us to support this exciting new voice in American theater, the gifted actors, innovative director and visionary production team.

Please help us to spread the word.  Tell your friends, make a donation, and we will see you at the show.

story:
What's Project Shimmy?

Torque, the professional belly dance troupe at Twisted Dance Studios began Project Shimmy in 2008 as a way to help Triad Health Project, a Greensboro-based 501(c)-3 non-profit organization, meet the needs of individuals living with HIV / AIDS and their loved ones.  2013 will be the 5th Annual benefit show, and Torque would like to raise even more funds for THP.  And to do that, they need help to pay for the expenses of producing Project Shimmy.  If Torque can raise $1000, any and all money raised by the benefit show will go directly to Triad Health Project.

What We Need & What You Get

Torque needs $1000 to cover expenses of producing and promoting Project Shimmy.  Here's where the money goes:

  • Theatre Rental:  FREE
  • Sound and Light Operators:  $600
  • Security Guard during the Show:  $100
  • Cleaning Fee for Theatre:  $75
  • Posters/Flyers:  $125
  • Programs: $100

If you donate to our campaign, here's what we can offer you!

$20 donation:  one Project Shimmy Ticket and a mention in the program as a Contributor.

$50 donation:  Pair of Project Shimmy tickets, one FREE class at Twisted Dance Studios, and a mention in our program as a Contributor to our campaign.

$100 donation:  Pair of Project Shimmy tickets, two Twisted Dance t-shirts and a mention as a Sponsor in our program

$500 donation:  Four Project Shimmy tickets, four Twisted Dance t-shirts, a mention as an Angel in our program, and a six-months AYCD pass for Twisted Dance Studios.

All money raised will go to cover expenses for the show.  Any additional funds will go to THP as additional donations for their services.  No monies will be utilized by Torque or Twisted Dance Studios for any purpose other than the benefit show.

About Triad Health Project Client Services:

Triad Health Project is committed to tailoring their services to meet the ever-changing needs of clients. Following the development over the past few years of newer, more effective treatments for HIV and AIDS, clients are living long and healthy lives, enjoying relationships, family and careers in a way never imagined when the disease was discovered.

Unfortunately, accessing adequate medical care and medications to ensure good health can be a challenge for many people living with HIV. A diagnosis of HIV also often brings fear, sadness, anger, stress, isolation, and anxiety--a stigma of fear and disgrace that can prevent treatment.

In response to these concerns, Triad Health Project provides intensive, individualized case management services, which are provided by professionals specifically trained and experienced in the field of HIV. THP fights against the stigma that continues to be a barrier to those diagnosed with HIV. Triad Health Project provides support, counseling and therapeutic groups to individuals and families who are learning to cope with HIV.

Triad Health Project is committed to educating the entire community about HIV and other sexually transmitted infections. Prevention is still the only cure for HIV and knowing one's status is the first step in protecting yourself and others. THP offers free and confidential testing and counseling every Monday night from 5:00 - 7:00 PM at their Greensboro office, and throughout the community at various outreach events.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to donate...you can still help!  Please share this campaign with your family and friends! Or email us at www.twisteddancestudios@gmail.com and let us know that you would be interested in volunteering for Project Shimmy. 
 
You can also help us if you are a business!  We need raffle prizes to help raise additional funds for THP.  If you would like to donate, please contact us at www.twisteddancestudios@gmail.com.

story:
work in progress theatre company

Hi! Thanks for taking an interest in our FIRST ever production! We (Drew Moyer and Larissa Colangelo) are the founding artistic directors of work in progress theatre company.  We are preparing to launch a production of Burn This by Lanford Wilson, at the end of August.  There are several expenses that go into producing a play - that a barista and math tutor's hourly wage simply won't cover.  Any contribution, no matter how small, will go a long way.  Whether it contributes to an actor's salary, set design, or theater rental - anything helps!

give a little, get a little..

Our current campaign is how much we'll need to "break even".  As artists, we're not concerend with profitting from this endeavor.  All we want is produce a quality production, with the hope of producing more in the future!  The money we're looking to raise is to ensure that we can compensate our actors properly, provide quality production standards (through set, lighting, etc.), and pay for a great theater to make it all happen.

We realize that it's not always easy to give money- even if you want to.  If you're feeling that you're able to do so, we would love to show our gratitude as best we can.  We can offer tickets to see the show you're helping put up, as well as a private reception with the cast after the opening night performance! 

If we don't reach our goal, we assure you that the help we do receive will not be put to waste.  We are extremely dedicated to the future of this company, and any funds received will help us with this current production, or with the many future productions that will hopefully follow!  Again, we are so appreciative of your generosity, whether we are able to reach our goal, or not.

 thanks! thanks! thanks!

We are a company that truly believes that the arts matter.  They have changed our lives in so many ways, and we honestly believe they bring a much needed intellectual and creative value to communities.  Our one goal is to produce good theatre to people who appreciate it, and create art that we're passionate about.  We have the ambition, now all we need is YOU!  Hopefully, we'll see you opening night!

no money? no problem!

We understand (seriously, we do) that giving money isn't always an option.  If you're able to post a link to this campaign via facebook, emal, or twitter; please do so!  Every little bit helps! Thanks for your support!

check us out on the web!

www.workinprogresstheatreco.com

story:
Short Summary

Romeo/Juliet is an experimental adaptation of William Shakespeare’s classic love story. It was adapted and directed by Stefanie Harris employing gender blind casting (ever want to see Mercutio played by a fiesty girl??), movement, and music as part of Spectrum Player’s “Night of Experimental Works” at Hofstra University. Since its premiere in April 2012, Romeo/Juliet has been reworked and rehearsed, and expanded its creative team, including the addition of the production company, Royal Family Productions, Inc. The next step is the production at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, the largest arts festival in the world. Our venue has been secured and we are officially in the festival. That's where you come in! In order to make this production a success, we are looking for donations, sponsors, and other fundraising opportunities to help us with our travel costs, accomodations, venue/production budget, and publicity.

What We Need & What You Get

Our overall projected cost for bringing our project to Scotland is $30,000.

Below is a breakdown of our sponsorship packages.

TITLE SPONSOR: $20,000

  • Branding above title on all promotional materials
  • Primary branding on all t-shirts*
  • Inclusion in all email blasts.
  • Links from show website.
  • Comp tickets to any New York performance.
  • Passes to opening night party in New York.
  • Executive Producer credit in show program.

PRESENTING SPONSOR: $10,000

  • Primary branding on all promotional materials.
  • Primary branding on all t-shirts*.
  • Inclusion in all email blasts.
  • Links from show website.
  • Comp tickets to any weekend New York performance.
  • Producer credit in show program.

CORPORATE SPONSOR: $5,000

  • Secondary branding on all promotional materials.
  • Secondary branding on all t-shirts*.
  • Inclusion in all email blasts.
  • Links from show website.
  • Comp tickets to any weekend New York performance.
  • Producer credit in show program.

ASSOCIATE PRODUCER: $1,000

  • Branding on all t-shirts*.
  • Associate producer credit in show program.
  • Inclusion in all email blasts.
  • Links from show website.
  • 5 comp tickets to any New York performance.

FESTIVAL FRIEND: $500

  • Links from show webstite.
  • Inclusion in show program.
  • Inclusion in all email blasts.
  • 2 comp tickets to any New York performance

*Branding will be placed on t-shirt if enough funding is raised to have the shirts made

 ****If you're not a big company and want to donate in the smaller range, check out our fun perks off to the right! ------>

Other Ways You Can Help

Our company is comprised of theatre-loving individuals who wish to foster an appreciation of Shakespeare in younger children. Members of our cast and creative team have extensive background in teaching and directing children of all ages. We are interested in partnering with schools and theatre programs to hold benefit workshops. To find out more about this opportunity, please email romeo.juliet.fringe@gmail.com
