story:
Columbia University MFA Theatre Directing Season, Fall 2013!

1 graduate program + 6 talented directors + Chekhov and fairy tales = 12 incredible productions at Columbia this fall

Columbia University School of the Arts graduate, second-year directors have banded together to raise support for their productions this fall.  Navigating the challenges of graduate school can be exciting, exhausting, and rewarding...and, for our next project we need your help!

This is a collaborative fundraising campaign for the Columbia University School of the Arts directing projects.  We have six directors working on 12 projects this fall!  All of the productions will be presented this October, November, and December at Columbia.  Our goal is to raise $3,100 (that’s about $516 per show) to be used in direct support of the director’s fall productions.  The funds raised here will help us cover the costs of sets, props, local transportation, and costumes.  Support for the fall directing projects extends beyond this campaign; we rely on the generous support of the School of the Arts, as well as our local community resources such as Materials for the Arts.  We know how to stretch a dollar!  Your donation will truly make a difference to all 12 productions!

The directors are: Juan Pablo Felix, Anouk Kemp, Dara Malina, Chris Murrah, Peter Petkovsek, and Maridee Slater

Check out the shows this fall:

October 4-6:

The Weird Tree (Peter Petkovsek) Schapiro Studio

October 11-13:

Three Sisters (Chris Murrah) Schapiro Studio

Uncle Vanya (Dara Malina)  Schapiro Theatre

October 18-20:

El Hombre Caiman (Juan Pablo Felix) Schapiro Theatre

October 24-26:

A Sea Gull (Maridee Slater) Schapiro Theatre

Ivanov: Acts I and II (Anouk Kemp) Schapiro Studio

November 15-17:

Peter Pan (Chris Murrah) Schapiro Theatre

Chekhov Play (Peter Petkovsek) Horace Mann

November 22-24:

Lilith (Dara Malina) Horace Mann

December 6-8:

Uncle Vanya (Juan Pablo Felix) Schapiro Studio

Donkey Skin (Anouk Kemp) Schapiro Theatre

SIRENS (Maridee Slater) Horace Mann

** Leave a message in the comment section if you’re interested in attending a production.  All tickets are free and require a simple email reservation.  We’d love to see you at the theatre!

The Impact

This project is unique in that your donation doesn’t just support one artist, one organization, or one production.  Your donation will support six directors creating 12 productions in just four short months!  Again, every dollar will be put to great use!

Other Ways You Can Help

We get it - we’re not in a position to hand out donations to all our favorite Indiegogo campaigns, either.  If you aren’t able to make a financial contribution to our project, we hope you take a moment to watch our video, read more about the project, and come visit us at Columbia this fall.  If you’re all about Facebook and Twitter, too, feel free to share and tweet away!  

And, yes, grad school is REALLY like this.

story:
Break dance for the community 4th event

 Galaxy Dance Project Uganda is a non profit youth empowering project in Kampala that uses break dance and other elements of Hip hop culture to reach-out to different communities to ensure positive social change.

Break dance for the community is an annual event organized by Galaxy dance project in order to give our dancers an opportunity to use their talents to communicate positively to the society. Its basically an inspiration and motivational cause for our project members to get the community involved in our mission and purpose.

This campaign will help us to raise funds to cover some costs for our event budget. Costs of sound and venue hiring are the reason for this campaign.This campaign will help us make the event a success and a big positive impact on our community as our strength in reach to more people will be boosted.

The budget

We need to raise $600 and its going to help us cover the sound and venue hiring costs plus getting a few event t-shirts printed.

We really appreciate our supporters and to show our appreciation,

  • We shall send each person a video of the event.
  • Funding above $100 will be appreciated with a project t-shirt.
  • Funding above $150 will be appreciated with a short hand photo-book about the project.
  • If we are not able to reach our goal in this campaign, the received money will be used to cover the costs of hiring a venue.

The Impact

Break dance for the Community is a valuable event as it gives us an opportunity to appreciate and celebrate the young talents that Uganda has. Its an opportunity of the contributor to support the empowerment of the booming talents among the youths. Its an amazing project to expose the young talents to the world out there, to inspire and empower other youths elsewhere, its a creation of opportunities for our dancers at Galaxy Dance Project Uganda.

With your support and contribution, we shall make this event a success and the unity and determination we have will help us through.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by following us http://www.galaxydanceprojectuganda.blogspot.com

http://www.galaxydanceproject.webs.com

Email- mbabaziesther9@gmail.com


You can also share this with your friends and family. We appreciate that.

story:
Hello, my name is Sarah. I'm an actor based in Phoenix, Arizona. Here's a sample of the work I've done over the last few years. 

Sarah (center) playing Winthrop, a 10-year-old boy with a lisp, in Meredith Wilson's Music Man. 

Here's a feature-length film, Broken Leg, we filmed in 2012. You can even buy the DVD or rent on August 1st. 


Versatility is my goal. I work to make my characters distinct and unique for each and every play or production. Film or stage..I love it all! 

Zenventory Commercial        Jo March in Little Women     Princess in Invincible

 

A New Opportunity

In spring 2014, I was 1 of 12 world-wide accepted to the Bristol Old Vic Theatre School in Bristol, England for a Master's program in Professional Acting. The course consists of 11 hour-days of intensive training to prepare actors with the skill and versatility necessary for a long-term career in acting. The school has produced some of the world’s best actors including Daniel-Day Lewis, Patrick Stewart, Jeremy Irons, Miranda Richardson, Pete Posthelwate, Naomi Harris, Gene Wilder and many more. The school provides excellent training for any actor, regardless of nationality. It’s a wonderful opportunity that would open many doors unavailable to me here in Phoenix.

Here's a video about the school. 


Phenomenal opportunity, right?!? There's just one little catch... The school costs a lot of money (around $46,000) and I'm unable to take out a student loan.

    I need your help! 

    Through the help of family members, savings from working various jobs, and random change found in my parents' house, we've almost been able to come up with funds necessary to pay for the year. I'm only $4,017.00 short!

    Here's how the numbers work out: 

    • Total Tuition Costs: £18,800 or $31, 914.88
    • Funds available to pay for tuition: $27,897.88
    • Amount left to pay: $4,017
    I'm so close, and yet so far from funding the program without a private loan. That's why I'm turning to you!

    Could you spare a dime? 

    Even a $0.25 donation is $0.25 more than I had before. Any sort of cash you might be able to contribute to get me to school, would be greatly appreciated. 

    It would be so appreciated that I have a series of perks to show my gratitude. 

    • $10 or under: Your name will get mentioned in our end-of-the-summer rap video my brother, Greyson, and I will make. Your name will go up on the"Great Wall of Thanks" on both my website that chronicles my time in England as a young actor and on the wall I'll make in my room in Bristol. 
    • $25: I'll take a selfie with your name and something English and send it your way. 
    • $50: You'll get a signed headshot with a cheesy saying on it.
    • $100: I'll record your voice mail in one of the British dialects I learn in Bristol.
    • $500: A postcard from Bristol, a British voice-mail, and a headshot.
    • $1,000: A care-package with a plethora of goodies including postcards, new set of head shots, and English biscuits as well as production and rehearsal pictures from my experiences at Bristol Old Vic Theatre School.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't give but would like to help out, please feel free to share with your friends and family. 

    Thanks for listening, folks! 

    Much love always, 


    Sarah

story:
Who We Are

Natalie Richardson is a second year undergraduate at The University of Chicago. She is the winner of the Poetry Society of America's Lousie Louis/ Emily F. Bourne Student Award and was a member of the inaugural class of National Student Poets, the highest award for youth writers given to five students nationally by Scholastic and the President's Committee on the Arts & The Humanities. She competed in "Louder Than A Bomb," the world's largest teen poetry slam, for three consecutive years, and is currently the coach of The University of Chicago Lab School slam team.

Drew Lewis is a second year dance student at Cornish College of the Arts, though he is a Chicago native. Lewis’s choreography has won the Illinois High School Dance Festival Choreography Competition two years in a row. He has studied at The Academy of Movement and Music, The Ailey School, Deeply Rooted Dance Theater, and Cornish College of the Arts. He was recently accepted into the scholarship program at Lou Conte Dance Studio, and the Hubbard Street Dance Chicago Summer Intensive. His performance credits include Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater as part of The Memoria Project, and MOMENTA Performing Arts Company. 

We are best friends and (experimental) artists hoping to make a big debut with our first collaborative piece. Our campaign covers the cost of Madison Street Theater’s studio space, an intimate venue we think will be perfect for our show.

What We Need

Your donations will cover the following costs:

• Rental fees of Madison Street Theater

• Costumes, sets, and props

• Production costs such as printing posters, programs, and tickets

What Else You Can Do!

If you can't donate, no worries! You can still help! You can spread the word by sending this link to your friends, family, and relatives. You can also help by spreading the word about the show. Tell everyone you know! And even if you cannot donate, we'd love to have you at the show! You can purchase your tickets here: 

http://poetry-motion.brownpapertickets.com

story:
Kalazu kowaka.

If you are here, you know what this is for. 

Between three and five years ago, a group of people came together and created an alternate dimension where everything was made of bubbles and everybody spoke the Alltongue. This dimension intersected with our own for a span of two days, on five different occasions. Its inhabitants called this place the Spirit Hospital, or more colloquially, the "Shore Party."

The wheel has turned three times. One leg of our journey is complete. With this new visiting of the Spirit Hospital, we celebrate the old and ring in the new.

Please contribute to this iteration of the Spirit Hospital so that we can open its doors again in the future!

Any donations above the goal will go straight back into making this an even better event.

story:
Our Story

Rhythm is Our Business & there is certainly a lot of Rhythm in Motion. It's a NEW year, we have NEW projects and we need your help. March 19 - 24, 2013 the ATDF has TWO opportunities to engage, hire and collaborate with a number of dancers, vocalists and musicians where we will be presenting TWO different productions at the Theater at the 14th Street Y. One is entitled “Rhythm is Our Business” and the other is "Rhythm in Motion".

"Rhythm is Our Business" is directed by dancer/choreographer Derick K. Grant and includes additional choreography by 2012 Bessie Award winner Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards and others. It will star a number of local tap dancers, musicians and vocalists including Ali Bradley, Brian Davis, Khalid Hill, Hank Smith, Andrew Nemr, Jason Janas, the Shufflettes, legendary performer Mable Lee and the Duke Ellington Center Band. 

Following this production we will be presenting “Rhythm in Motion” which highlights new choreography by SEVEN of our Artists in Residence. Performers and choreographers include the amazing Brenda Bufalino (ATDF's Artistic Mentor), Michelle Dorrance, Derick K. Grant, Kazu Kumagai (from Japan), Max Pollak, Lynn Schwab, our very own Tap City Youth Ensemble, Cartier Williams and others. This production requires working with a standard jazz trio (piano, bass & drums).

Your support will be used to compensate all performance and rehearsal fees associated with these performers. The casts of fantastic tap dancers, vocalists and musicians are currently being assembled and our rehearsals begin in January. We will be posting new content (rehearsal footage) as we progress.

In Case You Don't Know Us

We are the American Tap Dance Foundation, a non-profit 501c3 Tap Dance Organization located in the West Village, New York City.

For 26 years we've been:

- creating new venues and original productions

- presenting unique artists and contemporary choreography

- educating the next generation and building new audience

- preserving the American history of tap dance

In January of 2010, we moved into our new home at the American Tap Dance Center where we will be rehearsing. Our education programs have grown over the years and so have our students. But there are very few productions for our students to see and be inspired by these days.

So, this year we are producing these concerts for our students, their families and the community. We need funding to cover all the artist fees associated with these productions!

The Impact

Our philosophy is that Tap Dance is MUSIC and a UNIVERSAL form of expression; plus its HEALTHY, FUN, and ACCESSIBLE to everyone!

Supporting our programs, and helping us raise enough funds for artist fees, will guarantee we have live music in this concert. Dancers will be paid to perform, and our audiences will enjoy TWO new tap dance shows. 

Join us in CELEBRATING 26 YEARS of bringing Tap Dance into the world by donating what ever you can!

What We Need & What You Get

Your donations, large or small, will help make this happen. We have already booked the theater and rehearsals are underway. Tickets are already on sale and we are definately doing this! We just need your support. 

If you choose to support these projects, we would like to acknowledge your gift online, on-site and in future monthly newsletters.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this project with your friends and families. And if you live in New York, come and see the shows! Many thanks!

Tony Waag-Artistic Director

story:
Humanissimus is a project created by Vitolio Jeune and Francesca Lalanne Jeune. Humanissimus Inc. is the support structure through which we engage in various creative art concepts  such as exhibits, dance performances, teachings, collaborations, video pieces and combinations of the above. Through these artistic mediums, we seek to present art that conveys dialogue amongst various audiences with a focus on the human condition. 

HUMANISSIMUS DANCING BAREFOOT is a dance exchange collaboration between Humanissimus and Dance Barefoot. Dance Barefoot is a free dance training program in Haiti created by choreographer Jeanguy Saintus, which benefits young dancers who cannot afford to pay for dance lessons. It is also a place where they can go express their emotions and the daily challenges they face. Vitolio Jeune joined Dance Barefoot when he was 17 years old. He went on to continue his dance education on a full scholarship at New World School of the Arts in Miami Florida. In 2009 he finished top 14 on So You Think You Can Dance season 5 and now he is a senior dancer with the world renowned Garth Fagan Dance in Rochester New York. For more information about Vitolio Jeune's background, please visit www.humanissimus.org

 

MAKE OUR PROJECT HAPPEN BY PLEDGING YOUR SUPPORT

In August 2010 Humanissimus held a 4 day intensive dance training for Dance Barefoot. Because we had little funding, we had to limit the length of the program. This year Humanissimus will orchestrate one week summer dance seminar for Dance Barefoot in Haiti, which will be documented by our filmmaker. We will be taking on a mentoring project through dance by visiting the orphanage where Vitolio Jeune grew up (Our Little Brothers and Sisters of St Helen) to encourage groups of young adults to use dance as a form of self-expression.The program will include master classes, and creative improvisation that will give them the opportunity to develop their personal style of movement to better express their emotions. The dancers will also attend lectures, engage in dialogue on contemporary dance and Caribbean culture, as well as dance criticism. Vitolio Jeune will also choreograph a new dance for the participants, which will be performed at the end of the seminar. Our goal is to encourage these young dancers to continue to pursue their creative dreams, despite any economic disadvantages. Through this program, we hope to establish an intellectual relationship with additional art programs in Haiti and globally. 

 

THE IMPACT YOU WILL MAKE

Humanissimus hopes first and foremost to inspire forty to sixty dancers in Haiti to use dance as a tool to overcome any difficult challenges they face daily. Most of them are still dealing with the 2010 earthquake after-effects, which are both physical but mostly psychological. We want to give them a platform to express their stories and share them with their community and the rest of the world. Humanissimus believes each one of us has an important story to tell, and we want to make it possible for them to share their experience through dance as it heals their mind and spirit. 

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

In total we need to raise a minimum of $10,000. Our financial goal is to cover the cost of the trip, which includes airfare, moderate lodging, gas, and meals for the dancers and our team of four people. The money raised will also cover for the rental of a bus to bring students from the orphanage to Dance Barefoot studio in Petion-Ville (estimate distance 15 Kilometers). Additional funds raised will cover the cost of dance attire and books to help establish a dance library for Dance Barefoot. While our goal is to successfully raise $10,000, we hope that you help us EXCEED that goal. Your donation is highly valuable to these dancers and us; so we thank you in advance from the bottom of our hearts. You will get full access to how the program will unfold and our future plans. For questions you can reach us via info@humanissimus.org

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We really hope that you are able to donate to our project, as every dollar counts and gets us closer to our goal. However, you can still help and support our project by spreading the word about HUMANISSIMUS DANCING BAREFOOT 2012. Share our links on Facebook ,email our links to your friends, family, and colleagues. This will only be possible with your generous support.

 

For more information on OUR TEAM, please visit us at www.humanissimus.org

VITOLIO JEUNE

FRANCESCA LALANNE JEUNE

LAURA LALANNE

story:
The "Up, Up and Away!" campaign seeks to help kNOTDance create and present new works, travel with its empowering movement, as well as offer "off the wall" and "Pittsburgh off the ground" free public aerial performances outside. Contributions will go toward  a portable aerial rig, aerial dance harnesses, equipment, rigging, and supplies needed for producing these events. Donations will also help provide insurance for our kNOTy moves and payment for our dancers.

kNOTDance is "People Empowered Movement." We believe dance is not just a style but is ordinary movement executed extraordinarily! By exploring the limits of the human body as a performance tool, we create works demonstrating the boundless personal, physical and intellectual achievements humans can attain.

kNOTDance explores human life through contemporary experiences of dance, aerial arts, and movement. Through physically demanding and creatively engaging works, kNOTDance aspires to inspire. Empowering others to trust their inner strength and to reach their fullest potential. We're kNOT your average dance company!

A donation of any size will help. We appreciate anything you can afford to donate and will put your hard earned money to good use!

story:
Short Summary

Play or be Played is the first stage play to be produced by GRAFORSHA THEATRE & PRODUCTIONS. The new company is engaged in theatrical and diversified communication activities. Graforsha is dedicated to producing Caribbean plays and will be collaborating with Caribbean and American playwrights. Graforsha is dedicated to the exploration of works from emerging artist. We seek to harness the talents of those who love and hunger for the opportunity to be molded in the arts and to be showcased on stage. Graforsha is dedicated to entertain, educate and influence audiences by introducing Caribbean culture through plays, folklore, storytelling and performance arts. We will create quality theater experiences that confront human morality and purpose in this universe. We strive to revamp arts in the Caribbean communities that will allow artist and audience alike, embrace our rich culture through the medium of theatre.

“Play or Be Played” mirrors the life of a young Christian woman who travels from the Caribbean to the USA, to reunite with her fiancée, in hope of a better life. Reality strikes when she discovers her ‘married’ fiancée is living in squalor and that the stories she has been told about America being a land of “milk and honey” quickly fades.  Soon fear of abandonment, homelessness and deportation threatens her loyalty to her love, and she spirals into a life of frivolous sexual escapades.

What We Need & What You Get

Our ultimate goal is to secure funding to produce the stage play; Play or be played On or Off-Broadway.  We need to give the production every opportunity to be seen in front of every individual that cares deeply about immigration, religion, relationship and promiscuity.

Our fundraising goal is $8000. This will pay for:

  • rehearsal space
  • performance space
  • movement workshops for the cast
  • costumes, props, lights, and any set materials
  • insurance
  • posters, flyers  and ad space
  • stipends for our 9 actors, our stage manager, and our designers

Any additional funds beyond our goal will be used for administrative costs, community workshops, and future Graforsha Theatre Productions!

The Impact

With the deterioration of funding for great Caribbean plays, Graforsha Theatre & Productions has made it their mission to bring to life Caribbean Theatre to the heart of New York City.   It has proven so far to be a tedious task with the limited resources for Caribbean artist. We are therefore seeking the assistance of everyone, who believe in the art of originality and the belief that every culture or artist must be given equal opportunity to tell their stories through any medium of the Arts. Your contribution irrespective of the amount will become that rock of hope for strong Caribbean Theatre.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know everyone is  not in a position to help financially, but please take time to read about our project and if you find it interesting please share it with others through social media or any other suitable venue. Let your friends know we will take $1 – Thank you all.

Graforsha is dedicated to entertain, educate and influence audiences by introducing Caribbean culture through plays, folklore, storytelling and performance arts. We will create quality theater experiences that confront human morality and purpose in this universe. We strive to revamp arts in the Caribbean communities that will allow artist and audience alike, embrace our rich culture through the medium of theatre.
“Play or Be Played” mirrors the life of a young Christian woman who travels from the Caribbean to the USA, to reunite with her fiancée, in hope of a better life. Reality strikes when she discovers her ‘married’ fiancée is living in squalor and that the stories she has been told about America being a land of “milk and honey” quickly fades.  Soon fear of abandonment, homelessness and deportation threatens her loyalty to her love, and she spirals into a life of frivolous sexual escapades.


What We Need & What You Get
Our ultimate goal is to secure funding to produce the stage play; Play or be played On or Off-Broadway.  We need to give the production every opportunity to be seen in front of every individual that cares deeply about immigration, religion, relationship and promiscuity.
Our fundraising goal is $8000. This will pay for:

rehearsal space
performance space
movement workshops for the cast
costumes, props, lights, and any set materials
insurance
posters, flyers  and ad space
stipends for our 9 actors, our stage manager, and our designers

Any additional funds beyond our goal will be used for administrative costs, community workshops, and future Graforsha Theatre Productions!


The Impact
With the deterioration of funding for great Caribbean plays, Graforsha Theatre & Productions has made it their mission to bring to life Caribbean Theatre to the heart of New York City.   It has proven so far to be a tedious task with the limited resources for Caribbean artist. We are therefore seeking the assistance of everyone, who believe in the art of originality and the belief that every culture or artist must be given equal opportunity to tell their stories through any medium of the Arts. Your contribution irrespective of the amount will become that rock of hope for strong Caribbean Theatre.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
We know everyone is  not in a position to help financially, but please take time to read about our project and if you find it interesting please share it with others through social media or any other suitable venue. Let your friends know we will take $1 – Thank you all.

story:
I am raising funds to attend part 1 of Cirque du Soleil's basic social circus training in Orlando, Florida, in November - to learn how to utilize specific teaching methodologies to bring circus arts to at-risk students; to work with them in a way that encourages healthy relationships, healthy self-image, and personal power!

HOWEVER! In the event that I do not raise enough funds to attend the training, any donations made to this campaign will go directly to the Warm Springs Elementary School Music Fund in order to purchase instruments or fund an amazing field trip for the students. Rest assured that no matter what, your contribution is going to help the kids directly! 

Circus, in my opinion - more than any other art form - has the unique ability to fuse athleticism, theatre, dance, and visual art in such a way as to empower the individual from every angle. Circus can be everything. It is the ultimate personal development tool, as it incorporates and engages everything that makes us human - our bodies, our intellect, our ability to connect with, engage, and trust others. No circus artist is ever 'just' a juggler, contortionist, aerialist, stilt-walker - they must also be community-builders, culture creators and multi-faceted artists with intimate knowledge of struggle, self-discipline, and facing fear. Circus is inherently a dialogue between artist and audience, so practitioners have to learn how to engage with and speak to those that watch them. It is also inherently giving and trusting - practitioners must learn to trust their coaches, trust their partners, and most importantly - trust themselves. 

I would love nothing more than to see the teaching methodologies for social circus brought to the Native American children I currently work with, and to future students of mine from all walks of life. Being selected to attend this training is a great honor for me, and what I want most is to bring these skills back to those who need it most.

*The teaching methods learned from Cirque du Soleil will be brought directly back to the students I currently teach here in Warm Springs. There is not currently, nor has there ever been to my knowledge, any opportunity here for children to learn circus arts. I believe that utilizing the methods and techniques of social circus will help boost self-confidence and bring joy to a community still experiencing the emotional, mental and physical consequences of severe historical trauma.

I will incorporate methods learned from Cirque directly into my music classroom, as well as host one or more free after-school workshops this spring, incorporating the structure and training from Cirque, to craft a student-driven performance that the kids can do for the community.

I was selected from a competitive pool of applicants to attend this training. The training is only open to those selected, and an opportunity like this will not arise again until 2014.

The training itself is free, but airfare and lodging is not provided. As an Americorps volunteer, I am currently working without a salary, and cannot afford to attend without help.

A link to the Cirque du Soleil project is here: 

http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/about/global-citizenship/social-circus/cirque-du-monde.aspx

This is a two-part workshop - the first training in November, the second training in February. As I am currently working with an extremely at-risk population - youth on the Warm Springs Indian Reservation - I want to bring the skills learned from this training directly back into my classroom, to an after-school workshop, and back to at-risk youth in The Circus Project (Portland, OR).

Thank you for helping my children succeed!

story:
Momentum Dance Lab

MDL is hosting our 3rd Annual Fundraising Gala to raise funds for our performances, classes and community enrichment activities.  This will be a fun night of dinner and dancing and a silent auction.  We hope you will come join us for the party but, even if you cannot, we ask that you consider helping us reach our fundraising goal so we can continue to offer programming to our community and employment to artists.

We have two main stage shows per year and one major enrichment program.

  • Art Moves
    • 11 years running, this show features a wonderful collaboration between artists, composers, musicians, choreographers and dancers.  This highly original performance is always an audience favorite!
  • Annual Fall show
    • Featuring local choreographers and dancers in a professional theater performance.  All original works are created and we feature award-winning choreographers and dancers.
  • The Positive Effect
    • We offer Healing Movement classes within our community.  These sessions are designed based on the Liz Lerman techniques of crafting creative movement sessions within a class to engage both the body and the mind of participants.  The classes are desigend to be utilized for a wide range of mobility levels and experience.  We are taking this to senior homes, to children with disabilities and to anyone looking to relieve stress and anxiety!!
  • Internships
    • We offer internships for a variety of career choices including stage lighting, public relations/ marketing, arts administration and accounting as well as dance choreography and teacher training. 


We hope you will help us reach our goal and secure another year of wonderful programming for our community!

___________________________________________________________________

How can you support Momentum Dance Lab?

Attend our Fundraising Gala - Friday, April 27th at 7:00 pm!

Held at The Foundry, located at 747 World's Fair Park Drive, our Fundraising Gala is full of dancing, dining, silent auctions and FUN!!  We can't wait to see you!

Dress is business casual.

___________________________________________________________________ 

The Impact You'll Make

By supporting MDL, you'll help us continue our focus on our community.  These are just some of our needs/goals.

  • General operating expenses (facility rental, teachers, advertising, etc.)
  • The Positive Effect program expansion to offer healing movement classes in the community
  • Art Moves program expansion to include student artists and dancers

___________________________________________________________________ 

Can't attend the Gala?

Although we'd love to see you at the Gala, we'd still love your support!  We're excited to offer some perks in return.  Check them out!

 

Thank you so much for your consideration.  We owe everything to you, our supporters!

See you at a show or class soon!

 

You can learn more about Momentum Dance Lab by visiting our website, Facebook and Twitter pages below.

story:
EMU Theatre Inc is an independent theatre group based in Lawrence, Kansas. EMU was founded in 1998 by a collective of actors, writers and performers dedicated to creating theatre which fosters a spirit of cooperation and artistic growth among its practitioners, and a spirit of aesthetic adventure in its audience. Over the years we have performed over 35 shows in Lawrence, Wichita and Kansas City, showcasing the talents of local writers along with the works of noted playwrights like Sam Shepard, David Mamet and David Ives. EMU has collaborated with theatre groups in Lawrence and across the Midwest and annually presents 10-minute play festivals, one-act plays and feature length shows. In 2007, we debuted our critically acclaimed annual Halloween show. E.M.U. Theatre is an inclusive association of individuals dedicated to mounting projects which foster a spirit of cooperation and artistic growth among all artists working in the theatre. We believe in providing opportunities, through theatre, for people seeking an outlet for their particular artistic expression. Our goal is to further the appreciation of arts and performance in the Lawrence community while promoting and contributing to our city's rich cultural history. We draw and maintain our strength with an ever-growing membership of veterans and volunteers, keeping the local flavor while expanding the possibilities available in the local arts scene. Idealistic? No doubt. Yet this concept has driven EMU from the beginning and continues to be our foundation.

 

 

Over the years, we have made the most of the resources we have had to keep our ticket prices low. We have managed to do a lot with what little we have.  But even the most inexpensive theater production is still a costly affair. Our resources are running low and our best equipment is nearly worn-out from use. So we are asking you, friend of EMU, to help us out by making a tax-deductible contribution to our first ever fundraising campaign!

 

Here is a list of just some of the things your contribution will help us accomplish:

 

·        Dedicated rehearsal space for our upcoming productions, something EMU has rarely had and which has limited our ability to reach our full potential, especially for large cast shows like our upcoming Shakespeare in the park production of The Tempest.

·        Quality makeup to replace aging makeup supplies that may be dangerous to the health of our performers, and the case to store it in too.

·        Enough extension cords to provide light backstage, as well as on stage, so our actors won’t bump into each other.

·        Storage containers for our meager equipment so that it will stay useful over time, and maybe even . . .

·        Find a new home for our props, costumes, flats, and equipment so the Sorrels can finally park their car in their garage!

 

Our artists have been held back by limits of living room rehearsals and out-of-date equipment for far too long. Our history proves that we can make a dollar stretch, but we’re ready to flap our stubby little EMU wings and see how high we can get off the ground with a few more dollars. While we’d love to find a sugar daddy with deep pockets, every little bit helps:

·        Your donation of as little as $10 will buy a storage container to keep our costumes well-preserved.

·        Your donation of as little as $20 guarantees our performers a full hour of productive, uninterrupted rehearsal time in a reserved space.

·        Your donation of as little as $40 will buy a quality extension cord to extend our lighting capabilities.

·        Your donation of $100 will provide a month of storage for our flats and equipment in a secure storage facility.

·        Your donation of $300 would secure an entire week of uninterrupted rehearsal time in a reserved space (and our undying gratitude).

 

Your support really means a lot to us and your donation will make a direct improvement in our artists’ abilities to realize their goals.  We hope you will have an opportunity to see your money in action in our upcoming production of The Tempest, directed by Todd Schwartz, in summer 2011 and our next full season of shows beginning in August of 2011.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

EMU Theatre is always looking for volunteers: actors, directors, desgners, visual artists, technicians, concession stand workers, ticket takers, poster hangers etc.  If you're interested in getting involved please let us know by emailing emutheatre@yahoo.com

story:
"The Lord's Lover"

Coming to Hollywood March 2013, at the beautiful, kitchy, cool club/restaurant, "Los Globos" on Sunset Blvd! The show is a collection of thought-provoking, humorous scenes, live music, dance performance and video projections, artfully strung together by a star-crossed love story, in an elegant cabaret setting. Satirical drama and philosophical hi-jinks passionately explore the timeless mysteries of Love and God.
____________________________

Including ~

• The Lord takes a vacation, leaving all of creation to its own
    devices in “The Playing God”

• Three people of various sexual preferences fall in love,
    in an unfortunate configuration called
       “A Bermuda Love Triangle”

• A down-on-his luck man meets Jesus in a bar, in
       “Second Coming, Last Call”

A cast of 13 actors, 7 musicians (bass, drums, vocals, trumpet, guitar, accordion, percussion), a stage crew, and one writer/director/producer/trouble-maker are hard at work now on this production. See hear more at: www.LordsLoverShow.com

We Need Your Help For...

  • Costumes& Make-Up
  • Rehearsal space rental for the Band
  • Props & Set Construction
  • Advertising& Marketing
  • Printing costs for programs, fliers, etc.
  • Stipends for our hard-working, talented actors, musicians and production staff. 

This campaign also gives people who want to see the show the opportunity to get their tickets at a discount price, along with some great perks of music downloads, CD's, T-shirts, invites to an exclusive cast/musicians party and so much more!

Our actors, crew & musicians are working very hard and will only receieve a percentage of this fund, plus tickets purchased through other sources, such as at the door on the nights of the show. Hlep reward our talented cast, crew and musicians for all their hard work in this one of a kind production!

This is a "flexible" fund-raising campaign, so even if we don’t reach our entire goal, every bit donated helps. And if the gods smile upon us, blessing us with more than our modest amount of $666, then we get that dough too. (HellzYeah!)

The Difference Your Contribution Will Make:

You will be appreciated. No matter what the size of your donation, it will help and we are eternally grateful to you! You will feel the Love. We will feel the Love. It will be a virtual Love Fest. Rainbows will fill the skies and unicorns will once again romp with joyous kittens over hills & streams.

  • "The Lord's Lover" may change the world. (It is not a sequel or a prequel, but an original work of art) And you can say you were there.
  • You will be the envy of all your friends, enemies, co-workers, loyal subjects and/or minions
  • Your heart will grow two(2) sizes. Your brain will grow three (3) and your package might even swell a bit.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute $, you can still...

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Tell your friends, family, local talk show hosts, random strangers you meet on the bus, in elevators, or in your own highly stylized dream sequences...
  • Go all "hi-tech" and "moderne" by using the fancy, shmancy Indiegogo share tools here.
  • Set aside some quiet time in your cave, palace, teepee, chateau or harem in powerful prayer, voodoo dance, cha-cha, woo-woo or appalachian hoe-down in our name. WE will know. Thank you for all you do!

story:
"The world is a confusing place.  There are a lot of things around us that we don't understand, and theatre is our way of crying out for help. With theatre, we wish to ask those questions honestly and loudly, and hopefully more questions will appear and have to be asked but not necessarily answered." 

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Artistic Directors Pedro Chamale and Derek Chan are collaborating with a cast of six to produce the third show in their Orestia Trilogy, completing their Elements cycle.

Past productions in the Cycle include: Keep to the West (Wind, 2009), Mobilis in Mobili (Water, 2011), From Whence he Came (Earth, 2011). 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Where Our Money Will Be Going:

Our Projected Costs & Budget for the gods detest you:

$1700 ~ Astorino's Catering Hall rental
$ 300 ~ Insurance coverage for our crew, equipment, and our audience
$ 200 ~ Equipment rental, not limited to lighting, sound, and projection equipment.
$ 100 ~ Advertising materials (posters, post cards, and e-mail campaigns)
$ 100 ~ Creation Materials for the devising process.
$ 100 ~ Costumes.

Total Show Budget: $2500 

All proceeds raised will be going to produce our third show, including covering the costs of venue rental, insurance, licensing, and providing our hard working team with a modest honourarium. 

*A note: Astorino's is a banquet hall being repurposed as a space to serve the community of East Vancouver. There is no existing equipment or tools other than 150 chairs and a lot of character. We are thankful to have the chance to help volunteer our time and energy to help turn this basic space into a prime, accessible hall for groups producing programs of all kinds. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


About Us:

rice & beans theatre is a company interested in telling stories in unique, innovative ways. We strive to create thought provoking, boundary pushing art that is passionately intimate and delicately violent. We are always excited to work with new and emerging artists from all disciplines. 

Pedro Chamale - Co-Artistic Director
Derek Chan - Co-Artistic Director
Christina Andreola - Production and Technical Director
Stevie Benisch - Managing Producer

Total Show Budget: $2500 All proceeds raised will be going to produce our third show, including covering the costs of venue rental, insurance, licensing, and providing our hard working team with a modest honourarium. 
*A note: Astorino's is a banquet hall being repurposed as a space to serve the community of East Vancouver. There is no existing equipment or tools other than 150 chairs and a lot of character. We are thankful to have the chance to help volunteer our time and energy to help turn this basic space into a prime, accessible hall for groups producing programs of all kinds. 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
About Us:
rice & beans theatre is a company interested in telling stories in unique, innovative ways. We strive to create thought provoking, boundary pushing art that is passionately intimate and delicately violent. We are always excited to work with new and emerging artists from all disciplines. Pedro Chamale - Co-Artistic DirectorDerek Chan - Co-Artistic DirectorChristina Andreola - Production and Technical DirectorStevie Benisch - Managing Producer

story:
Northwestern students of all sorts will be asked to submit cards with their secrets on them. Any secret. All secrets. 

In turn, the ensemble of MURMURS will create a piece that will perform 12-15 of the secrets. They will also have a formula for creating those small vignettes, because...

At every show, people wanting free admission will bring new secrets, and three of those secrets will be performed LIVE with the murmurer in the audience.

Everyone wants to be heard. However, in order to help people have their stories told, we need your support. Murmurs is an entirely student-produced show, so we need as much help as you can give to fund this special event. The show runs from June 5 to June 7, and we'd love to see you there!

story:
Short Summary

ABOUT NEW STREET DANCE GROUP (NSDG): Since 2009, New Street Dance Group (NSDG) has been bringing our dynamic form of collaborative dance-theatre to audiences throughout Southeastern Pennsylvania and beyond. Co-directed by former college roommates Shannon Dooling and Krista Armbruster, collaboration, authenticity, and artistry are our hallmarks. Our performances cross disciplines,  often incorporating live and original music, spoken word, and design, and we are committed to creating high-quality, accessible work for a variety of audiences.  By encouraging honest collaboration across artistic genres, authentic movement, and moving performance, we try  to create dance experiences that are thought-provoking, challenging, uplifting, and fun! With collaborators in the Philadelphia and Washington, DC Metro areas, we enjoy a wide performing and teaching radius. We have performed in showcases and festivals in Philadelphia, Bethlehem, PA, New York City, and the DC area, in addition to self-producing annual spring concerts and Philadelphia FringeArts Festival performances. 

ABOUT "ANOTHER WORD FOR MISSING" (AWFM): Another Word for Missing was derived and choreographed by NSDG Co-Directors Krista Armbruster and Shannon Dooling. It will be our fifth self-produced show and our third Philadelphia FringeArts Festival appearance. It is our largest and most ambitious performance to date. The work examines the theme of "missing" through intellectual, emotional, and movement-based lenses. Our research and creative explorations have brought us to stories of long lost love letters, autism spectrum disorder, endangered runaways, and the Bermuda Triangle, and to the development of new and re-imagined choreographic devices inspired by the missing theme. We hope to bring to light critical societal issues through the work, such as autism awareness and human trafficking, and to create an engaging, entertaining experience for our audience. The cast is compromised of 9 dancers and 12 musicians. The show features a score by composer Alexandra T. Bryant, including a world premiere original composition, and a set design by the choreographers. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $500 for basic production supplies - costumes, set materials, and music. This a fraction of our total cost, which also includes, theatre rental, production fees, marketing costs, insurance, and travel expenses. The dancers and musicians have generously donated their time and talents to this production - it is truly a labor of love. 

In return for the love you show us through your donation, we're offering some pretty neat perks. Every donor of at least $5 will receive a thank you card signed by the cast. Additional thank you gifts are listed as well. 

    The Impact

    Your support will help New Street Dance Group during a critical juncture in our history. We are poised and ready to expand our artistic, educational, and outreach efforts, but cannot do so without financial support. Funds raised during this campaign will help us not only put up Another Word For Missing, but will ultimately enable us to grow and thrive as an organization. Every dollar raised for AWFM up front will enable us to divert proceeds from ticket sales to compensation for our collaborating artists and to future artistic and educational programming. We can only continue to make and share high-quality dance experiences with your help - for which we are most grateful!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Please, share this page on your social media sites and help spread the word about the campaign. Be sure to join us on Saturday, September 13 at 7:30pm at Performance Garage in Philadelphia for Another Word For Missing!

story:
WHO ARE YOU?

Open Booth is a New York-based theatre company dedicated to creating new plays that explore big ideas through an intimate lens. And much like a booth (hah), we’re open to anyone who’s quick enough to grab a seat. We believe that plays begin with questions but do not generally end with answers. We believe that the best plays are made from ensemble, luck, and the ordinary moments that you'd usually forget. We do not believe in Shakespeare, adaptations, or anything that an old person would describe as a “laugh riot!”


WHAT ARE YOU DOING?

Open Booth’s inaugural production is SHE, written by Renée Roden and directed by Joey Doyle. SHE follows three high school girls over the course of one day: from bathroom to bathroom, from sink to stall, from mirror to mirror to mirror to mirror to mirror. Staged site-specifically in a real high school bathroom, SHE asks: How well do you know the person you tell everything to? And how the hell did that awful Christine get such a toned butt?


NO, BUT LIKE, WHO ARE YOU?

Open Booth was founded by six Notre Dame grads living in New York. Renee and Joey are two of the aforementioned grads. #grads
Here’s a little more about them.


RENEE RODEN
Playwright

Renée Darline Roden is a writer/director/performer and an unabashed native of Minnesota, and had her start in theatre in the lovely theatre community of the Twin Cities, where she will most likely come to a pathetic and anonymous end. As a performer: she has appeared with the Tony Award-winning Minneapolis Children’s Theatre Company (The Magic Mrs. Piggle-Wiggle, Bert and Ernie, Goodnight!), The Playwright’s Center (Planting Shelley Anne), Upright Egg Theatre Company (A Midsummer Night’s Dream), and the egg at the Theatre Royal Bath, UK (How I Became a Pirate). As a director: she has wreaked havoc at the University of Notre Dame (On the Verge), and orchestrates the love lives of friends. As a writer: her work has been produced at the University of Notre Dame (SHE), and received development with Project Y Theatre (Genna the Goldfish Solves it All, The Official Hurricane Namebook). As a teaching artist: she works at Cristo Rey New York High School in East Harlem helping teenagers tackle Our Town, and at Stages Theatre Company in Minnesota, helping four-year-old thespians not tackle each other. When not doing any of that, Renée tweets, eats, and blogs. (Always in that order.)


JOEY DOYLE
Director


Joey Doyle is a director and a writer. His directing credits include God of Carnage (production: University of Notre Dame), The Demise of the Downtown Bar Scene (co-writer, production: University of Notre Dame), and Beneath My Skin (production: University of Dotre Name). As a writer, he works on staff for The Garbage Time (thegarbagetime.com) and finished this bio himself. Joey works full-time at the digital production company BrandCinema and freelances as a film editor. Joey Doyle is fine. He’s totally fine at what he does. He’s like, fine. He once met Oprah and asked her if she was the lady from those infomercials about blankets.


WHO ELSE IS INVOLVED?

These people!

Cast: Emily Dauer, Katherine Dudas, and Meaghan Adawe McLeod
Producer: Charlie O’Leary
Technical Director: John Yost
Choreographer: Brock Switzer
Stage Manager: Arshia Panicker
Costume Designer: Sam Squeri
Props Designer: Maddie Landon
Social Media: Lesley Stevenson
Graphic Designer: Colleen Hancuch


WHEN AND WHERE IS THIS HAPPENING?

SHE will run from July 23 – August 8, at 8:00 PM on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. Performances will take place in the third floor women’s restroom at Cristo Rey New York High School (112 E 106th Street) in New York.


WHERE CAN I GET TICKETS?

You can’t! (Yet.) As of right now, the only way to guarantee a seat at a performance is by donating to this campaign. For an upfront donation of $15 – the cost of a full-price ticket – you’ll be able to guarantee yourself a spot in the bathroom.


WAIT, YOU'RE SERIOUS? THIS IS ACTUALLY HAPPENING? HOW?!

In addition to all the great folks above who’ve donated their time and talents, Cristo Rey New York High School has given us use of their third floor women’s bathroom for the run of the show, and we’ve also received a generous donation of a high-end theatrical lighting package. This campaign is to cover a portion of the remaining production costs – but no matter what happens, at the end of July, SHE will be coming to a bathroom near you (assuming you live in New York – otherwise, it will be coming to a bathroom that is not near you).


WHERE IS MY MONEY GOING? WHAT ARE THESE “REMAINING PRODUCTION COSTS”?

We’re glad you asked!

Sound (including QLab/speaker rentals): $250
Props (including special effects): $150
Incidental tech costs: $100
Marketing/art design: $250
Printing (posters, postcards, programs): $150


WAIT, IT LOOKS LIKE YOU'VE HIT YOUR GOAL. SO WHERE IS MY MONEY GOING NOW?

$1000 was the amount we needed to meet all of our basic production needs for this show. But if we raise more, we can make the show even better, and even make some strides towards establishing ourselves as a company, lowering our cost of production in the future.

  • If we're able to hit $1300, we'll be able to add a great special effect to the show's final scene. (We'd tell you more, but we don't want to give it away!)
  • If we're able to hit $1600, we'll be able to purchase (instead of rent) sound software and equipment, supplies that will greatly decrease the cost of our future productions.
  • If we're able to hit $1750, we'll be able to purchase a high-end microphone for recording future videos and theatrical sound effects.
  • If we're able to hit $1900, we'll be able to renew our website lease for another full year.
But honestly, that's about it. Beyond that, your donation will fund the continued work of Open Booth Theatre Company. Your contributions will go directly towards future play development and productions, allowing us to continue creating new works.


THIS ALL SOUNDS NICE, BUT HOW IS THE AUDIENCE GOING TO FIT IN A BATHROOM?

SHE will be performed for an intimate audience of 13 each night. The show will run about 70 minutes – and no, you will not need to sit on a toilet. There will be stools. We promise.


ARE YOU INSANE, LITERALLY?

Yes.


OKAY, JUST MAKING SURE. I’M READY TO DONATE!

Thank you! We’re really, really grateful to have people like you that are willing to back weird new work like this. Check out the rewards on the side to see what you can get for your donation.


WAIT, I CAN’T DONATE. BUT I’D LIKE TO HELP OUT!

Thank you! You can help us by spreading the word about this campaign: via Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tinder, Snapchat Story, or just by screaming loudly into the void.

story:
Balloons Theatre is a devised theatre performance collective, including Joshua Webb, Bryony Cole, Emily Sitch, Bj McNeill and Nastazja Somers. McNeill and Somers also run theatre company No Offence Theatre, which brought the 5 star hit Torn Apart (Dissolution) to Theatre N16 in 2015. 

Balloons theatre are only in the first year of production and are currently taking the steps needed to power on to make theatre for years to come. Your help would be a massive step towards the future. 

Eastlake Productions, a production company co producing our Edinburgh transfer ran by Jamie Eastlake, artistic director of Theatre N16 , a "trailblazing" company that wants to change the face of the theatre industry. Eastlake’s career in producing includes four Edinburgh Fringe productions as well as over twenty across the North East and London. His recent project which he also directed YOUR EVER LOVING, a political piece about The Guildford Four has taken the OFF WEST END scene by storm receiving high acclamation from both the audiences and the critics.

Jamie "Is going to break the big time and do the North East proud" Newcastle Chronicle. 

The Rules of Inflation

Born from the idea of creating a political piece of art by exploring the most basic rules and questioning the pathological patterns of our society, The Rules of Inflation is an immersive piece of performance art theatre that aims to make even the most comfortable uncomfortable.

We live in a world of power, rules and leaders. But really, it’s all just one big game. Do you want to come and play? If so, welcome to your childhood dream: a world full of colours, celebrations, a party, games and… rules? And you know the rules. You would never dare to break them, would you? Play the game, balloons and stakes are high and there is no way out. We take you on a journey where nothing is the way it seems. Come to our party and meet the other guests: Green, institutionalised and obedient; Pink, curious, competitive and outcast; Yellow, playful and naïve; and Blue, abused, objectified and wise. And, of course, our game controller.

“wild and pioneering” Grumpy Gay Critic ★★★★

“This is theatre that stays with you long after the event itself and compels you to talk about it“ Ginger Wig ★★★★

“Brilliant yet highly traumatic(…)Never have I left a theatre more swiftly after a performance, and never has a play had a more lasting and profound effect. “ A Younger Theatre

“The Rules of Inflation constantly made me reassess about what I was seeing and feeling” Female Arts Magazine

Following a highly successful one week run at Theatre N16 in March “The Rules of Inflation” is now going to The Edinburgh Fringe and will play at The Space, Surgeons Hall from 15-20th of August.

WE NEED YOUR HELP :

Balloons Theatre is a new theatre company, therefore we rely solely on our own private funds; crowdfunding is the major platform to help us create our work. 

In order to pay for our show and accommodation we need a further £1000 on top of the funds generated so far from our London run of the show.

“The Rules of Inflation “has been created by us in order to voice a socio-political message in the most crazy and bonkers way possible! We also can’t deny the fact that this piece belongs at The Festival and it would be absolutely amazing for us to be able to take it there without owing money to the banks.   


Thanks for reading. Your help would be invaluable.

story:
Journey to the Centre of the Earth

We are fundraising to develop and write a new production, Journey to the Centre of the Earth. This will be an darkly comedic adventure that examines what happens when we dig down.

The story?

Four geo-scientist wunderkinden journey to the centre of Earth to find the answer to climate change. Standing on the drifting plates of the aesthenosphere, their light goes out. Darkness settles. Panic ensues. In the darkness, not knowing, they begin to dispute the way forward.

Why this show?

Plastic, silicon, oil, gas, mining, £££ and the big CC????? (Climate change - but we prefer not to say it out loud.) What does one do about these issues when you're not a scientist and feel the guilty claw around your neck every time you order an almond milk latte? As performers, we naturally thought we could don our adventure gear, BECOME the scientists, dig a big hole and see if any answers come to light.

Money matters?

We were granted an Artist Residency at Fljotstunga (an eco-farm in the Icelandic wilderness dedicated to supporting international artists). However, the residency doesn't cover little things like food, transport and toilet paper.  We've already funded our flights, fees and preliminary research costs, but we need your help to feed and transport the artists while they make brave new theatre! You can also help by sharing this campaign in your social media network.

Residency Fee: £200

Flights/Train: £680

Car Hire: £600

Insurance: £112

Food: £300

If we receive more then our target amount, your donations will go towards venue hire in London, basic props, lighting equipment (torches!) and materials.

So far, we have support from The Pleasance Theatre, Fljotstunga Iceland, Corn Exchange Newbury, Culture and Ecology Network, Chats Palace and Look Mum No Hands. Please join these incredible organisations to help us create Journey to the Centre of the Earth.

What is HOAX?

Hoax is a collective of international theatre makers committed to making and presenting work that responds to ecological and environmental issues. Our goals for Journey to the Centre of the Earth are:

1) Make an incredible, inspired, accessible and informed piece of theatre.

2) Ensure Journey to the Centre of the Earth gets a UK tour in 2016.

3) Continue putting skilled actors/creators with something to say about complex issues at the forefront of UK theatre, not just in this show but in future productions too.

Meet the Team

AYESHA TANSEY is an actor and a creative producer who has studied at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama (London) and Jaques Lecoq (Paris). She has worked with MKA: Theatre of New Writing, Les Foules, SpaceJunk, One Taste Cabaret, Miriam Austin, the RAF, BAE Systems, Allanah Madeline Foundation, Look Twice. 

FLAVIA BERTRAM is a physical theatre performer who trained in Corporeal Mime. She has worked with with Twisted Hip, OneTaste Theatre, NOH Budget Theatre, Theatre Re and the Canadian Opera Company. 

KRISTOFFER HUBALL is a two year graduate of the Lecoq school in Paris. He is a co-founder of Rhum and Clay Theatre Company and has worked internationally with companies such as Wildworks (BAC) Tanz Theatre Wuppertal Pina Bausch, Annish Kapoor and Akram Kahn. 

SABRINA MANAC'H trained at Lecoq in Paris and at Caen. She has worked across Europe, Turkey, Australia and North Africa with Les Horzinzins, Cie PNT and Melbourne French Theatre. 

LUCY CLAIRE is a London based composer originally from the North East of England who trained at London’s Royal College of Music in composition and music for the moving image. 

ANDREA CARR is a scenographer, performance maker and artist, with a first class honours degree in Theatre Design from Nottingham Trent University and an M.A from Slade School of Art. She has worked recently with Michela Sisti, WOW Festival Southbank, Extant, Kew Gardens, and Bath Fringe Festival. She is currently creating the 'EcoStage Pledge'. 

The Perks are no HOAX, check them out! 

£10+ We will write your name in the sand and take a photo of it and send it to you! It will be like you are right there in Iceland with us! 

£15+ You wil receive a hand carved, hand made cutlery set- crafted by Avinder S Nanray@ Building Blocks.

£25+ A tickets to the red carpet event of Journey to the Centre of the Earth.
£65 Two tickets to 5 **** tour comedy tour (Londonist Pick of the Festival 2015) The Ugliest Buildings in London.


£100 Organic Picnic Basket for two by Michael Harrison @ the Cornwall Project accompanied by Look Mum No Hands local ale. 


£250 A night's accommodation in Monmartre, Paris.



£500 Your pick of a limited edition print by Andrea Carr (currently exhibited at the British Museum) 

Andrea Carr
story_txt:
Journey to the Centre
of the Earth
We are fundraising to develop and write a new production,
Journey to the Centre of the Earth. This will be an darkly comedic adventure
that examines what happens when we dig down.
The story?
Four geo-scientist wunderkinden journey to the centre
of Earth to find the answer to climate change. Standing on the drifting plates
of the aesthenosphere, their light goes out. Darkness settles. Panic ensues. In
the darkness, not knowing, they begin to dispute the way forward.
Why this show?
Plastic, silicon, oil, gas, mining, £££ and the big CC????? (Climate change - but we prefer not to say it out loud.) What does one do about these issues when you're not a scientist and feel the guilty claw around your
neck every time you order an almond milk latte? As performers, we
naturally thought we could don our adventure gear, BECOME the scientists, dig a big hole and see if any answers come to light.
Money matters?
We were granted an Artist Residency at Fljotstunga (an
eco-farm in the Icelandic wilderness dedicated to supporting international
artists). However, the residency doesn't cover little things like food,
transport and toilet paper.  We've already funded our flights, fees and preliminary research costs, but we need your help to feed and transport the artists while they make brave new theatre! You can also help by sharing this campaign in your
social media network.Residency Fee: £200Flights/Train: £680Car Hire: £600Insurance: £112Food: £300
If we receive more then our target amount, your
donations will go towards venue hire in London, basic props, lighting
equipment (torches!) and materials.
So far, we have support from The Pleasance Theatre,
Fljotstunga Iceland, Corn Exchange Newbury, Culture and Ecology Network, Chats
Palace and Look Mum No Hands. Please join these incredible organisations to
help us create Journey to the Centre of the Earth.
What is HOAX?
Hoax is a collective of international theatre makers
committed to making and presenting work that responds to ecological
and environmental issues. Our goals for Journey

story:
Death of the Persian Prince will have its World Premiere at the 2015 Midtown International Theater Festival in New York City, July 13 - Aug. 2, 2015.  It is a prestigious honor to be selected to participate in the festival, and we are raising funds to support the production needs of the play. 

Death of the Persian Prince is a powerful new play by Dewey Moss (The Crusade of Connor Stephens, A Normal Life, All the Way from Arp, TX) that sheds light on the growing practice of gay Iranians being pressured or forced into sex changes in order to avoid legal execution. While sex change operations are legal in Iran, homosexuality is punishable by death.

According to a 2014 BBC documentary, exact numbers of sex change operations are difficult to obtain. State government statistics claim that "sexual adjustment surgeries" rose from 170 in 2006 to 370 in 2010; however, one doctor well known for performing the surgeries claimed he alone carries out over 200 surgeries each year. Furthermore, additional studies claim that 45% of people receiving the surgery were not transgender, but rather gay or lesbian told to have the surgery to avoid legal persecution.  (Watch the referenced documentary at https://youtu.be/Wg51RnpGn9k?list=UUHHHU4lEp_N5-p9H98oh9xg).  

Join us in supporting international LGBT rights by supporting this play.  The theater is a powerful educational tool, and it is our hope that this play will continue to educate and create conversations to help further rights for LGBT individuals worldwide.

story:
OUR BAD MAGNET!!

Mary-Arrchie Theatre Company is proud to present a brand new production of OUR BAD MAGNET by Douglas Maxwell, featuring Dan Behrendt, Lane Flores, Layne Manzer, and John Ross Wilson. Directed by Carlo Lorenzo Garcia.

About the show:

On the shores of Scotland, three 9 year old boys begrudgingly befriend a troubled young outsider, a gifted but tormented child who harbors the ability to spin magical, often fable-like fairy tales. The boys, now men, reunite years later to try to piece together the circumstances that led to the mysterious disappearance of their childhood fascination.

Playwright Douglas Maxwell, one of Scotland’s brightest young writing talents, uses his own unique brand of dark humor to take us on a magical journey in which the boundaries between fantasy and reality merge with unpredictable results.

“Under the impeccable direction of Carlo Lorenzo Garcia, the superb actors morph easily through their three stages of development and use Maxwell’s mix of real and hothouse language and goth imagination to maximum effect. This gifted ensemble also makes sure the play’s modern-day Grimm fairy tale quality haunts you long after you’ve left the theater.”
-Chicago Sun-Times (Hedy Weiss, Highly Recommended)

Where does the money go?

We have an amazing group of artists working on this project and we want to be able to compensate them for their time as well as invest in the design elements for the production to re-create the magic of this beautiful play!

(Reheasal Shot 2015)

Other Ways You Can Help

Tweet it! Facebook It! Email it! Help us by sharing the message and this link:
http://igg.me/at/ourbadmagnet/x/5749162

You can also buy tickets to a performance here

Production Team:

Anthony DeMarco - Stage Manager

Allison Goetzman - SM Advisor

Gus Menary - Assistant Director

Stefin Steberl - Costumes

Matt Gawryk - Lights

Joe Court - Sound

Mike Sanow - Technical Director

Thad Hallstein - Set Advisor
